description:
This place is really nice. It's pretty dark inside so it took a while for my eyes to adjust. Service was great I was asked if I was there for dinner or HH. I was getting the option to choose a tall chair or booth. I choose the tall chair. With had my feet dangling and I'm 6'3" 

Order oysters, fritters, and both chicken and steak stewards. The fritter was really interesting plus the sauce it came with so yummy. Everything was amazing! Would recommend and come back again. Price was reasonable.
author: Mo N.

description:
Come for happy hour! I cannot comment on the food options and prices outside of it, but if you are able to make it during this time, it's a a good deal. It makes dining in the heart of Union Square and the city more affordable. Cocktails on their list are $6 with numerous small bites at reasonable prices. And try an order of the corn fritters. This small bite was one of my favorites, and it's vegetarian friendly if you are one. One con of the small bites is it won't fill you up per se.

The reason for 4 stars instead of 5 stars is it blends in with other restaurants in the area. The Asian twist is great, and I thoroughly enjoyed the food. With that in mind, there are many places with nice decor, solid food, and good service. E&O's happy hour stands out for sure, but nothing stood out that tells me to come back here as many times as possible. Nonetheless, still a solid choice when in the area.
author: Brandon S.

description:
I loved this place. The happy hour is unbeatable - the dumplings are $1 and the mushroom satay is $2. I had a tasty cocktail for $6. I dined alone and ate at the bar, which has a very contemplating and swanky feel to it. The wait staff was polite and fairly attentive. 

The gem of my trip here was the Japanese-Bop. This tasty take on the Korean bibimbap was incredible. The rice was fried to be crispy, but, it wasn't overdone so as to be chewy or burnt - as can be the case in some of the more "homey" Korean places I've been to. The pickles were an excellent twist to the standard Korean radishes. I'm not from San Francisco and, that's probably for the best. If I was - I'd go broke eating here.
author: Kathryne B.

description:
Came here to meet my niece who just turned 21 for our first happy hours.  Sat at the bar, atmosphere is very pleasant with professional services from staff.  There were few ladies already enjoying their happy hours deal.  

The happy hours food is better than I anticipated or from the review I read.  The oysters were fresh especially great with a happy hour price $1.  Many happy hour dishes are between $1 - $3.5 each.  We ordered 6 oysters, 2 dumplings, 1 duck meat bun, 2 ahi tuna,  2 skewers, 1 corn fritters (comes in 3) and three drinks. The price came out round $50.  Not bad for happy hours 

The wrappers on the dumplings were soft, but not watery and the dipping sweet soy complimented the dumplings.  The beef skewer did not need to add the satay sauce, the natural taste was great, but each piece was not grilled evenly, one piece was perfect medium while the next was over cooked.  The chicken skewers were perfectly tendered.  Moving to the ahi tuna which was very fresh and not choppy, you can bite into each tuna pieces.  Corn fritters were the star, nicely fried with the right amount of proportional corns and breading.  Yes, must return on different occasions.
author: Frances C.

description:
Nice ambiance and great service. Flavors are not quite bold enough for my taste. No zing in the papaya salad. Not enough glaze on the miso cod. 

The decor leans towards chic and fancy. Great place for bringing parents and rellos if you need a classy place with American friendly Asian food. 

From a food perspective, it's on the bland end of Asian Fusion food spectrum.
author: David T.

description:
Came in for my sister's 30th birthday on a Saturday evening. We made a same-day reservation for 6:30PM and were sat immediately. 

First impressions - the restaurant's ambiance is a bit dark but really nice overall. Furthermore, it's huge! There's the main floor where patrons are are sat, but there's also an upstairs and downstairs (I'm guessing for larger parties and events). One slight negative was that the restroom was located downstairs, but there's nothing they can really do about that.

Must try:
- Wood Roasted Black Cod: Incredible, melt in your mouth.
- Shitake Mushroom Dumplings

If it tickles your fancy, perhaps try:
- Steamed duck buns
- Glazed Chinese Eggplant

Skip:
- Prawn and/or Shiitake satay
- Salt and Pepper calamari 
- Chow Mein Noodles
- Indonesian Fried Rice

All of the "skip" items were still good, but weren't anything particularly special in my opinion. I'd rather save my stomach and wallet for the more unique items such as the cod. 

$20 corking fee if you bring your own bottle of wine. A great and solid spot overall!
author: Mars S.

description:
My group was extremely hungry and stumbled into this dimly lit, romantic ambiance restaurant. We weren't even dressed for a typical date night since we were touring downtown SF but I'm ecstatic that we chose to stay. Customer service was A+. 

In terms of food, bless yourself and get the steamed duck buns! Omg, the duck was very tender and aromatic. The buns were sweet, savory, and melted in your mouth. Did I mention that the duck was also crispy on the outside? I wanted to order another one but had to control myself. The deep-fried green beans were seasoned so well; not bland or oily like most places. The Indonesian fried rice was different and light. The pork was delicious and not fatty. Finally, we shared a large appetizer platter that was a good introduction to their popular appetizers! 

TIPS: Make a reservation or else you'll end up sharing communal tables.
author: Fareedha P.

description:
I found that their signature cocktails were a bit too sweet. I tried the 2 cocktails that were at the top of their drink list. I don't remember what they were called but one had bourbon, the other one had scotch and pineapple juice. Both were on the sweet side and bit too frufru for me. 

I had heard a lot about the food here so I was hoping to be amazed but I was a little disappointed. We ordered quite a few entrees but the only thing that stood out in my mind was the Indonesian fried rice and the fried corn fritters, which were both excellent. The others, meh I wasn't too impressed: 
Pork chop - a bit too fatty
Flounder - not enough flavoring/seasoning
Spring Rolls - tasted different from the Asian spring rolls I'm used to, and not in a good way. 

I just was not impressed overall by the food but I'd be willing to give this place a second chance if they changed up their menu
author: Kenson K.

description:
I went here with my cousins the food was good but I think they should improve the size of the servings. Everything we ordered was good but the portioning felt a bit small for the price. We had the to share menu and we tried the calamari, papaya salad, fried rice, satay beef, and the pork ribs. And for dessert we had the ginger cookies. That was really good. 
The service was great. No doubt. But the only thing for me was the portions. We had to add a pad Thai and fried rice to fill us up. But everything was good. If you're in the area you can try it here. If you're craving something different and Asian fusion. It's good here.
author: melissa a.

description:
Me and my girlfriend stopped by on a Sunday for dinner recently after seeing so many great reviews, but it missed the mark really badly for us.  The first problem that became apparent almost immediately was the bad service.  There was only one or two other parties in the entire restaurant when we were here, and we had to actively try to wave a server down.  After ten minutes, someone came but wasn't a server, so he helped us try to find someone.  After five more minutes, a server finally came after we frantically waved our hands.  Definitely not a great start, and the mediocrity continued throughout the night.

We ordered the ~$20 fritter burger and the ~$28 cod.  The fritter burger with fries was alright, and it was a huge portion, but I felt that it was still very overpriced for what you get.  The cod was much worse.  Firstly, the cod wasn't deboned.  There were tiny bones everywhere, which is not acceptable for something we paid $28 for.  The fish tasted dry and frozen, and it lacked flavor throughout.  The vegetables the fish came with were decent, but the entire outer ring of vegetables were colder than room temperature.  Only the vegetables underneath the fish were hot.  

TLDR - Unjustifiably overpriced.  Terrible service and poorly/carelessly cooked food.  Don't make the same mistake we did.  Go somewhere else to eat.
author: Tim L.

description: The food was quite good -- I would give it five stars, if the portions weren't microsized. Unfortunately, the tiny portions left me quite hungry after my entree. Won't be returning. :(
author: Peter L.

description:
After hearing great things of this restaurant from my friends, we decided to go here for dinner with our out of town friends.

Our party of four decided to share dish, family style. We ordered the corn fritters, Asian Ceasar salad, Indonesian fried rice, chicken spring rolls, braised flounder, and grilled kurobata pork chop.  Out of all these dishes, I only liked the corn fritter.

The corn fritter was fried and had a good crisp texture.  I enjoyed the corn pieces in it. The sweet chili sauce that accompanied it, added a nice heat to the fritter.

As for the other dishes, I didn't find anything really appealing to it.  The Asian Ceaser salad was a Ceaser salad. The naan croutons were the only Asian part.  The pork chop was too charred. I found the taste of the fried rice and the flounder to be bland. The chicken spring roll was OK.

I thought the service was spotty. After our server took our order, we never saw her again until we were ready to pay the bill. Though the pork chop was already cut into 4 length wise pieces, you still would need a knife to cut the meat into smaller pieces. I asked for knife and what they brought was a butter knife. I guess they don't have steak knives???

I would only come back for the corn fritter, if I am in the city. And only for happy hour.
author: Marck N.

description:
loved this place. it's been on my list for a while and I'm glad I finally made it. service is wonderful, reservations suggested, but it's bigger than it first appears because there's a large back room. 

beautiful decor throughout

menu is an eclectic mix of asian-fusion. the very good  spicy vinegar pork sandwich (some of the pieces were a little too fatty which was disappointing, but I would try it again) was similar to a banh mi, the jicama salad seemed Thai-inspired. we also had a fritter covered hamburger which was just weird. instead of a bun, it was a hamburger between a coagulated jumble of cooked corn. separately, it all tasted good, but it was too messy to eat as a sandwich.

even with the couple of misses with the menu and food, it's a beautiful space and the service so good that 4 stars is appropriate and I'll definitely be back to try other options on the menu
author: Bob U.

description: The food is pretty good. They have a wide menu of different things. The place was packed and the waitress did a great job keeping on top of our order and what we wanted. We sat in the back and the music wasn't too loud but it was in other places. They seem to have a lot of spaces for big parties. We would go again if we were visiting SF.
author: Desa D.

description:
-high class happy hour-

Buck a shuck oyster

Dumplings

And the fu Fu platter

For 3 people the cost is a little higher than what I normally pay for...but there was no fault in any of the dishes. 

Corn fritters - a prickly fried texture melded with corn. Its hard to explain, but it works really well.

Ribs - looks juicy but are actually dry ribs. Nice flavors

Chicken skewers - cooked really well and goes with a peanut sauce. 

Ahi tuna - a chewy texture on top of a chip. It's nice.

Dumplings - comes with an unncesaarily giant spoon. Tasted great and not overly saucy.

Oysters - briny and simple.
author: Andrew F.

description: Yep. 4 stars. We found two seats at the bar with no wait on a Thursday night, though the place was bustling. The deviled eggs, calamari, and lamb naan were all standout small plates. Service was friendly and efficient. The restaurant decor is showing some wear and tear.
author: Morris R.

description:
This review is primarily for their happy hour! M-Sat 3-6PM.  
They have a pretty decent menu for their HH including drinks and small bites! 

FOOD: 
We came here primarily for their Pupu platter for 2! 
+ The pupu platter: $22: comes with 2 of each item: sliders, rib, chicken satay, tuna ahi bite, corn fritters, some fermented veggies and taro chips! I personally love sampler plates because you can try a bit of everything. The highlight of the platter were the sliders! The ribs were a tad to salty for my taste, but tender! 
+ $1 oysters w/ kimchi sauce: $1 oysters are always worth it. Theses were pretty fresh, but a bit on the smaller side. 
+ Squash dumpling $1: The dumpling was filled with squash and had pretty good spicy curry sauce. But for $1/each I rather skip this item next time. 

SERVICE: 
Very friendly hostess and waitress. I had to wait on my friend who was running late, but she was very attentive in checking to see if I needed water refills or if I wanted to order anything ahead of time. 

AMBIANCE: 
Interior has a classy-dimmed-lights feel, with a hint of traditional feel to it. They have some seats along the walls with majority of the high seat tables. They also have a pretty large bar and some seating upstairs. They can hold up to parties of 12+.  

Verdict: I would come back for HH again!
author: Samantha F.

description:
Love love this place... not far from the Omni San Fran 
BEST appetizers, drinks and good... 
atmosphere is awesome too. 
Very romantic
author: Emily A.

description:
Meh. Very underwhelming for a place that is so highly recommended on Yelp.

Popped in for happy hour and it was very crowded. The interior was visually interesting and not too loud so that was good. Only spot left in the "happy hour" area was at a communal table which was kind of weird. It was husband and I, a dude by himself and then a group of 3 college girls. A random assortment for sure and it made the dining experience... uncomfortable. On to the food we tried:

$1 Oysters: Good, not great. Enjoyed the HH oysters at Plouf more.

Wood Oven Naan: Again, good not great. I think it would be a lot better if the sauces were better. A creamy hummus and/or tzatziki would be more well-received than the chunky raita and chutney they currently serve it with (in my opinion).

Ahi Poppers: My husband LOVED these but they were so tiny. $3 each for literally just one (small) bite.

Duck Buns: I enjoyed but they were super dry. I couldn't taste any of the hoisin sauce that was supposedly on there. These were also super tiny and not worth their price tag of $4 each.

Pea Dumplings: So... My husband and I didn't try these, however, previously mentioned single dude at our communal table did. He ordered two of them. When they were delivered to our table, he dove right in and took a bite. Swallowed and didn't take another bite. Then when the server came around to ask him what else he'd like to order, he told him to take them away because he didn't like them and he wasn't going to eat them... I'm going to assume they weren't great.

We also ordered a couple of their deviled eggs and those were delicious. The char siu bacon... Yum. The drinks were fine too.

Don't go expecting this over the top amazing experience and you will probably enjoy. Order the ahi poppers, deviled eggs and drinks!
author: Cynthia D.

description:
Very yummy and satisfying. Four of us dropped in for lunch on Cinco de Mayo. So I had to get their Tequila Tamarind cocktail. Basically a Margarita with tamarind for sour, salt-chili rim for added kick and sliced fresh jalapenos inside. Excellent. Very well made.

For eatsies we had Lapsang Souchong Tea Deviled Eggs (very tasty, with a touch of smoke), Ahi Tuna Tartare (fresh tuna, good texture), Indonesian Corn Fritters (crunchy and corny - just as you'd imagine), Steamed Pork Buns (chewy bun, well seasoned pork), and the Fritter Burger (huge, impossible to eat w/o knife and fork, and deconstructed into bacon wrapped burger, Indonesian Corn Fritters and togarashi dusted fries). Asked the burger medium-rare and that's the way it came.

The atmosphere is calm, darkish, relaxing. I forgot to take pics of the dishes but did take one: the view going down the stairs to the rest rooms. Could have been a nothing but they placed a lovely flower display that impressed me.

Certainly worth a visit.
author: Crowden S.

description:
I don't get why people rave about this spot. It was mediocre at best. We came here since hops and hominy wouldn't have their full dinner menu until 5 PM. We had an hour to kill so we decided to stop by here to grab some small eats. As soon as we entered this establishment, it just seemed as if all the wait staff were all careless. As soon as we were seated, it took quite a bit of time to get a wait staff to help us get an order in. The first wait staff that helped us was nice but not very knowledgeable about the things that were served. He excused himself and told us he would grab someone else to do our ordering. Another guy came over and we finally got our order in. 

We ordered a dozen oysters and we got the pu pu platter to share. The oysters were good but there was one that tasted kind of foul. Other than that one oyster, the other oysters were quite meaty and had a nice cucumber finish. It was refreshing to slurp up. The pu pu platter was a sampler of all the appetizers. Presentation was nice but that was the only thing great about it. If you are coming here for happy hour, do yourself a favor and don't order food from the HH menu.
author: Ada H.

description:
It's like this restaurant wanted to serve Asian food, then couldn't decide on the exact cuisine so it shoved 4 different countries onto the same menu.  Weird.

I can't remember the last time I had Indonesian, Thai, and Japanese all at once and there's probably a good reason for that.  Food was decent, but nothing really stood out.  The prices were so high for the appetizers, many of which you could get for half the price at a casual Thai restaurant.  

I tried the pad thai, katsu sandwich, corn fritters, burger, calamari, and chickpea fries.  It was our mistake in ordering so many fried foods, but in the end everything started to have the same flavor profile.  Even the katsu sandwich sauce started to taste the same as the pad thai.  I'd recommend ordering a vegetable or something fresh to cleanse your palate in between.

Tips and Tricks
-Ample seating, would be good for a work function
-Would probably come again to try out happy hour
author: Jessica L.

description:
For my last night in San Francisco, I wanted to try something different. I was between Chinese and Asian Fusion then settled for the latter. When I was seated, to my disappointment, I found the ambience and number of people to be lacking probably because it was a Sunday night. However, I soon realised it was up to my friends and I to create our own ambience. 

On the menu, there was a huge variety including everything from Calamari to Mushroom Satay to Chilli Beef. The food did not disappoint and was packed with flavour especially the beef. It tasted amazing due to the chillis and leaves that came with it. The service was very pleasant as they very accomodating and their food recommendations were excellent. 

Overall, even though I did not immediately get trendy vibes from this place (Sunday?), this is a restaurant I recommend if you want have both a relaxing and fun night while enjoying the adventurous taste of Asian Fusion!
author: George W.

description:
Was really impressed by this place and surprised that it took my so long to make it here. It's very close to union square and the financial district, and I've passed it before but never paid much attention to it. It's really spacious, and nicely decorated. 
Sat at the bar and had some small dishes including the chicken lettuce cups. All the food was really good! The service was also impressive, and the bar staff are really friendly. The prices are not bad either. Will definitely come back.
author: Derek M.

description: We came here with a large party of 12 and had reservations, so it was an easy way in. The ambiance is dimly lit and cozy however since our table was right at the far end I was not able to soak up on much the scene in the restaurant. The service was very prompt and good and they made sure we got everything just the way we liked, they even replaced a drink for us since we dint like it . So Great job on the Customer satisfaction. We had a lot of food and mainly ordered things from the starter section. we had the Panir naan, Lamb naan ,Chickpeas fries, Corn fritters, Fries, Chicken lettuce cups ,Crispy chicken spring rolls, Chicken satay, Shirataki mushroom dumplings and Char Siu roasted Black Cod. The food was mostly Ok , it wasn't great but not bad either . Everyone particularly liked the dumplings and the Lamb naan and they were both soft and full of flavors . We all ordered almost three rounds of drinks and some were a hit and some were miss. From what I remember the Jaded Buddha ,maple Bourbon and Vodka Ginger were very popular on our table . Overall It's a good place if you like Asian flavors and could be a good date night spot .
author: Rashi T.

description:
Strolling through Union Square we wanted to have a quick dinner on a holiday. We made reservation on OpenTable for two people, but by the time we made it there we had another friend joining us. They couldn't accommodate the 3 of us for our reservation, we opted to sit at the couches setup by the entry where they do serve dinner as well as drinks. An interesting idea and accommodating, too bad it was by the door and would get the very cold draft with each customer walking in. The decor was as we expected a very nice modern Asian decor.

We ordered the oysters and tuna tartare for appetizers. The oysters were very small, the tuna served was very small amount compared to the rice crackers served. However, the flavor was great. 

The green papaya/cucumber salad lacked flavor by far, I had tried this combo in other restaurants and this was the least flavor I had experienced. The burger with the corn fritters was good but the fritters felt to be a bit too greasy 

All together the service was very good despite the location we were seated, the food was average and the price was way over the quality/portions served.
author: Mehrnaz H.

description:
Asian fusion done in a nice way
Full of business lunch crowd 
Nice service 
Good fish 
Nice Japanese beer
author: Zehr S.

description:
We just paid 220$ to feed 5 people with no alcohol and had the most below average flavorless pap we've had in a long time. 

Shaking  beef tasted like the meat was off.  

Our satays has no flavor. 

The duck buns are dry. 

Literally the only good thing was the service was very good. 

But the food just sucked!
author: David B.

description:
This place was just okay. First of all, the service was slow. We got our menus right away, but they walked by several times before taking our order. I had to ask them a few times to fill up my water cup because they were slow on that as well. Also, the whole restaurant was super dark, a little too dark for our tastes. 
After we ordered, the food came in a reasonable amount of time. We got the duck buns, the chicken satay, and the lamb naan. All of the food was fine. The duck buns were nice, the chicken satay was probably the best of everything we ordered, and the lamb naan was not our favorite. There was barely any lamb inside the naan which did not seem to be how the waitress described it. These 3 dishes for 2 people was not enough, so I would recommend getting 4-5 for 2 people or just larger plates of items. The servers also did not make it easy for us to split the check.
author: Kathryn M.

description: This place has an amazing happy hour. Every time I've been here for dinner or lunch I have never been disappointed. I definitely recommend the black cod,  short rib sliders, shaking beef, spare ribs, and oxtail dumplings. Honestly you can't go wrong here.
author: Sandra F.

description: My friends, what a marvelous place. We snagged a reservation for two on a Sunday night, but ended up just sitting at the bar because we simply couldn't wait another 30 mins for our reservation to eat. Got the ceviche- amazing! I tried to eat the coconut meat but couldn't get much. Dats ok, the ceviche more than made up for it. Plus, taro chips waaaaay better than normal chips. Got the infamous burger and it was everything it was hyped up to be. Also got the sea bass and fried noodles. Yes it was waaaay too much food for two people but we came here to EAT and eat we did. And then we shuffled back home with full bellies and big smiles. Loved it!
author: Shelby G.

description:
Came in around 3pm on a Saturday.  I would maybe come back for the food but the service is EHHHHH. Only one person explained the plates they dropped off in front of us. And it was extremely difficult to flag down our waitress, Jessica, that we had to ask at least 5 different people throughout the night to find our waitress for us. NOT something you'd want to experience in the hustle of downtown SF. Interestingly our waitress was also seating people...short staffed perhaps? 

Happy hour is awesome though $1 oysters and dumplings! Ahi tuna is delicious! Chickpea fries were very hot and crunchy. Chicken satay yummy! Can't fault the food. But with that kind of service I will not eagerly return.
author: Sam M.

description:
Happy hour 3-6 Monday through Saturday! Need I say more?! This restaurant gives you a relaxed lounge vibe with couch seating and the bar area. Th staff are friendly especially the bartender that went out of his way to recommend events for us tourists to enjoy in the city. 

Now for the libations. I had a prickly tequila which was mainly tequila and I will never complain about that. Imagine a prickly pear infused tequila with a little lime squeezed in. For $6 yes please!

Then I had the rum vanilla. It has vanilla infused rum and pineapple juice. Imagine a horchata with rum in it. It was so sweet like a creamsicle candy or dessert. This was my favorite.

I also had the spare rib. It was covered in hoisin and tamarind sauce that was easily some of the best sauce I've ever had. Put that on everything! That rib fell off the bone and into my mouth faster than you can say "last call for alcohol!" Get some! Get more than one though. What was I thinking lol one rib!
author: Alexis M.

description:
Loves coming here for the their happy hour menu for oysters! My friends usually drinks and I usually snack on little bites!
Service is okay, I haven't really experienced a bad services yet. Their happy hour is very popular so comes early if you can. 
I am from San Jose, so I disliked the small and no parking in San Francisco but I get used to it by now. I don't know how people would willing to drive to eat other restaurants if the parking is tight or if you are lucky enough to find a parking spot. I think most of people lives in SF order a lot of food through Uber or doordash. 
Anyway, the happy hour menu is great. I usually order the raw oysters... sometimes up to 50 just two of my friends. 
Yeah, it cheap and good! 
Overall, I recommended coming here during happy hour for their small bites menu. Foods sometimes take a while since oysters is very popular and demanding during their happy hour!
author: Kim T.

description:
This restaurant is located very near the Chinatown entrance and you can find parking at the Sutter/Stockton garage. On arriving it was very busy so reservations is highly recommended.

My friend and I decided to stick to the small plates and skip the entree dishes.  We ordered the raw oysters, curry cerviche, butternut squash wontons, beef ribeye sliders and shittake wontons.  The server was prompt and the food came out in a nice sequence which did not overcrowd our small table.  All the dishes were quite good but the butternut squash wontons were outstanding.  All the curried sauces reminded me of Thai yellow curry.  In the menu there were different dishes that were labeled Indonesian but I did not recognize them.

The atmosphere was very busy and crowded with tourists and local business people.  It was hard to carry a conversation at times as the noise level was significant.  Definitely not a romantic destination.  The tables were somewhat small so ordering more then 2 dishes would be an adventure.  Prices was reasonable for the SF downtown location and I may come back again to try some of the other dishes.
author: Harun R.

description:
Great service, awesome happy hour deals, and fun edge-of-Chinatown location! 
The best part was service- although we waited 45 min for food at the communal table due to a backup in the kitchen, our server was incredible. She checked on us multiple times to apologize for the wait, and even brought out the ahi tuna poppers on the house! After our pupu platter arrived, we were treated to a second round of our drinks due to the wait! Best service anywhere on our SF vacation.
author: Kayla R.

description:
Went here for Happy hour with my gf (keep in mind we are college students, so we have to budget)
I am a health freak so I'm picky with my food/where it comes from. 
The happy hour menu was packed with surprisingly health conscious foods! Chickpea fries! A must try! 
The tuna ahi bowls or whatever... wow! Super fresh and clean! 
It's a nice upscale place to go enjoy delicious mini meals and great drinks  I ended up spending $25 with tip... I definitely want to go back for a nice dinner
author: Kaylana B.

description:
Cute Asian fusion restaurant. Food was mostly average, but 2 standouts we ordered were:

1. Burger on corn fritters (blanking on actual name but if you eat meat this is a must order!)
2. Maui mule
author: Luna L.

description:
Absolutely LOVE this place. The food menu is spectacular, especially the happy hour (too good to be true).

The only reason I'm writing this review is to shed a little light on the dessert menu...it's always disappointing, uneventful.  After a perfect meal I would love a tasty dessert to complete my meal.  A lava cake or bread pudding...something rich  

Thank you for the delicious food!
author: Lena D.

description:
I've been here several times over the last year and it's been consistently a good experience. They nail a lot of the Asian flavors, but lack the little something to put any one dish into 5-star territory. Their corn fritter burger is probably the most distinguishable entree and it's certainly an enjoyable eat.

Service is attentive and you'll usually have someone checking in every 5 minutes. Food comes out relatively quickly and flavors rarely fluctuate. Their Happy Hour specials are awesome and definitely worth coming in for.

A lot of the patrons work nearby and it's an overall nice spot for business meals.
author: Andrew J.

description:
Coming from out of town I had the pleasure of hosting my clients here. The tables we booked were communal about 6 of us and easy for across table communication. Everything went smoothly! Great environment for a laid back celebration. I love the decor and it wasn't loud but it was still lively. 

A team member needed a gluten free menu and that was provided promptly. All the appetizers had a delicious fusion to it. I had the pork chops with kimchi. The kimchi wasn't traditional Korean but the the fusion made sense. The pork chops were perfectly cooked and not too fatty or greasy it was the perfect blend with the balsamic sauce! We stayed about 3 hours since last we were having a blast! 

Mains were about $25-35 on average. I was very pleased with the selection and service! The night was a success! Excited to be back here the next time I'm in town.
author: Rachel T.

description:
Came here for happy hour while we waited to get in to the Museum of Ice Cream. Our party of 3 adults chose the Pu Pu Platter which came with a variety of bites (ribs, corn fritters, ahi tartare, sliders, veggies, chicken satay). It normally comes with 2 of each "bite" but, since there were 3 of us, our server suggested we add an extra serving of each and it was the perfect amount of food. My favorite was the ahi tartare, but the corn fritters came at a close second. We had a child with us who loved and ate all the ribs. I didn't really care for the chicken satay; it was a little too smokey flavored for me. But everything else was delicious! The drinks were really tasty too. 

We did, however, have to wait a while for just appetizer foods, and it wasn't very busy. Not sure what happened there but the server was really nice. Just a little FYI in case you're expecting to come for a "quick bite". Other than that, great place to have happy hour! I'll be back!
author: Arielle G.

description:
We made a reservation for 8:30 PM and when we arrived, the table was just about ready for us. Unfortunately we had missed the happy hour deal, but the menu still looked good.

I had looked beforehand about things to eat here, and the sliders looked really good. I had to try those. We ordered one of the short rib sliders, the crispy spring rolls, and the Indonesian fried rice. 

The spring rolls came out first and they came with 4 pieces and a sauce. I'm not exactly sure what the sauce was, but it did have some jalapeños in it, so if you do not like jalapeños, just stay away from the sauce. I found the sauce to go really well with the spring rolls. They were crispy just like the description said. They did not disappoint. 

Next came the sliders with the taro chips. I love taro chips and they were the perfect munchies to go with the sliders. The short rib in the sliders was really soft and seemed to melt in your mouth. They only have three in the order, so if you are an even number group, just take note of that. I wish they had given an even number of sliders so my boyfriend and I could have had two each, but we still really enjoyed them. He let me have the 3rd one, bless him. 

Finally the Indonesian fried rice came out. It wasn't a huge portion, but they did give a good amount of shrimp and char siu, so that makes up for it. Some of the shrimp pieces still had some shell on it, so be careful when you eat them. I know some people say you can eat the shell, but I just personally do not like the crunchiness. The shrimp was so flavorful and just tasted exactly like the rice. You can tell they mixed it all together. It was just delicious. I would definitely recommend this dish. 

Overall, our experience was really great. Our server was really nice. However, it was a little weird that the A/C was on above me even though it was cold outside. Other than that, I could definitely see myself coming back, possibly to try the happy hour here.
author: Allyson L.

description: Late post:last week: First time here and I really enjoyed it. My date chose this place since he really liked it here and I can see why. The service was great and so was the food. We had the stir fried noodles, cod over greens and a stuff pita like bread for appetizer. Everything tasted great. I definitely want to come back for their happy hour $1 oysters and appetizers which I read was 3-6 mon-sat. Our service was really nice too.
author: Christy V.

description: Service is good but nice venues but foods is average to an Asians. Foods is very salty. Not authethic Vietnamese foods. No boxes to doggie bag. Pretty restaurant.
author: Allen L.

description: Our dishes were excellent! Chicken chowmein and beef Satay were delicious! The filet was so tender and marinated perfectly. We will be back (:
author: Erica R.

description:
Came here on a Saturday afternoon and man, this was a damn good choice.

I'm gonna start off by saying that the ONLY drawback of this place is that it is located by Union Square, so parking is gonna be a major hassle.

Food? Amazing. I tried their famous frito burger since it was my first time and it was definitely an experience, but since I know I'll be coming back again, I won't be getting it. It did get a little boring after awhile, and the corn fritos just don't hold up. The fries and patty were delightful though. A friend of mine got their shaken beef which was delicious. We got the calamari beforehand from the appetizer section and boy oh boy was it a good choice. The calamari itself was already tasty but this was the first place I've been to where they used fish sauce instead of the usual marinara sauce as a dip. 

Ambiance? Can't be beat. It looks very upscale, modern and Asian-themed (3/3 for me!). I'm sure at night it would look even nicer

Service? Hmm... They did lag a little in the beginning and take awhile for them to get our order, but after that they were quite responsive. 

I'll definitely be going here again. Whether it be for a date, brunch spot, or drinks with friends, I love this place!!
author: Matt D.

description: Needed a quick dinner but didn't want to compromise on quality. I think the dish was described as American style wagu ny steak... Definitely didn't see the marbling I would expect.  It was a little under done. The acidity in the sauce helped the dish with some brightness. Overall it was a good dinner but I didn't walk away thinking I really need to go back again.
author: William L.

description:
Weak 4... not the best Asian food I've had but decent service and tasty dishes make it worth trying at least once for a casual night in town. 

Venue / Service: came during their Happy Hour on a Saturday (3-6pm) with a friend.   We had made a reservation at 7pm but we were able to move it up to 6pm after Happy Hour ended after asking the hostess.  The waiters came frequently enough to check in and fill water glasses.  They did bring food out kinda quickly- it all came out at once and it would have been nice if it came out one at a time.  Thankfully our table was big enough to fit all the dishes.  

Food: HH bites were small and cheap but quite tasty.  Food was decent and usually on the lighter side for dinner (or maybe we coincidentally picked lighter dishes).
-- HH Oysters ($1 per oyster) - very fresh and briny, though on a smaller side (as expected from a happy hour)

-- HH Dumplings (butternut squash and red curry sauce)($1 each)- butternut squash flavor comes out very nicely and red curry sauce didn't overpower it.  Has a creamy texture in terms of mouthfeel, so definitely different from your typical Asian dumpling

-- Japanese "Bop" (crispy dashi rice, sunny side farm egg, spinach, pickles, red chili furikake, bonito flakes, umeboshi plum)($17) - interesting take on crispy rice, with the egg adding richness and the pickles add some acidity.  The rice was a bit too crispy at times, making it super hard to cut through.  

-- Prawn Salad (gulf white prawns, cucumber, asian fruits, cashews, onions, fresh chilies, thai basil, mint, cilantro, lemon oil, maldon salt)($18) - interesting, fruit forward salad.  Definitely a lot of fruit but enough shrimp to satisfy our protein craving.  Luckily it doesn't eat super sweet with the lemon, fresh herbs, cucumber and chilies.  It is a rather large portion- my friend and I had a bit of trouble sharing it just between the two of us.  

-- Wood Roasted Char Siu Black Cod (sauteed water spinach)($27) - highlight of the meal!  The char siu flavoring worked surprisingly well with the black cod- sweet but slightly tangy.  The cod was well cooked and flaky.  Also a big fan of the sauteed spinach since they were not too oily!

Dinner came out to around $30 per person excluding drinks.  Little pricey considering we only got 3 dishes to share, but the food was decent enough that I'll let it slide.  Wouldn't be my first choice in terms of where I want to go for modern Asian food, but perhaps would be my second choice.
author: Audrey H.

description:
I've been here several times now and each time have found it to be solid. One of my colleagues has labeled E&O as her favorite restaurant in SF, and while it doesn't rank as high as all that for me, it's a good place for a tapas-style meal. I've had many of the non-seafood items on the menu, with highlights below:

-Wood-Roasted Edamame Beans: I mean, yes, it's edamame...maybe it's the Maldon salt on them, but they're really good.
-Lamb Naan: The.Bomb. The lamb is marinated well, tender and juicy, and balances well with the naan. Frankly, I was surprised that somewhere as overtly fusiony as E&O did this well, but I ordered a few of these and ate them all myself!
-Beef Short Rib Sliders: These are OK but not mind-blowing and I think the particular pickled veggies they use totally overpower the dish. It's like, "Oh, here's some pickled radish and...is that...essence of beef?"
-Chicken Lettuce Cups: My favorite thing on the menu. Okhthanksbye.
-Crispy Chicken Spring Rolls: I like that these are actually heavy on the veggies. Really nice and light every time. 

I've found the service here to be super hit or miss. The last two times, flagging someone down required a bit of work, although the staff were pretty friendly when you could find time. Note that it can get pretty loud in here, especially on weekday nights, but that's sort of par for the course for a restaurant like this one.
author: Willie R.

description: E&O has a great happy hour. The food is yummy.  I loved my potstickers The ambiance is relaxing! You should definitely check it out - they even have happy hour on Saturdays. M - Sat
author: Danielle S.

description:
I originally wanted to try their happy hour but my boyfriend & I decided to sit in their dining room area for dinner. I love the décor. Upscale Asian themed. Our server was great as well. As soon as we cleared a plate, it was picked up within 5 minutes by the busser & our server was always filling our water glasses. 

We decided to share a couple things.
Lamb Naan - Really good! 
Chicken Crispy Rolls - Pretty bland & basic. Wouldn't order again
Duck Buns - Good as well
Corn Fritter Burger - The corn (bun) didn't hold up but all of the flavors worked really well together. Very filling!

Next time I do want to try their happy hour since they do have a couple different things on that menu.
author: Nari M.

description:
Came out for a last minute Happy Hour. 

I like the Happy Hour menu and the drinks as well.

Food
Oysters - For a dollar a piece, its solid. Comes with a Kimchi sauce... but taste like ketchup
Buttersquash Dumpling - $1 as well, nothing special. All I taste is the red curry sauce. and its also only ONE piece 
Pu Pu Platter - $24 and feeds too, sample platter.
(Sliders - basically taste like pulled pork)
(Ahi Tuna -  would say this is the best on the platter but literally one bite)
(Chicken Satay - Meh, its okay, peanut sauce is a plus)
(Spare Ribs -Good flavor, 2nd favorite)
(Corn Fritter - Love this, texture and flavor is perfect)
(Taro Chips)
* Additional $14 for an extra person on the platter? Thats a little high

As far as Asian fusion goes... I don't know man, I wouldn't exactly call it that. The happy hour menu is cheap yes, but you're paying per bite basically. And I would not recommend eating here for dinner at all. The happy hour is a hit and miss, don't think thats something you want to chance for the prices they charge for dinner. 

The service was disappointing. It wasn't busy at all, and still had to ask for things, like sauces, napkins... ask again and then still not accommodated. So while the food was a hit and miss, along with the service, I don't think I would come back.
author: Arron E.

description:
It has been a good 2yrs ago since I last came here, and I simply forgot what this place was called back then to be able to Yelp it. Fast forward to today, the manager took us out for a work lunch and a decision was made by the group to come here.  This place is pretty busy, but thankfully we were able to snag a table for 6 and be seated right away without a wait. We ordered a few appetizers before our meal including:

-INDONESIAN CORN FRITTERS 
-CHICKPEA FRIES 
-LAMB NAAN
-AHI TUNA TARTARE
-LAPSANG SOUCHONG TEA DEVILED EGGS

While each of these dishes were delicious, the Indonesian Corn Fritters really stole the spotlight. Truly had the meal simply ended there, I would have left happy. But then...the main entrée came out. While a variety of dishes were ordered throughout the table, I took the advice of one of my colleagues and ordered the fritter burger. Don't let the steep price ($20) dissuade you, this burger was worth every penny (even though technically I wasn't footing this bill). First, this massive burger is sandwiched with two corn fritters as buns. And if that wasn't delicious enough, it comes with a healthy amount of pickles, bacon, kimchi, and sirracha all topped on a perfectly cooked, thick, medium rare (because let's face it, that's the only acceptable way to eat beef) patty. Oh and of course a bunch of fries which I honestly completely ignored in favor of the real prize. 

Ambience is nice, in a business casual sort of way. And service was very friendly and attentive. If you're looking for a nice sit-down restaurant in the Union Square area for lunch (or dinner!), I would highly recommend giving E&O a try!
author: Alex C.

description: It's been years since I've been here but the corn fritters were the same hot, fresh corn, popping, crunchy yumminess...definitely did not disappoint. After a long day in The City, we were staying in Union Sq. So a late night walk to E & O was easy. So glad we did!! Quiet on a Wednesday but the food was amazing. Lamb naan with the best cucumber mint yogurt sauce.  Grilled baby artichokes are amazingly bright and delicious with the seaweed that reminded me of collard greens. The chicken satay was juicy, hot and favored with the perfect rub. Pickled veggies on the side were legit. Service was great as the kitchen closed, a quick last call but we were happy with our choices. Asian fusion at its best. Cute bar, nice options and the food was fantastic.
author: Betty L.

description:
Their happy hour platter is a bummer!!! It was so filling for 2 people that we only ordered alcohol after that!

Must try!
author: Deebs M.

description:
When an acquaintance from my past agreed to make plans for a 3-person get together in San Francisco I resisted the urge to micro-manage.  I let her choose and when she chose E&O my unspoken reaction was "who still goes to E&O?", a place I've heard little of since  the 1990's.  

Surprisingly, E&O turned out to be a stellar choice, proving that I was wise to keep both an open mind and my thoughts to myself.  

The surprises happened from the moment we entered.  E&O is low lit and, on a Thursday evening, appeared mostly full.  Catching up with old friends demanded a drawn out ordering process as we were so unfocused on the menu.  We finally got around to ordering a bottle of wine, with an excellent and reasonable recommendation from our waiter, and eventually to our shared food.  Our waiter was patient, never hurrying us, helpful, and unobtrusive.  I couldn't have asked for better service.

The menu is extensive, varied, and interesting, things I could also say about the food we ordered (Indonesian Fried Rice, Chicken Satay, an excellent salad, Corn Fritters, and Roast Cauliflower).  It'd be fair to say that E&O is breaking no new ground but they are, in fact, covering old territory with great success.  

Everybody is always searching for the shiniest new thing but I have to admit that E&O, in sticking with the tried and true, is working quite well; don't fix what ain't broke.  I left here quite overjoyed that I'd returned to E&O and certain that the next time someone is looking for a well-priced place downtown, I might actually recommend E&O myself, especially for their Monday thru Saturday (3 - 6 pm) happy hour.

Well done, E&O.
author: Tracey A.

description:
The drinks and service is awesome! The food is delicious and the ambiance is lovely! I had corn fritters which were absolutely amazing.  The small plates have very nice portions. It a definite must go to in San Fran. 

This is an update. I recently returned to E&O for happy hour and had an amazing experience! The food was delicious and they consistently serve good food with a smile.
author: T L.

description:
We ate at E&O kitchen last night to celebrate our anniversary out in the city... dinner and show. Unfortunately, the dinner portion of our evening was disappointing. 
 We arrived on time for our dinner reservations and were quickly whisked to the back of the restaurant. The decor of the restaurant is lovely, clean, and spacious. Once we reached our small table, I realized we were in a separate part of the restaurant. In the back, in front of the cooks. It's an odd space, you definitely feel separated from everyone else. Especially if you're the only two sitting there.
 Since it was a special night for us, I was hoping to sit in the livelier part of the restaurant. It was a Saturday night, our anniversary, and just wanted to be around other patrons enjoying their evening. We asked our server if we could be moved to another table closer to the front. This is where our night began to take a negative turn. She looked at me and said I have no idea what's going on in the front of the restaurant or with the hostess. To be quite honest I was surprised by her answer and her unhelpful manner. I answered, well I don't either do you think you can ask someone? She left and came back with a gentleman who explained that they needed the other tables for larger parties. Ok, I got it.
 She perhaps was having an off day, and I understand that that can happen... my husband asked about the wagyu steak and how many ounces it was. She didn't know and had to ask about details about the wagyu, and then realized that she forgot to ask about how many ounces it was. So she had to go back and ask again. I ordered the steak satay ( which were grisly and hard) very disappointing. The fried rice we ordered was ok, a bit bland. 
 All in all usually if you have service that falls short, you hope the food will be better. It wasn't. I will say whomever answered our call and took our reservations was very helpful and friendly, we were so very excited to try E&O. Unfortunately, this will be our first and last trip here.
author: Janine C.

description:
I see why many people really like this place. The servers are very personal to their regulars and they offer a generous HH menu. My bf and I were spending the day in SF and wanted to find $1 oysters that were offered before 4PM. This place was the closest so we had went. Assuming because of the time, it wasn't too crowded and we were able to get seated right away. 

Other than the oyster we tried the dumplings and the beef short rib slider. I say you can past on both. The dumplings were so small for $1 and the sliders were pretty dry. Can't complain about $1 oysters; well because, they are $1 oysters. We had ordered 18 to split between the two and both were filling. In terms of drinks, I had tried their special during that time which was the green tea vodka. Surprisingly, very tasty. I would get it again.

The other issue was the service. For the place being so vacant when we were, the service was unbelievably slow. However, when it came to the regulars, they were served/catered to almost immediately. That didn't sit well with me especially when it took forever just to get some damn Tabasco and the bill. 

Good place to go to if you're looking for an early HH spot offering $1 oysters before 4PM. Otherwise, there may be other places of better service and better quality appetizers.
author: Rio O.

description:
One of the best oyster happy hours in SF! $1 oysters and they are delicioussssss. Briney, really  fresh, and full of flavor. Got a dozen and they were displayed on a small sheet pan with lemons and a cocktail sauce. 

Drinks are $6 and we got the moscow mule, Sauvignon blanc, and the vodka green tea. Everything except for the green tea was pretty basic. Green tea vodka was good but not strong.

The pupu plate at $24 is a great deal!!! The perfect amount of food for 2 people. Everything on it tastes pretty good. Only critique would be that I wish the sauce for the corn fritters weren't so salty and that the sliders had an aioli on them as they were very dry. 

The service is great and the ambiance of this place is amazing. A really fun place to hang out with friends. It a bit nicer but you still feel laid back. Reservations were easy to get the night before. I'll definitely be coming back here!!!
author: Courtney N.

description: This was an amazing place with a variety of options. Great service and great ambiance and right next to union square! We had a birthday dinner party so had a private room in the back! Loved it! I got the Japanese Bop dish and it was so good. Here is a picture of it!
author: Sophia K.

description:
I have been to E&O twice now, once for dinner and once for lunch and I have to say that the quality of the food and service is great at either time. When you go in for dinner, make sure to make a reservation because there is usually a wait. When we went in for lunch, there were quite a few people there but we were sat right when we walked in.

The hosts and servers were very welcoming and warm. They were able to give us their opinion and preferences on the food and drinks available. The setting and atmosphere was nice and decorated just enough.

For lunch we ordered the three course meal and shared it. We added on the corn fritters as an app and it was as good as it was the first time.

Corn Fritters - They were nice and hot right out of the fryer. They were very crispy and had a nice texture to them. The sauce that accompanied it was right.

Butternut Squash Dumplings - The dumplings were cooked well and had a little chew and bit to them. The filling was a great mixture of sweet and salty. The curry based sauce was a great addition to the dish.

Pork Ribs - The pork ribs went nicely with the coleslaw. They were tender but not overcooked. Not quite fall off the bone, which was great because it gave it a nice texture.

Definitely a fan of E&O and will be back for lunch or dinner anytime I'm in The City.
author: Camera P.

description: Love the Indonesian fried rice and the staff are very nice. Solid drinks. The Brussels sprouts side is very good too. Great spot for asian fusion food and they have a nice bar to sit at for drinks
author: Weich Y.

description: Is for Americans who want fusion. Good environment for group meal, but the food is really not great. Corner seat smells. Is a fun place for group who like fusion food.
author: Anya C.

description:
Went here for dinner with my friend and boyfriend.

We ordered the string beans, fried rice, steak, and prawns.  The portions were smaller and didn't really quite satisfy the tummy.

The food came out quickly, but it wasn't very tasty.  Some dishes were either bland or too salty.

I would only come back if my friends invited me.
author: Kimberly D.

description: Booming business Asian Fusion with a plethora of just right options, in Union Square San Francisco. The menu is always going to change and rotate season to season, but one unceasing appetizer item is the INDONESIAN CORN FRITTERS, which once dipped in sauce, is a crunchy yet gooey delight. Great cuts of filet fish, a classy beer menu, service that mostly makes sense (arghhh, they took my beer glass and I wasn't finished -- okay, they brought me a new one). Many positives. But did they have to be so stingy on the Chow Mein dish? Not only is it hard splitting it, the fact is it's hardly enough for one hungry tummy. "E&O" has dazzle with oodles of style, but they need a little bit more sense. #sincerity
author: Sean C.

description: A cute place for gatherings. The small dishes were quite filling when you try a few different dishes. I like the smaller portions. We had a bit of everything and I have to say I didn't have a dish I didn't like. I would come back and recommend this place. I enjoyed the ambience a lot. Our waitress was accommodating and nice.
author: Daniela B.

description: Great experience at E&O. I made a reservation a few days in advance due to other yelp reviews indicating a reservation is needed due to long wait times. Unfortunately, we needed to add an addition person to our reservatio and they could not accomadate us at original time but they were able to accomadate us an hour early. Upon arrival we were seated immediately and our server addressed us as soon as we sat at our table. The food was served quickly after ordering, but because it's mainly small plate style servings our table filled up pretty quickly with food and they had to slow down the arrival of the food. While the service was great the food was good and at a great price. Overall it was enjoyable experience, not a stand out experience but still a nice place to go if you want to enjoy multiple plates of food at reasonable prices.
author: Nakia W.

description:
I made a reservation for a party of 24 people. The servers were super patient in dealing with our large group. Everyone was served quickly. The place was very dimly lit and has a nice, romantic ambiance to it. Perfect for a date night! 

[Indonesian Fried Rice] To my surprise, this dish was slightly spicy. There was a good variety of meat (shrimp, pork) and veggies in the dish.
author: Annie Z.

description:
When asian fusion tastes funky it tastes really funky.

Super dry Nan bread starter. Worse than from the microwave.

The E and O burger that I had was undercooked and raw not once but two times so I sent it back. The weird part is they still couldn't get it right and the waiter apologized but I still got another raw burger in the end.

The ahi tuna tartar was one of the worst I've ever had. Bland and it didn't taste fresh. Like it was sitting on the counter at luke warm room temperature.

The ginger cookie dessert tasted like it was from the $1 store and the line in coconut Panna Cotta was bitter and didn't even taste like coconut.

And $9 for dry cold green beans was also a no go.....

This was a total waste of money.
author: Jack R.

description: Best pork chop! Cooked perfectly. Dumplings and mud pie dessert were amazing.  The table next to us arrived after we did and they ordered the same after seeing how good it looked and hearing how delish everything was.
author: B K.

description:
E&O normally doesn't pop up on my radar.  My first visit was many moons ago when they had communal tables upstairs for dinner; my memory was that the cuisine leaned towards Indian and Southeast Asian cuisine.  Then, I was fortunate in being invited to a YEE here a few years back.  In organizing a business lunch where one attendee was on Maiden Lane, I thought about this place and promptly made a reservation for a Monday business lunch.

The first thing I noticed were the gaudy yet interesting decorations in and around the ground floor dining room. A few years ago, I read that the company hired Arnold Wong (renown for his Eos and Bacar... boy, I miss Bacar) as the corporate chef de cuisine.  Knowing his style,  I looked forward to trying E&O's revamped menu. 

Arriving early, one guest and I ordered beverages as we waited for our fellow diners.  After studying the menu, when said guests arrived, I ordered a shared dish of mushroom dumplings (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=vrOepTGwg0Ek4NeKi2seTQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q).  I believe there were five to an order so we each got to try one with a bonus one. 

While discussing the menu, , we agreed the two courses for $23.95 option was the best choice.  With three choices per course,  my selection was the  green papaya salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=X9xStogBS00negYbQTAu9g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) to start; I was surprised by the portion as it was a heaping plate and, if they added a protein, this would be an meal in itself.  For my second course, I chose their pad thai (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=hgkb8kGwvoevWudjdEZvow&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q); also a generous portion and nicely seasoned, not overly so like many places.  My friend offered a small chunk of his ribs which were tasty and tender.  Ginger cookies were offered for $5.00 more but we passed on that.

I enjoyed my meal and the location is convenient for those who work or happen to be in the Union Square area.  I would come back and try other things on the menu.  Just wish I'd see that pork chop that I remember and crave from Bacar...
author: Mike C.

description:
Good happy hour prices from Mon-Sat 3-6pm.

Cocktails were $6 - my friends got the prickly tequila and the rum vanilla, while I got the vodka green tea.  They both said that the vodka green tea was the strongest, but it was honestly the better of the three.  The vodka green tea was very smooth.  The prickly tequila was good.  The rum vanilla tasted like a soap or carbonated drink.  Drinks weren't too bad though.

We ordered oysters, which were $1 each and came with a kim chee cocktail sauce.  We all agreed that the oysters tasted fresh and good.  The kim chee sauce complimented them well.

I also ordered one ahi tuna tartare (popper) $3 and one dumpling $1 just to try it out.  The ahi tuna tartare was good and the shell it came in gave it a nice crunch.  It was a nice amount of tuna.  The butternut squash dumpling was nothing special and wasn't that satisfying.  It was also super tiny!  The red curry sauce probably saved it a little.
My friend also ordered the Indonesian corn fritter bites $3.50 and she enjoyed them and got full after eating them.  They give you 3 per order.

Service was okay.  The waiter was friendly, but I had to repeat myself multiple times and he almost missed some items.  It was nice that he allowed us to split the check by our items though.

Overall, this is a good place to come by for happy hour.  I'd come for some drinks and a couple of HH appetizers.  Not really sure I would come for a dinner.  More of a 3.5 stars, but the $1 oysters + the sauce it comes with and the $6 cocktails round it up.
author: Stephanie Z.

description:
We were drawn in by their Happy Hour menu while waiting for the Chinese New Year Parade to start. There wasn't space in the bar area, so we sat with three other parties in the front lounge area. I remember they had decent happy hour cocktail prices. 

I liked the idea of the Char Siu Black Cod $27 I ordered. It had a nice sear on it and the the texture of the fish was excellent. Sadly the fish was too salty. When I tried to eat the side of greens to help, but the greens were even saltier. 

The Fritter Burger $18 was a cute but became a huge mess when the corn fritter "buns" fell apart. You gotta eat it with a knife and fork. 

The Happy Hour $1 butternut squash dumplings were okay. 

We were mostly ignored and had to ask for utensils after some of the food was brought out. We had to request refills on drinks also.
author: Thien H.

description:
4.5 this time. Service always excellent, comfortable chairs. Tried some new dishes. Previous dishes we liked, varied this time.

Ahi tartare: Outstanding. Well-flavored with sesame oil and the crisps are wonderful.

Minced chicken lettuce cups. Actually romaine spears, tasty chicken filling with very little filler. Second best behind ahi tartare.

Eggplant & Tofu: tasty, but very intense sauce. Needs rice, so excellent for table to share.

Steamed pork buns spicy kimchi. Fail: bao too big and thick, much too bready. Char siu sweet but good quality. But kim chi was arranged around the outside of pork filling, so folded over, the two fillings stayed separate, never mingling flavors. This dish needs reworking.

Tea smoked deviled eggs still 5-star. Down 1/2 level this time:
- Lamb naan. bread didn't seem quite as good this time.
- Corn fritters. Still good, though; much better than Soi4/Oakland.
- Spare ribs. Seemed a little too sweet this time but still good. The slaw with it remains sensational; light and refreshing.

Black cod with broccoli. Generous serving, but fish wasn't as fresh as before. Chinese broccoli was prepared on-point and excellent.

Overall, not quite the heights of our 2016 visit, but still very good. We feel E&O is one of the more underrated restaurants in SF.
author: Jean K.

description:
I was looking for a Saturday happy hour spot, with food and drinks, and came across E&O. Their happy hour is Mondy-Saturday from 3-6pm. 

They have some pretty nice options, both for drinks and food. For the drinks, they have nice mixed drink options (bourbon maple, prickly tequila, vodka ginger, etc.), wine and some beers. The prices range from $4 for beer, $6 for wine and mixed drinks. For food, they have a bunch of small bites, including dumplings, oysters, ahi tuna, sliders and more. The prices for the food range from $1-4 or $24 for the pu pu platter, which includes an assortment. My favorite from the platter was the taro chips and the chicken satay. 

If you want more bang for your buck, skip the sparkling wine, it's served in a flute, so you're getting a smaller quantity. Opt for the cocktails! The oysters are worth it, at a dollar a pop, they weren't too small and there was no sand. Also, the sauce pairing is a kimchee cocktail sauce and it wasn't too spicy. 

The spot is quite spacious, but during happy hour they were only seating people at the bar, small tables near the bar and the small lounge area. You may need reservations to sit at the larger tables, which appear to accommodate a large crowd.
author: Ashley G.

description:
Had a lovely, low-key dinner here the other night. I had been to the E&O in San Jose, like, 10 years ago, and didn't remember the food, vibe, etc., but this was great. We tried a bunch of dishes--the satay platter, the cauliflower, the green papaya salad, the fries, the chicken spring rolls, and the tuna tartare. All were beautifully plated and very tasty. I especially enjoyed the tuna--just the right amount of seasoning. The kids loved the satay platter (except the roasted mushrooms, which were very smoky).

As for service, two thumbs up! The server was completely on top of things and very prompt with extra requests. There was an additional server clearing plates, getting water/drinks/etc. - well done!

I also thought the location was quite convenient. Union Square is kind of a drag and overrun with tourists. Since this was just north of Union Square, we had less trouble getting in/out. Also, we parked at Sutter-Stockton and had no problems (the restaurant is right next door).
author: Lis B.

description:
Pad thai was filling but mediocre.
Too much salt on Edamame.
Pea dumplings (4) were the best thing on the menu.
Must give it a 7.8/10 for ambiance.
Older crowd.
author: Nabiha J.

description:
A group of 9 of us had dinner here recently. 
Overall it was an excellent meal with outstanding service and nice pacing. Everyone enjoyed the dinner and all the dishes were very tasty. Here is a recap, sorta ranked in order of how much people liked them:
Chow mein (both regular and vegetarian) was perfect
Shaking beef - very nice
Corn fritters - a "must have"
Black Cod w char siu and greens - yum
Dry fried green beans - another must have
Short rib sliders - surprisingly popular
Ahi tartare - awesome, but not everyone eats raw tuna
Fried rice  - delicious. Can't stop eating this
Brussels sprouts - awesome, but some people just dislike sprouts 
Spare ribs 
Chicken spring rolls
Kennebec fries

We had so much food, the last three items ranked at the bottom of the list only because we were on overkill. They were still tasty.
author: Lewis C.

description: My friends and I agree in that this place was mediocre. We came on a Saturday night and had reservations, not like we needed them since they had more than enough open tables. I'm not really sure that I understand the concept of this restaurant. It's a very interesting place that had Asian fusions and had all kinds of different foods from all Asian cultures. Service was really great and attentive but I thought the food was okay for what I was paying for.
author: Monissa W.

description: What a fantastic place! A friend treated me here  for my birthday (chose it based off yelp reviews) and it was definitely a hit. Everything from service to atmosphere to the food was all superb; our server Miguel made sure of it. For drinks we had the Silk Scorpion and Korokata Punch. We started off with Edamame which is a must try, it was charred on open flame  not something typical for edamame. We also had chicken satay, ahi tuna tartare, and Japanese "Bop". All the flavors in each dish went really well together. Definitely will come back to this place. Spectacular.
author: Alexander H.

description:
Made a reservation for 5:45pm just in time for the Happy Hour menu. We got here a few mins early, but they still happily seated us.

PARKING + AMBIENCE
It's SF, so unless you want to pay an abysmal amount of $$ for parking garages, public transportation is an efficient option. The restaurant is a short walk from the Powell St. BART station. The restaurant's ambience is perfect. The dim lighting and stylish dining decor greet patrons with a truly enjoyable dining experience. The noise level is loud, with everyone chatting away, but not too loud that it overpowers any conversations to be heard at your table.

FOOD
E&O's Happy Hour is 3-6pm (Mon-Sat) and it was a great value! Cheap prices and good portions, you could have a whole meal just off the happy hour menu. 

Butternut Squash Dumplings ($1): the texture of the dough was notable, but the sauce was savory and flavorful. 4/5 

Oysters ($1): They were okay. Not the best, but it's $1. 3/5

Indonesian Corn Fritter Bites ($3.5): I didn't like these, flavor was dull and bland. Maybe I just don't like corn fritters. 1/5

Ahi Tuna Tartare ($3): Delicious! They gave a portionable amount of ahi tuna, we ordered them twice. 5/5

Beef Short Rib Slider ($4): Came with taro chips. The meat tasted like stew beef, the sliders are filling. 4/5

As for their main menu, we weren't impressed. Food was just average and not worth the price. Portions are large, but the food quality was missing something. 

Indonesian Fried Rice ($17): Flavors were okay, but it tasted just like average fried rice, nothing outstanding. 3.5/5

Pad Thai ($18): Not your typical authentic pad thai, and that's not a positive attribute. The flavors of the dish were meh. 2/5

SERVICE
Friendly customer service right from the beginning. We were seated immediately since I made a reservation in advance. Our waiter was delightful and attentive, he asked us for any last calls from the happy hour menu, which was a nice gesture. Great hospitality!

CONCLUSION
If you decide to come here, make sure to take advantage of the happy hour menu, it's a great value. The main menu dishes were not worth the price, too expensive for mediocrity. I would only come during happy hour.
author: Vincent P.

description: I loved this place! The prawn chilli was bomb -- one of my favorite places in Sf! It's a great place to for the weekend as well as dinner with friends!
author: Safia K.

description:
We needed to arrange a nearly-last-minute reception venue change for after our small SF City Hall wedding; E&O came to the rescue! 

In fact, we ended up incredibly more impressed with our interactions and experience with E&O than the original, more well-known Asian-fusion restaurant we were supposed to have our event at. We had never eaten at E&O, but we trusted the reviews and had seen the space once before.

Not only did we have quick responses from the event staff, they gave us more detail about options and spaces than we received from any of the restaurants we contacted. They also provided a deep, much appreciated discount for our party. And the food... oh my gawww it was amazing! I will try to come back to this review soon and describe more in detail of what we ordered, but to summarize: it was excellent. They had plentiful vegetarian, vegan, gluten-free and nut-free options. Everything was just sensational.

E&O is going to be one of our regular spots for nice dining when we're visiting San Francisco now. One of our guests says he is going to see if he can have an event he is planning for next year with them. I highly recommend contacting the event staff if you're looking for a great Asian-fusion spot for a large party/event. 

This really made our wedding so special. I'm so happy I put my trust in E&O.
author: Melanie P.

description: Really interesting and unique Asian fusion restaurant. Everything we ordered was delicious. It's located right downtown, and the service was prompt. Would eat here again.
author: Laura R.

description:
TLDR - My favorite sit down experience in the union square area!

Well shoot - I have to say this place is next level. I have no idea why my sister rated it 3 stars but she is a dummy!

The sliders, burger, and the satay are next level bomb! Sliders are amongst some of the best i've ever had. They're succulent and a dope treat.

Naan for the appetizer is legit. Lychee martini is great.com as well!
author: Samraaj B.

description:
We got the corn fritters (great), mushroom dumplings (best), crab rangoon (like, great idea using ONLY crab on the filling to make it worth $15 but tbh just use half crab and half cream cheese and price it less and it would be a lot better, nobody at our table really liked these), indonesian fried rice (good, not special), shaking beef (pretty good, nice quality meat), and special upside down cake (everything but the cake was great. Cake itself was too sweet and too dry).

If someone asked me if they should go there I'd say sure but I won't go out of my way to recommend. It's solid, but not special.
author: Colleen R.

description:
Although I didn't make it in time for HH this is a solid place to grab Asian food w/ a twist. I enjoyed the ambiance of this place. It's basically 3 floors but the top/bottom are mainly for events while the entrance floor is for dining. It does get pretty packed even outside HH times so I recommend reserving a table beforehand. 

WHAT WE GOT: 

- Squash dumplings- One of my favorites of all the dishes in addition to the ceviche. They let you order in a serving of 5 or 6. The dumplings were filled with a load of squash and the wrapping tasted fresh. The sauce was very flavorful and went well with the dense dumplings. GET THIS! 

- Ceviche - My second favorite dish. Unlike normal ceviche this one has a coconut kick which is a. Ice twist. Also A-1 presentation on being served in a half coconut shell as well! On the sides they also lay out thin taro chips that paired great with the ceviche. 

- Drunken Noodle- The noodles had a great texture but I think it was hard to eat for me because of how salty it was.

- Roasted Eggplant - can't go wrong with eggplant. Great flavor and roasted well. Nothing too spectacular about this one though. 

- Corn Fritters - it seems like this was something everyone tries so we ended up getting them too. They give you 2 per order. The fritters are HUGE and composed of tons of sweet corn. I enjoyed eating them since they added a nice mix in texture with all of the softer dishes we got. The sauce they pair it with is tasty as well. 

I docked a star because service was meh. We felt rushed to order/eat and also a little pressured to buy drinks. When we didn't we were overlooked - con of looking young I guess? 

For all the above we paid around $85 for 2 people outside HH. A little on the pricier end but I'll be sure to make it before 6PM next time.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Perfect option for a nice restaurant that takes reservations and has portions big enough for sharing or eating by yourself.  The staff is friendly and accommodating.  The only reason for the average review: prices are on the high side and the food took a little while to get, especially for a lunch when speed is key.
author: Carlo A.

description:
This review is for the restaurant's Happy Hour. I've been here 3x now for happy hour and have always left happy and full. Their HH starts at 3pm (including weekends)! My favorite things to order from their HH menu are their $1 oysters and $1 butternut squash dumplings, and corn fritters. If I'm feeling extra adventurous (and hungry) I go for their pu pu platter.

Also, a little birdie told me that this restaurant is great at accommodating tables for large group dinners!
author: Diana Y.

description: Food isn't bad. We really liked the atmosphere. One thing we didn't like is we came abt 3.30pm and waitress didn't come long time we called so many times and they came. So food comes abt 4.30-4.40 we having a meal and wanted to hangout with my friend and her son.  they said this table reserved abt 6pm and basically saying leave. We were dissapointed. Service is slow and took so much time and just finishing food and wanted to talk with my friend they just saying basically leave it's so rude.Waitress isn't looks really nice never smiles.
author: Melody A.

description:
TLDR - Solid Asian fusion, nothing amazing but they have a great HH for food

Came back here for happy hour and thought it was one of the best HH deals for food I've had in SF. They have $1 oysters and dumplings and other bar bites for $2-4, or you can order a whole platter sampling most of the bar bites for $24. My friend and I got the Pu Pu Platter, 2 oysters and 2 dumplings, which was plenty for a meal and only $28 before tax/tip!

Food wasn't necessarily amazing, but I'd definitely recommend if you're looking for a more affordable HH. They have drinks for $6 too.

* PU PU PLATTER ($24) - 4/5
[fritter bites, 2 sliders, 2 ribs, 2 chicken satay, 2 ahi tartare, taro chips & pickled veggies]
Good value and good if you're like me and enjoy sampling a little of everything.

- INDONESIAN CORN FRITTER BITES - Fried and greasy but not bad
- BEEF SHORT RIB SLIDERS - Pretty meaty but a tad dry and lacking a little in flavor
- TAMARIND & HOISIN PORK SPARE RIBS - 1 was tender, 1 was a little chewy. Flavor was sweet and tangy/citrusy
- CHICKEN SATAY - Pretty tender chicken. Plain on its own but there's a peanut dipping sauce to go with it. Or pair it with the red curry sauce from the dumplings if you're getting those.
- AHI TUNA TARTARE - Basically your classic tuna poke.

* DUMPLINGS ($1) - 3.5/5
[butternut squash, red curry sauce]
Meh, the overall texture of the dumpling was too mushy and doughy. I did like the red curry sauce though, which I'd recommend saving to dip your taro chips or chicken satay in.

* OYSTERS ($1) - 4.5/5
[local variety, kim chee cocktail sauce]
Fresh! Loved the unique cocktail sauce. The kimchee gave it a little kick.

--------

From a previous lunch visit:

* PRAWN SALAD ($16) - 3.5/5
[gulf white prawns, cucumber, asian fruit, cashews, onions, fresh chilies, thai basil, mint, cilantro, lemon oil, maldon salt]
Crisp and fresh ingredients, but a little disappointing in flavor. I was expecting sweet and spicy from the fruit and chilies, but the chilies didn't have any punch to them. The prawns were big and well cooked but few in quantity.

* INDONESIAN FRIED RICE ($17) - 3.5/5
[gulf white prawns, char siu pork, vegetables, egg, chilies]
