We got the fried rice without the chilies and it honestly tasted like any other fried rice, just greasier and saltier. Maybe it would've been more interesting with the chilies.

* DRUNKEN NOODLES / PAD KEE MAO ($16) - 3.5/5
[broad rice noodles, ground pork, chinese broccoli, chilies, basil]
Not bad, but again not very memorable. The noodles and pork were cooked nicely, but the dish was definitely on the greasy side.
author: Jessie L.

description:
This is like a global-fusion with dishes from all over the world. Day or night, this place is full of energy and laughter and puts a smile on your face.

Very modern upscale interiors with booths n high chairs, with matching interior brightness to outside light that keeps the atmosphere relaxed and natural.

Service is ok. Staff is very polite and accommodating but not that attentive. Gotta earn their attention to even get a glass of water.

I have mixed feelings about their food. I really liked the presentation of their ceviche. It was served on a cracked half of coconut on a bed of yuca fries. The sweetness of the yuca chips balanced (or tried to) the tanginess of the ceviche. It was a creative idea, but failed in execution. Ceviche was a lil too tangy and i wonder what they do with all those coconuts? 

Pad Thai tasted funny but their fried rice was really good. So, in my opinion instead of putting too many items on the menu from all over the world not getting them right, they could just focus just Asian food and get it right.

I will go there again because its a fun atmosphere and food isn't that bad.
author: Sujeesha V.

description: One of my go to bars in Downtown SF. Very chill environment. I go during happy hour after my morning shift to unwind and relax. Sergio always takes really good care of me and my friends. The drinks are excellent and the food is very good. One of my favorites is the squash dumpling. I also like their Indonesian Fried Rice, a kick of spice but not overwhelming. Highly recommend this place. I bring friends and colleagues every now and then. And all the time they say, "how come I didn't know about this place before?"
author: Alex G.

description: I first came here after seeing them on a food network episode of the best thing I ever ate. One of the chefs said the corn fritters were heavenly. And they were right! I have been back several times since then and always get their corn fritters. I love their happy hour, who can go wrong with $1 dumplings!
author: Anna-Lisa D.

description: Love the tartare! Had the noodles and spring rolls and fried rice!! Looking forward to the happy hour oysters $1 from 3-5!! Yum'!! Love their fresh fruit drinks!' Yes they use freshly squeezed EVERYTHING !'!!! The bartenders are super cool and the crowd is professional young !
author: Apple O.

description:
My girlfriend took me here on her lunch break. I had a wonderful time! The restaurant had the perfect ambiance as far as lighting and seating goes, and it definitely had that modern upscale touch. Service speed was moderate at peak SF lunch hours. I had the fried rice which had to be the best I've ever had. No disrespect to my mom, but this killed all the fried rices that I've had in many moons. I was so impressed with the amount of shrimp that was in my bowl too. Don't sleep on the lettuce wraps either! Those are my girlfriends favorite! Have them as an appetizer or you can even make that your entree and it will be more than enough. This place is great.

Warning: I felt rather underdressed wearing just a T-shirt. Make sure to come with at least a button up :)
author: Michael C.

description:
Came here with a group of friends the other night and got the Indonesian Fried Rice. The fried rice was decent, but definitely overpriced. I would recommend coming back for Happy Hour as I've heard those prices are better. 

The restaurant itself has a really nice and modern ambiance and is a cool place to bring a group of folks.
author: Sharan B.

description:
Great happy hour menu. They have six dollar drinks and wine. Also very cheap finger food. 

Ordered a dozen oysters (much regret) and two ahi tuna tartes. They were probably the worst oysters I've ever had. The oysters had either broken shell or sand in every single oyster I ate! It was so gross and really annoying to eat.

Despite the bad oysters, the bartender was kind and helpful in selecting drinks. I also tried the prickly tequila, which consisted of prickly pear, tequila, and lime. Very interesting drink! I really liked the prickly pear, considering I have never seen any other bar offer this before. 

Really nice place to go for happy hour, despite the horrible experience I had with the oysters.
author: Annie H.

description: This was an amazing restaurant.  Beautiful inside. Food was out of this world, drink were fabulous. And the staff was so friendly. Especially our waiter Miguel. He was so friendly and smiling. He took great care of us and gave us great suggestions when we had questions. I would definitely recommend this restaurant when visiting San Francisco.
author: Lori H.

description: I was visiting sf and my friend and I saw this on yelp so we decided to give it a try. We got there around 6:30pm on a sat and they said there were no tables available besides chefs table or bar. We ended up at the chefs seat which was basically a bar area in front of the kitchen. The head-chef offered us recommendations and even gave us two free dishes, the squash dumplings and the corn fritters!! Both were amazing btw!! We also ordered the lamb naan, satay platter, deviled eggs, and Indonesian fried rice. Everything was so tasty!! But the squash dumplings and satay platter is a must !
author: Patricia T.

description:
This review is only for their happy hour menu. 

Coworkers and I came here on a Friday around 5:30pm with no reservations. Bad move on our part. However, we decided to stay in the back table even though we weren't going to get those dollar oysters. Right when we were about to go to our table, another hostess was very nice enough to get us seated for happy hour! It was super nice of them to accommodate to our party and make sure we got our happy hour orders on time because we literally had only 5 minutes before it was over. 

Recommendations:
- Green tea vodka
- bourbon if you like the strong drinks
- corn fritters
- pu plater
- OYSTERS!!
author: Megan C.

description: It's hard to wrong at E&O. Almost everything is amazing. I wish their desert menu was better but it's definitely a go-to for my gang.
author: Melvin R.

description:
A quality restaurant with a top notch happy hour service! Grab yourself a seat at the bar and indulge in their $1 oysters and short ribs. Make sure you top it off with a nice, cold glass of white wine or some beer.

Cheers!
author: Sarin P.

description:
The service was great, from the Host in the front of the house, to our Waitress and Bus Fellow.  The chefs were very accommodating to our individual requests. All were very professional, polite and personable.

The food was fresh and perfectly prepared.  I will be dreaming of eating the Black Cod with YuChoy for a long time.  The Asparagus with the Dragon Egg and Pea shoots is also a must have.  And the very best delicate Corn Fritters I've had anywhere.  Not greasy, but so light and delicate with a perfect sauce to balance the sweet and salty we love.
author: Sandi L.

description: Yikes! This place definitely needs work on their food.  We had a few happy hour items and we weren't thrilled out any of what we had.  Textures and flavors were off.  Dumplings were disappointing, but the only saving grace were the chicken satays. Chicken was cooked to perfection.
author: Patrick C.

description:
On a Thursday evening there was plenty of seating at the bar and in the restaurant.

The decor and space is very nice with very clean restrooms downstairs.  The bartender was friendly and accommodating  We tried 4 of their specialty cocktails which were very interesting and worth the $12.00.  

The corn fritters were very good, large pieces of roasted corn with a light batter.  The calamari had a light but firm breading and were tender.  The butternut squash dumplings were flavorful but had a bit of heat to them.  We did not care for the pad thai with the tofu and peppers.  It did not have any sauce or flavor.

They have an extensive food menu for happy hour.
author: Michele L.

description: I'm usually not a fan of anything fusion, but my date said he loved it. I was  surprised by how much I enjoyed it. We had the calamari, chickpea fries, egg rolls, and the prawn salad. My favorite dish was the salad, and I loathe salad. This salad was like a party in my mouth! The salad had prawns, cucumber, mango, mandarin oranges, cashews, mint, cilantro, and maldon salt. The salt complimented all of the ingredients perfectly! I may have to come back just for the salad. Oh, the lime in the coconut cake was fantastic. The cake was moist with bits of coconut flakes and a hint of lime.
author: Ha D.

description: Took the family to E&O on holiday. They have something for everyone. Service was top notch and the food was on par with the service levels. They even made a non-vegetarian dish into a vegetarian dish for us. Great Asian/American mix
author: Peter C.

description:
Went last night with my friends for happy hour.
We ordered 14 oysters  (only a dollar each) and tried some of their other offerings.
We all thought the oysters were pretty good. I liked the kimchi sauce that came with them.
 I got the corn fritters which came with 3 fritters and sauce. They were pretty good but nothing super special. 
My friend ordered the ahi tartare and the dumpling.
We also all got drinks off the happy hour menu which were all $6. I liked mine the best which was the vanilla rum because it tasted the least like alcohol. My friend got the one with tequila and my other friend got the one with vodka which was to strong tasting for me. 
The place is a good place to come for happy hour and has lots of room.
The waiter was super nice and accomadating to use having to split the check.
Will come again for happy hour!
author: Erin S.

description: Not casual dining per ambiance, but definitely casual cuisine kicked up several notches. Some of your favorite simple Asian dishes served in bowls with clean lines so, it's fancy now. The small plates were very tasty! We had the coconut milk seafood ceviche which was superb! If you're not allergic to seafood, you MUST have this even if you don't think you like ceviche! Duck buns- delish! Calamari- crispy, flavorful and light not greasy. The crab Rangoon was ok. The amount and flavor of the crab was great. They turned it up with the addition of goat cheese, but meh! The wonton wrap was very good though- yes they have a texture and flavor so don't think I'm crazy commenting on that Lol! But I'll keep my Rangoon with well whipped and seasoned cream cheese. Smoked deviled egg was quite tasty. Served chilled so be aware of that. Now, entrees- the black cod was, oddly, just okay. I expected more. Cod is so delicate so yes you do have to be cautious when seasoning, but they could've done more with the rub. Korean fried rice- good pieces of shrimp and pork, but the flavor was just okay. I asked for a side of the hoisin sauce served with the duck buns  in order for punch up the flavor. The service was fine. I'd return, if only for that ceviche!
author: Athena A.

description: Great food and drinks here! Brought by my friend here and it's an awesome place for catching up! The food is good and it's a lovely place for conversation! Also, it's right next to a cheap public parking garage! So it's pretty convenient! Highly recommended!
author: Shirley D.

description: Not a huge selection of food - I went with the chicken satay and brown rice, and it was fine, nothing special. I ate at the bar - the bartender was really nice and didn't charge me for my second drink. I don't know that I'd go back, but it was a totally fine place to grab a quick dinner.
author: Emily S.

description: Wanted to try this for a long time. Went for happy hour. Drinks were priced amazing and tasted great. Food wasn't anything to write about. Maybe it was an off day. I'd go back for drinks!
author: Noah M.

description: I've been here for dinner and lunch a few times, and I enjoy the fusion food, and original menu. The space is vast, and I would consider this place for a large group reservation. I could pretty much live on the appetizers alone.
author: Jason P.

description: Came for a work dinner; the back dining room is very loud, so beware. Water glasses were small and were not filled promptly. The calamari was rather tasty though, not too chewy and had a nice flavor. We got a bunch of dishes and shared them: the brussesls side-dish was crispy and good; folks seemed to enjoy the crispy chicken egg rolls and the prawn satay. The pad thai had good flavor but wasn't overly warm and needed more noodles (the tofu was cooked well though), and the table also seemed to enjoy the shaking beef. Didn't try dessert.
author: Emily M.

description:
Had not been here in well over 7 years and ended up going 2x in 2 weeks, it was SO GOOD !!! Both times I took out of town guests and they too loved it. 
First visit, our server was Liza and she was  lovely and a lot of fun. She was also very familiar with the entries and guided our decisions nicely. Also the pace of the dishes was perfect.

Food choices were:
Wood Roasted Edamame Beans ($7.00), The Best Edamame Beans I have ever had and perfectly salted and enough beans for 3 or 4 people.

Tamarind and Hoison Spare Ribs ($16.00) 4 meaty, juicy, melt in your mouth, finger licking good ribs. They were so tender you could even eat the bone. Honestly, I could have just had this and been very happy.

Citrus Avocado Salad ($13.00) dressed perfectly with an abundance of citrus, avocado and other ingredients. Think it was a special of the night. So fresh and pallet cleansing without being too acidic.

Last was the Char Siu Black Cod ($27.00) which melted in your mouth, it was like Butter. Nice generous piece of fish, worthy of sharing. Perfectly marinated  and cooked to perfection.

All the servers were fantastic, on point but not intrusive.

I have to go back as soon as I can.  In the interim, I will go for the Happy Hour, which looks fantastic !

Great job all the way around and nice improvement from the last time I went, well over 7 years ago. They have certainly stepped up their game in freshness, quality, creative dishes with interesting choices.
author: Marla B.

description:
We had a work event here and booked a private room.  While the food was just ok...the service was the best I've ever received.   Tim was our server and knew exactly what we needed.  He followed every instruction to the T and knew exactly what we needed before we needed it.

On top of that, at one point I was thinking of using the restroom and one of the chefs noticed and actually came up and escorted me to the restroom!  For them to pay attention to every last detail like that, even after 20 years of being in the business speaks volumes.  

Thanks for the awesome corporate event!
author: Vi Y.

description:
This is one of my favorite places to go for a relaxed, slightly higher up than casual, dinner. I'm usually pretty skeptical about asian fusion but for the most part, E&O handles it really well. 

If you're coming around dinner time, especially during happy hour, I would recommend that you make a reservation because it can get really busy. There's also a bar here so the ambiance is quite noisy. However, they tend to have dim candle light so it doesn't actually feel like you're in a bar.

Their small plates are probably my favorite part of the menu. The corn fritters are a must get in my opinion! I like them alone but the corn fritter burger was a delight as well. The ahi tuna tartar is another one of my favorite dishes. I will say that their food tends to err on the side of salty especially their ribs and sliders so just be aware. If you're looking for a sampler, the pu pu platter is a nice 2 person sampler plate for $24. You won't be very full off of it but it's great if you're not that hungry.
author: Cassie Z.

description: Humberto was amazing at the bar!!!! Great drinks beat happy hour in Sf! Highly recommend coming here! Amazing food!
author: Molly R.

description: Food was good. Ordered the corn fritters, duck buns, green beans (side), fried rice, pad thai, and black cod. Fried rice and black cod were my fav. Need to go back for happy hour!
author: Van P.

description: I've been here several times and I was satisfied every time. However, I only come here during happy hours because the deals are pretty good. Usually I order the $1 oysters and share. The Pad Thai was pretty boring and was missing something that made it really bland. In my opinion, the tuna tartare is to die for and for $3 each during happy hour, it's a good appetizer. It's a beautiful, dim atmosphere and pretty romantic for a date and there's also an eye-catching drink menu as well. Overall, it's a nice place for lunch and/or dinner.
author: Merrilyn W.

description:
Came here for a quick lunch.   It wasn't crowded at all.   We were seated very fast.  Our server Eddy was very helpful with our decisions. 

The lunch menu had a ton of options and it was hard to chose what to order but I ended up going with the make your own sushi wrap option with the shrimp, brown rice and cucumber with kimchi combo.  

I substituted a salad instead of chips.  

It was actually really yummy and under $12.00.  I would totally come back for happy hour!
author: Kimberly L.

description:
I love this place and I have never had a bad experience  I absolutely recommend you all to try it at least once 

Chris Morgan
author: Chris M.

description:
I was here with a group for a business dinner.

I asked for a gluten free menu, which took about 30 minutes to get.  I was able to eat some of the other items we ordered as appetizers because they were simple and I could tell no gluten was present (they were free of soy sauce too).  

Once everyone at my table was done eating, they finally stopped to ask me if I wanted to order anything.  I realized that I could have just asked if I could order, but I was caught up in conversation and was just annoyed at the limited gluten free menu once I finally got it.  

 A meh in my book.
author: Carrie B.

description:
Good location and decent interior design. 
They brought numbers of samples so I could pick my favorite beer. 
TAI PAD is amazing. Chicken rolls also tasty. 
If you're in business district area, check it out.
author: Mahdi A.

description:
If you want American Asian dishes then E&O is the place for you. What I mean is flavors are either super salty or sweet

Prices are adequate but not worth the price for what you get

Ambiance was definitely good for a date night drink spot but skip the food 

Overall Thoughts

Not my place to grab Asian food
author: Eddie W.

description: Great happy hour $1 oysters and drink specials.  Bartender very friendly.
author: Pat F.

description:
Came here last Friday for their happy hour (Mon-Sat, 3-6 pm) and had a great time!

When I got there, I asked for a table for two and they sat me in the back. However I didn't realize this was the dining area, so when I asked for the happy hour menu, the waitress told me happy hour was only served at the bar and at the high top tables in the front area (some private, some communal). Keep that in mind if you're there for happy hour!

My friend and I tried the following:

Butternut squash dumplings with red curry sauce ($1 each): the dumpling itself tasted a little bit sour to me, but I really enjoyed the light curry sauce it was served in

Oysters ($1 each): this is what we came for, and it did not disappoint! I forgot where our server said our oysters were from, but it was somewhere off the Washington coast

Indonesian corn fritter bites ($3.50): each order comes with 3 small pieces and they were SO good. This was probably our favorite hot small bite. Definitely get this if you like sweet corn

Ahi tuna tartare ($3): I'm usually not a huge tuna person, but this dish had been liberally smothered with sesame oil and came served on a nice crunchy chip, so I really enjoyed it

Tamarind and hoisin pork spare rib ($3): This was okay, but my opinion is probably biased because I'm not huge on the taste of tamarind. I got this so there would be some actual meat in this (otherwise light) meal

Mushroom satay ($2): each order comes with one skewer with a portabella mushroom slice. I love portabellas so I liked this, but thought it was a bit pricey at $2/skewer.

We each got a drink as well, but neither of us particularly liked our drinks. I had the sutter punch (vanilla bean infused rum, pineapple gum, lime) and my friend had the daily white wine.

This happy hour wasn't as cheap as I thought it would be...we each ended up paying around $34! But overall we enjoyed our food if not our drink so I would like to come back again sometime.
author: Dianna H.

description:
This is my favorite place close to work in FiDi for happy hour, which runs until 6pm. Although this place gets decently packed during the early evenings, I never had a problem with getting seated instantly without a reservation. However, reservations are recommended if you have a large group (7+). Also note that the tables in the very back of the restaurant do not partake in happy hour specials.

The $6 HH cocktails I've tried are the Blushing Geisha (tequila prickly pear) and a new vodka green tea drink. Blushing Geisha is hands down my favorite go-to drink of choice. Other HH drinks include $6 wine and $4 beer. I've tried the rosé, which was good but nothing special.

As for HH food, I've tried the butternut squash dumplings, oysters, naan, corn fritter bites, tuna tartare, ribs, sliders, chicken satay, and taro chips. For first timers, the pu pu platter is a great way to try out an assortment of items on the menu or simply to share among a group. My favorite HH food items are the dumplings, corn fritter bites, tuna tartare, and ribs. Skip the $1 oysters. Although $1 may seem like a great deal, the oysters are actually a lot smaller than average and not worth it.
author: Alice S.

description:
It's been way too long since I've eaten at E&O--so, tonight we made a trip downtown to try it once again.

They've created some new cocktails since I've been there and I couldn't resist trying their Rye Spiced Apple drink.  It's chilled and served up with a cinnamon rim---I had two--whoops!.  Very nice cocktail!

We went for the small plates tonight and ordered the ahi tuna tartare, short ribs sliders, corn fritters, lamb naan and finished things up with the ginger spice cookies.  I think the favorite was the ahi tuna tartare--the serving size was perfect for two people and the tuna was as fresh as could be.  Actually, all of the small plates that we ordered were perfect for two people--we left full.  I was happy with the sliders too--the short ribs were moist and seasoned well.
The ginger cookies were "un peccato di gola".  (A sin of the throat!)
So moist and delicious--they gave us 6!  We ate them all.

Service was excellent.  Food was excellent. 

Clap! Clap! Clap!
author: Thomas D.

description: I have been a fan of this place for a while.  My friend and I make the trek into the City just for the food.  Although, I have to say my most recent visit was not as enthusiastic.  It appears they have a new chef?  They changed the menu and removed the most popular item, the butternut squash dumplings and replaced them with two other option.  Very disappointing.  The two other options just had no flavor.  The steak satay also seems to have changed.  The quality was just not there.  Granted there are still things on the menu that are very good, and the pu pu platter always a good choice, I was just not that pleased with menu changes as well as flavor and quality of food.  I'll give it another try at another time to see if they have made some changes.
author: Karen Z.

description:
Highlights from my meal:

DRINKS - if you're looking for something sweet / fruity, I definitely recommend the pisco lychee and vanilla rum. Very refreshing and so delicious, I had to order twice!

Appetizer - corn fritters... a must in their menu! Comes in two big pieces, perfect for sharing with another person. I loved the sauce they provided, and the fritters were fried to perfection. I am definitely getting this next time I come back. 

Main dishes - 
1. Mushroom dumplings - a bit disappointing, to be honest. Dumplings came in 6 pieces, and it wasn't worth its price tag. They were also very salty - I would recommend heading over to Chinatown if you  are craving them.

2. Wood fire burger - another dish I recommend! Their siracha aioli sauce was not spicy at all, and this is coming from a person who cannot tolerate spicy foods at all... 

Service was great and attentive. My friend and I sat at the bar, and the bartender did a great job recommending things off the menu. They also came out to chase after me to return my credit card I left with my check. Will be back to try other items off their menu.
author: Esther K.

description: I'd heard of this place through Gilt (which is like a high end version of Groupon). This past weekend, some friends of ours wanted to meet up for dinner here. So we made a reservation on Opentable. Reservations are recommended - the place seemed packed all night. The mood in here is dim and romantic-like. The food is described as Asian fusion but I think it's like Americanized Asian food. We got a bunch of dishes for the table - Indonesian corn fritters, butternut squash dumplings, shaking beef, paneer naan, and vegetarian chow mein. I would say the best thing was the corn fritters. I specifically picked the butternut squash dumplings so I ate most of that dish. 5 small dumplings in a creamy curry sauce for $14. They were good and stuffed with squash. The shaking beef dish was $28 for a plate mostly of veggies (tomatoes, bell peppers and a ton of onions) and a little bit of beef also slathered in a ton of sauce. The chow mein was ok. I didn't try the naan but our Indian friends loved it as they said it was made with fresh paneer/cheese. At the end of the meal, we had the chocolate silk road cake. I only had a bite and it was pretty good. But I could see it being rich if you had to eat more than half. My bf, who isn't even a chocolate fan really liked it too. Overall I thought it was super overpriced for just ok food. Service was good and quick. Their happy hour menu looks like a good deal - may be back for that.
author: Alison W.

description:
Never been disappointed!
Food: really well balanced and just spicy enough
Ambiance: Great interior design, confortable and warm
author: Bruno C.

description: Great drinks and service! Happy hour specials are great, we ordered the sampler and were fully satisfied.
author: Stephanie M.

description: The butternut squash dumpling is delicious.  Delicious. The sauce is creamy, rich, delicate,and incredible. Absolutely delicious!
author: Henry V.

description:
Come here for happy hour at this in the Asian fusion place. The ambience is quite dark inside - better for later dining than lunch. 

For happy hour:
- miyagi oysters are quite good but there is shell in the oyster so be careful when eating them or requesting the person shucking it to not leave any shells inside the oysters. 

- butternut squash dumpling is put together well but I am not a huge fan of sweet dumpling (from the butternut squash). Go for the savory ones on the main menu

- spare rib is a fantastic deal. Get as much as you want (they are pretty large). Skip the cabbage on the side.

I also had the Indonesian corn fritters here which are quite good and original. 

NON-HAPPY HOUR:
- crispy chicken spring rolls. Done well here. Solid. Recommend

- chicken lettuce cups - bland. Skip. 

- roasted asparagus - bland. Not a fan.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
You ever have a long, and rough day from work and think to yourself, "man I need a beer." Go here. 

Their happy hour will get you out of you post-work day slump. 

Here's the cure: bring a co-worker and order a Pilsner & the pu-pu platter to share. This will make your day a lot better. 

The pu-pu platter is a smorgasbord of Asian fusion bites.
-Chicken satay: juicy chicken on a skewer paired with a peanut sauce
-Corn fritter: fried corn with a special sauce
-Tuna tartare bites: raw tuna on a small round chip. (I ate this in one bite & it was delicious)
-Pork spare ribs: sweet bbq ribs, the meat pretty much falls off the bone
-Beef short rib sliders: a bit dry, but dip it in the corn fritter sauce and that brings it back to life. 
-Taro chips: less guilty version of potato chips

Just some snacks to eat while you discuss how much your work day sucked (:
author: Rachelle Y.

description: My first time eating here. I loved it. It was an interesting and fun experience. We had nasi goreng, pad Thai, burger on corn flitters buns, appetizers and drinks. This E & O kitchen seemed like kind of Indonesian, Thai and Malaysian fusion. The staff very friendly.
author: Suzane S.

description:
We went here for a Saturday happy hour and I really enjoyed it. 

The oysters weren't amazing (though they were only $1 so I can't really complain) and the drinks were a little weak, but the rest of the happy hour food we ordered was awesome. 

The dumplings were definitely my favorite--I could totally eat a whole plate of those--and the spare ribs and chicken satay were on point too. Definitely worth the price overall.
author: Christina L.

description: This place has amazing food, drinks, and service. We went for the first time tonight and loved everything. We will definitely be back.
author: Kathy C.

description:
Got to SF pretty early for a concert and needed to kill time and find a Happy Hour spot STAT! Chose this place because the menu pulled me and Boba Guys was nearby. I also was curious since it has several private dining space, I had sourced it for a couple work events. 

Here are the HH items we ordered: 
- butternut squash, red curry sauce: ahhhhmazing! my favorite! $1 per dumpling 
- wood oven naan: pretty good, it had sesame seeds and nicely toasted. I only tried the yogurt dipping sauce with it.  they give you a good amount for one order. 
- ahi tuna tartare: they give you a good amount on one piece. tuna was fresh. $3 per piece 
- oysters: small, but they were yummy. $1 per oyster 
- chicken satay: pretty large pieces on the skewer, reasonable price for one skewer which is $3
author: Lorelyn P.

description:
We were at E&O to meet a friend for dinner. The place has a great downtown vibe--great place for drinks and dinner. We decided to order a bunch of small plates.  The Indonesian corn fritters (two on a plate) were huge, crispy, delicate and the corn was fresh and sweet! So good.  The chickpea fries looked great but the flavor and texture was just okay. The shiitake dumplings were to little pillows bursting with flavor---to die for! Next time I am ordering one just for myself!  The butternut squash dumplings were a surprise--slightly sweet with a savory curry sauce with a hint of heat! Yummy! We also ordered a mushroom satay and a chicken satay (for the hubby)--both flavorful. For some freshness we ordered the coconut and jicama salad which was wow! Crunchy, sweet, salty, sour and full of flavor! WE rounded off the meal with chocolate in mandarin--devils food cake, bittersweet chocolate mouse mandarin orange ganache with miso caramel! Perfect way to end the meal! 

Great place for an evening out in the City!
author: Deepa R.

description:
They need serious help in Asian cooking...

When my server presented the chef's special fried chicken, I was at one point confused that it might be some huge samosas instead. The skin was somehow ripped, mixed with too much flour, and put back to cover the chicken. It was the hardest and thickest fried chicken skin I've ever had! And I can't really eat with hands! My friend kept apologizing because it was her idea to order it and share.

Now I can only picture some chefs making up dishes with their smatter asian cooking knowledge and their own twists in the kitchen......

So please, do not come here for decent Asian food.
author: Yuhuan T.

description:
I was attending a lecture nearby and dropped by for a quick bite afterward. Little did I know it would turn out to be my new favorite place!

The staff are so incredibly nice and helpful, first thing you notice.  We had the chicken satay, lettuce cups, chickpea fries and the salt/pepper calamari.  While I've had pretty much all of these dishes at other places before...this place definitely elevated them. The lettuce cups use gem lettuce so you can actually bend the lettuce. The seasoning was fantastic! 

The calamari was so good, you didn't need the dipping sauce! 
All the food was fresh, seasoned to perfection and just delicious!
author: Eileen F.

description:
I was in San Francisco celebrating my friend's birthday, and we decided to dine here for dinner.

E&O kitchen is nestled in the downtown area by Union Square. It offers an intimate yet modern setting with an open dinning area and bar.

We happened to be there on the weekend of Chinese New Years, so the parade occurring downtown made everything very crowded and a bit hard to access. The staff there was excellent and accommodating in getting us there and seated despite the craziness. 

Below is what we tried-

Ahi Tuna Tartar- Served with black sesame crackers.  Excellent fresh and flavorful. The black sesame crackers were a tasty addition
Panir Naan- Cucumber raita, roasted tomato chutney. Very good. Great option for vegetarians.
Corn Fritters- Served with sweet chili soy sauce. This was a signature item of theirs and was excellent. 
Shiitake Mushroom Dumplings- Very good
Satay Your Way- We did a vegetarian style with tofu, and fresh veggies. It was excellent
Grilled Cauliflower- Great as well.
Devils food cake-Sinfully sweet, but a must have. Served with a to doe for salted Carmel sauce. 

Aside from the food being great, (Props to the chef) the staff was amazing. The manager Akop went above and beyond to make our experience, and my friend's birthday, absolutely memorable. He sent over champagne for us to toast with, and the tasty birthday dessert. Our waiter, who I am blanking on his name (Male, younger with blond hair) was amazing as well. He was attentive, friendly, and knowledgeable. He made some great suggestions on modifying the menu for my vegetarian friend, while also suggesting some tasty dishes for those of us that ate meat/fish. Lastly, the host was also wonderful. She was pleasant and even checked on us during our meal. She was also nice enough to charge my phone for me while I dinned.

Overall our experience was great. The atmosphere, chef, and staff were all top notch. I wish I lived in San Fran so I could dine here more often. However, I will definitely be back on my next visit.
author: Jenn P.

description: Came here on a Friday night. Felt bad because I recommended it to my husband and had really bad service. The restaurant itself is nice and the food is good but our waitress tonight was horrible. She only came around to drop off our order and never checked on us. I literally had to shout out for her to get her attention as she passed us. I understand it was busy but I also saw other servers being attentive to their tables. Very disappointed.
author: Leslie C.

description:
This was the second night out for us during my bachelorette weekend. E & O has such a cool menu--very diverse and broad-ranging so I had a hard time deciding what to eat. It's also on the more reasonable side, price wise, which added to the challenge.

We had a private room, and this is where the one star is knocked off. The wallpaper in this room made EVERYONE in my party (and there were 11 of us) dizzy and feeling like we were on a cruise ship.  I also wasn't a fan of our server. She was slow and hardly checked on us. Even though a tip is guaranteed as it was built in, this seems unprofessional.

Anyways, we all ordered different things. The edamame was delicious, but what you expect at places that do steamed edamame.  I had giant Indonesian corn fritters which were enough for 4 people. They were challenging to eat because they fell apart rather quickly.  Friends got the pad thai, the roasted cauliflower (delicious), chicken lettuce cups, dry fried green beans, and the kimchi spring rolls. The food is good, filling and unique.  I wanted fries but thought that wasn't unusual enough to try here.

I would come back but not sit in that spinny room.
author: Milee S.

description: I was is recommended for this restaurant And I was not disappointed. The drinks the food outstanding service everything was wonderful. Highly recommend this wonderful restaurant to anyone who wants to enjoy a great meal thank you very much
author: Nick K.

description: AMAZING old fashion and it's only $6 during happy hour! They make their old fashion with their Evans well whiskey, but they also add their own HOMEMADE maple BITTERS. All their cocktails are made with their HOMEMADE fresh fruit mixes. The oysters were also amazing!
author: Kimberly D.

description:
We had reservations for 3 at 5:30 for this restaurant situated near Union Square. Parking is available at the Sutter/Stockton Garage.
Reservations are recommended as this place quickly got busy as the night wore on.
We were seated rather quickly and the wait staff was very friendly and efficient. The restaurant has a hipster/art deco feeling. The full size bar is huge and the kitchen is situated way in the rear of the restaurant behind clear glass.
The cuisine is basically Asian fusion style. Since we got there early we hit up the Happy Hour menu ordering squash dumplings, mushroom and chicken satay, chilled oysters in half shell ($1,00 each) served on large tray of ice with lemon and spicy cocktail sauce- great deal, rib sliders, excellent, and we had  fried crispy fritters. We ordered only one dish off the regular menu which was cauliflower. 
Along with the happy hour appetizers I had a Trumer Pilsner for $4.00, regular price is $6.00. There are a few drink specials also mentioned on the happy hour menu.
Everything here is very delicious and I would definitely recommend the happy hour specials.
We spent along time just bs'ing and even though it was busy, they never pressured us to leave or to hurry up.
This is a very cool place to eat great food and have a drink or two.
author: jack d.

description: All the good things you've read about this place are true. The servers are very attentive and the food is awesome.  Will definitely be coming back next time I am in the city.
author: Gerry K.

description: A fabulous restaurant with amazing Asian flavors. The crispy corn fritters are always tasty and fresh, and lots of great veggie choices in addition to me
author: Ted L.

description:
Food tasted pretty good for the most part. But portions are always skimpy on these upscale places. I had the satay skewers, only comes with 4. It was $24 for a set menu with calamari appetizer and the satay skewers with rice, if u want the cookie as part of.the dessert it was extra $5...blah

4 dinky skewers and rice...not enough to feed me if I only ordered an entrée.

Hubby got the fritter burger and loved it...but I still rather go to a real Thai place and have better tasting skewers
author: Nina T.

description:
I've eaten at E&O several times over the years and always remembered them to be "good enough".  I recently revisited with a gf for a birthday dinner and it was tasty so I thought I'd return again last eve with my other half as I thought he would enjoy it as well.

It was tasty as expected but here is the deal.  I had the black cod which I thought the texture was kind of gummy versus firm for a cod and my other half remarked the same.  Later when I got home I had a serious case of upset tummy.  

It's obvious I didn't die but I thought I'd call them to let them know.  Here's how my phone call went with them:

Me: "Hi, can I please speak with the manager?"
E&O: "Sure, what is this regarding?"
Me (thinking huh?): "A food safety issue"
Put on hold
E&O: "Hello how can I help you?
Me: "Is this the manager?"
E&O: "Yes" (apparently still nameless)
Me: "Hi, my name is XXXXXXX, I wanted to let you know that I dined with you last evening and I had the black cod and it made me sick."
E&O: "First of all I am sorry to hear that you were sick.  Are you sure it was the black cod?"
Me: "Yes, because I had the deviled eggs to start then the black cod with the Brussels sprouts."
E&O: "And did you share your meal?"
Me: "No, he just had the lamb nan.  And btw the table beside us had apparently complained about their fish as well.  They had the braised fish and they both did not touch it saying it was "very fishy"...so there must have been an issue with your refrigeration or freshness of your fish yesterday..."
E&O: "I am sorry to hear that you were sick, are you feeling better today?"
Me (really grateful they cared enough to ask): "Yes I am"
E&O: "Well thank you for calling to let us know"
End of call

So I apparently did y'all a public service by calling them and letting them know their fish was bad.  That's my charity work for the day.

I think I lost the plot somewhere.  The times when I've had such issues with a restaurant I've always been invited back on some sort of complimentary drink or app or whatever.  I even got a refund or a gift certificate.

Not that I am broke butt but I think it's called public relations? So what used to be a 3 - 4 star restaurant got taken down due to lack of "sensitivity training".  Eat at your own risk.
author: Favoloso M.

description:
Came here after an event in FIDI. Hungry and on the prowl for dinner with the SO. Stumbled upon E&O as there was no wait.

Great space, nice ambiance, perfect dim lighting for a date (LOL). We were seated promptly by the hostess.. Our server came around, with a frown :( sad he wasn't too enthusiastic about the menu. I guess we were taking too long perusing through the yelp photos as he did not seem too please at us for not being able to make our selections quickly. (I'm sorry, it's a bad habit, but i can't help check out my selections with my eyes prior to ordering an entree). 
Anyhow, we ended up sharing the following as we weren't too hungry.

Papaya salad: Too much vinegar. Missing umami flavor. Was not really balanced and definitely lacked the pow you would get at a traditional asian restaurant. I get that it's "asian fusion"  but, i felt the flavors were diluted and the vinegar overpowering.

Spicy Green Bean: Great flavor, loved the blistering chared-ness of the green beans, but OMG the tiniest portion ever. I get that it's a side, but really? the serving was less than my fist..and for $9...Maybe i just have to get accustomed to the ridiculous pricing of DTSF eats?

E&O Burger: great flavor and pairings. Burger was cooked nicely, fries were delicious. Good burger overall, very happy with the kimchee on the bottom bun.

Overall, it was a decent meal. I probably will not come back as I feel the food did not "wow" me and was not too memorable. Also for the price, there are definitely better options out there with more bang for your  buck. Dining experience was mediocre as well.
author: Diane T.

description:
I'm a fan of this place for their happy hour deal! This is the first spot my friends and I went to when I got to San Fran and it was right during the 3-6pm happy hour mark, winning! They have $1 oysters, $1 dumplings plus a variety of other small plates that you and everyone else can share (if they share). 

I ordered quite a few oysters and they were indeed fresh. The ahi tuna tartare is a great choice as well as the Pu Pu platter if you're dining as a group. The Pu Pu Platter included the the fritter bites, ribs, sliders, chicken satay skewers and the ahi.  I would recommend that if you're indecisive of which plates to try out from their list. We all had moscow mules which were perfectly made, wasn't too strong or had too much ginger beer. Best part was that it was only $6. 

I definitely appreciate the cleanliness of the restaurant including the washrooms. Everything was properly presented and the service was exceptional. For a Saturday it wasn't too busy either so you're bound to have no problem finding a seat for some small happy hour plates. Would highly recommend to those in the area!
author: Tien N.

description: Came here for lunch on our first day in San Fran after a quick yelp search and had a great meal. We had the tuna tartare, the papaya salad, shiitake dumplings, naan, the green beans, edamame, and the eggplant with tofu ( a side dish actually!). All were great. I was a bit disappointed that none of the vegetable dumplings, chickpea fries, or fritters were vegan, but still, they were able to make the payaya salad, as well as the eggplant and green beans vegan. They were a few other options as well.
author: Ami I.

description:
We went for the happy hour. We ordered 10 oysters ($1 each), tuna tartare, chicken satay, and mushroom satay. All the dishes above were excellent. 

The sauce for the oysters were a kimchi oyster sauce that was very special and easy to eat.

The chicken satay was very soft and tender and was dipped in some peanut sauce.

The tuna tartar was placed on a crunchy tortilla like chip and it worked perfectly. 

The mushroom satay was also really delicious. 

Overall, a great happy hour dining experience.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Stylish, friendly restaurant. I had an early dinner here at the bar on a Sunday night with a friend and it was a very pleasant, chill experience. We loved the mushroom dumplings and the chicken with lettuce cups. The steamed edamame was your basic steamed edamame so not really worth it. I should have had the corn fritters instead. My friend really didn't care for her BBQ riblets.

The bartender was very friendly but let us chat without interruption. I'd love to return!
author: Shari S.

description: We had a company dinner here so the menu was fixed. Everything was excellent but the stars of the evening where the appetizers. Sobo noodles, corn fritters, lamb meatballs, shrimp satay all were out of this world. The lemon grass tofu as an entree was beautifully prepared. If I could make tofu taste that delicious, I could easily be a vegetarian.
author: Brad G.

description:
Three words: CHICKEN LETTUCE WRAPS

Absolutely delicious and tasty! Cost about $16. The lettuce is cut and served fresh to order and the chicken was bursting with flavor. Made with ground chicken, water chestnuts, shiitake mushrooms, and topped with pine nuts. The dish is more than enough for two people to share and feel free to ask the server for more lettuce. I did, haha just cause we had more chicken than lettuce which I thought was a great thing. To get the whole experience, don't forget to try the sriracha sauce on the chicken lettuce wraps. It added the perfect amount of heat for each bite. If you're not a hot sauce fan, this dish is very appetizing on its own. Literally, I have nothing, but good things to say about this.

I also ordered the Satay Your Way $17 - it was a mix and match of 4 satays of your choice: pickled vegetables, rice, chicken, shrimp, beef or mushroom. It was my first time, and I ordered one of each which was recommended by the server. The chicken, shrimp. mushroom was cooked to perfection and the meat was very tendor. She also shared with us the new drinks on the menu, one of them was lyche and the other was prickly pear. Both were very refreshing and you will definitely enjoy it to the last drop.
author: Tina M.

description:
Great value for HH.

So what I love about their HH is they have a good selection of cocktails/appetizers. The only issue is that I did not love the actual taste of the appetizers, which is why I probably would not come here to eat. Definitely would continue to visit for drinks!

Place gets pretty packed in the evening, if you're here for dinner, I'd definitely suggest calling ahead.

FYI, all the HH portions are small so it'd be redundant if I kept repeating that-

Dumplings- these were fine, don't think I'd order again. Maybe as a palate cleanser, though?
Tuna Tartare- this was good! Definitely left you wanting more.
Oysters- yay, $1/piece. Fine, but like most places when they're producing them in this variety, they definitely tend to get lazy on the shucking so slurp wisely.
Chicken satay- probably would avoid ordering this again
Fritter bites- didn't take a stab at these myself, other friends seemed to be satisfied by them

Prickly Pear cocktail- On the sweet side! I didn't order this one but the bar accidentally gave it to me, haha. Not my first choice off the menu.
Vanilla infused cocktail- This was fine, almost feels night-capy so be warned
Green tea cocktail- This one was the winner off the cocktails on HH for me.
author: Arezou A.

description: The food was great, I'd recommend the pork buns. It's a open bun, looks like a taco and taste like lava. So spicy, and delicious. Drinks were great. A little overpriced. But the bartender was cute and friendly with a great accent. "Cheers". I'd go during happy hour, and get the pu pu platter. The people sitting next to me ordered it and it looked amazing. 4 stars instead of 5 because we showed up 10 minutes before 3 and our waiter didn't recommend to wait til happy hour...
author: Zachary G.

description:
Went for dinner with family during a recent visit to sf. Amazing experience! 

Dinner was great, food quality and preparation was top notch. Had the black cod, dumplings, Japanese bim bim baap. All were great. Service was good not stellar. 

Overall, highly recommended.
author: Tarun G.

description:
Let's be honest - "Asian fusion" is almost always a total miss (typically in the form of a mediocre Indian menu with chow mein thrown into the mix). However, I was seriously impressed with almost everything we ate at E&O given the diversity and range of the true fusion menu. The casual yet ambiance with great service is the icing on the cake. 

We started off with the butternut squash dumplings based on our waitress's recommendations - these are a must. The flavorful and tender dumplings in the rich red curry are a unique and memorable combination. 

Entrees we went with the steak satay and lamb naan. The satay wasn't anything particularly unique or memorable. That being said, very well cooked steak with a great hint of seasoning - as straightforward as it gets. When it came to the lamb naan, I was honestly surprised with how much my Indian palate enjoyed it. Ground lamb was excellently seasoned, the bread was soft, and the raita yogurt sauce was an awesome complement. Also ordered a side of eggplant and tofu. It looked great, but was honestly pretty flavorless. 

Dessert menu looked bomb, but I'd already sinned with a double scoop of Ben & Jerry's earlier in the day. Hope to be back soon to try them out and get a second crack at the fantastic fusion dishes! (Also, the happy hour deals were super compelling).
author: Chandrabh A.

description:
I honestly try and avoid crossing the bridge and paying toll unless it is unavoidably necessary. This place could have been avoided. My sister and I came here for her friend's birthday dinner. 

The ambiance and vibe of this restaurant is one of the few things I liked about it. The restaurant is dimly lit and had an air of relaxation circulating. The crowd age ranged from mid 20s to late 30s. I really enjoyed just being in here. This could be a good spot for a stereotypical date, with a casual feel. 

I know that there is an issue when I eat somewhere and feel the need to get food from another place when I leave. This was, unfortunately, the case after I left here. The 3 stars is for the food. I paid $30 for food that I did not enjoy. I ordered the butternut squash dumplings with chicken skewers. The dumplings dish was the best out of the two, but it only came with about 4 dumplings. It came in yummy coconut sauce. The chicken skewers was a really bad decision. It was poorly seasoned and a regretted every bite. 

This appears to be a good place to go to for drinks. I chose not to drink adult beverages, so I ordered the House Made Ginger Ale. Yummy! You could really taste the ginger. 

I would come back I here for drinks and good company and most likely avoid the food.
author: Cherise N.

description: Absolutely amazing experience. We made late reservations for a party of 7 and we were gladly given a table in their private room! It was an absolute awesome start to our dinner as we had just come back from a long drive from Napa. The service here was impeccable. They catered to our every request. Our waiter on 7/28/18 at 9:30pm (forgot his name) was amazing and probably was one of the best waiters we've ever had! He was knowledgeable about the menu, made awesome recommendations, accommodated for our dietary restrictions and even helped us adjust the temperature in the room to our liking! We were floored by the service and equally LOVED the food! The many different vegetarian options made our 99% vegetarian party very happy! The food was delicious and if we lived out on the west coast this would definately be one of our go to spots on the regular! For now, we will be recommending any of our family traveling to San Francisco to E&O!
author: Bina B.

description:
I came to E&O with two of my friends for happy hour! We saw E&O had really good happy hour deals so we were pretty excited. 

We got there at around 5 pm and it wasn't crowded at all. The interior and ambiance of the restaurant is super intimate and the lighting is dark! Very nice for a happy hour with friends or date night. :-)

We ordered 30 oysters ($30) and the pupu platter for two ($22) and added on another person on our pupu platter for $10! The pupu platter comes with a variety of their appetizers- ahi tuna tartare, beef short rib sliders, pork spare ribs, corn fritters, chicken satay skewers, taro chips and pickled veggies! We thought this was a good deal because we got to try multiple items from the menu. I would say my favorite app was the corn fritters!! I love corn and anything fried so it was basically those two together haha. The chicken satay skewers were also realllly well cooked/juicy and went well with the peanut sauce. 

We actually got two rounds of oysters (split 15/15) and the first round was pretty small, but the second round ones were huge!! Also loved the kimchi cocktail sauce!

I didn't get a drink but my friends got beer and a cocktail, and they enjoyed their drinks! Maybe next time for me!

I wouldn't mind coming back for HH but their normal menu items do seem a bit pricey. The service was awesome though! Our waiter was really friendly and was always checking up on us.
author: Tara A.

description: We went for lunch before a matinee. The menu is the perfect size with a wide variety of choices. We started with the chickpea "fries" which were served with a sumptuous curry aioli and wood roasted edamame which were also delicious. My wife had a green papaya salad and I had the choose your own satay plate. The salad was full of umami and the shrimp and steak satay was cooked perfectly. As an added bonus the service was exemplary. Antonio, our waiter and the rest of the staff were very observant yet not annoying and provided a great experience. The Asian fusion POV is inviting and I can't wait to go back and try some more of their enticing menu.
author: Bruce L.

description:
I thought I reviewed this place already...

I came here on a Tuesday night after work with my friend and it was pretty packed already, which I take is always a good sign. And without my boyfriend there to stop me, we ordered way too many dishes...so here they are!

First of all, it's ALL about the Butternut Squash Dumplings and the Indonesian Fried Rice. I don't know what makes the fried rice Indonesian but it's certainly delicious (if anyone knows, please let me know). The rice was cooked just right and not dry at all. The dumplings were soft and the Thai red curry lemongrass sauce was amazing!

Indonesian Corn Fritters - meh, just corn fritters but tasted more like fried thing than corn.

Beef Short Rib Sliders - a little oily, too dry. Comes with taro chips but I'm not too much of a fan but my friend said they were delicious.

Portobello Mushroom Satay - too much sauce. My friend gave me a weird look when I told him because sauce is important. I agree but I don't want my veggies drowned in this sauce. I'd still like to taste mushroom if possible...

Dry Fried Green Beans - I always order this because I'm on a mission to find a good Dry Fried Green Beans to restore my boyfriend's "faith" in this dish. It's one of my favorite Chinese veggie dishes but every time we order it, it fails us. So if any of you know a place with really good 四季豆, please let me know!

I'd come again to keep trying other dishes for sure!
author: Athena C.

description:
Interesting 

Tried a new thing. Japanese bop. Like a deep fried Rice Krispie cake. With pickled veggies. Spinach and a fried egg on the top

I enjoyed it but would probably not order again. Lots of crunchy fried rice 

The calamari to start was good but standard fare

Service very pleasant
author: Dave H.

description:
HH menu was good and food was delicious
$1 oysters (small ones) 
$1 dumplings ($1 per DUMPLING) 
$3.50 for the corn fritters (amazing) 
$4 draft beer 
$6 white, red or champagne 

Service -
Came in and the front desk staff weren't inviting. They also talked about us as we were walking in. 
 
Some of the bartenders were really nice and sweet and even smiled at us. 

Overall, we definitely didn't feel welcomed and would not come back.
author: Michelle N.

description: Very nice experience.   Everyone seemed to like their jobs and were very helpful and friendly.  Miguel was our waiter and he was excellent.  Food was fabulous as were the drinks
author: Jewel M.

description:
It's best to reserve a spot by calling them ahead of time during busy hours for this restaurant. We came here a bit early for our reservation today, but they were kind enough to let us sit around and seated us really quick. We were expected to get those high tables, but since we came a bit early, we were being able to be seated at the regular table. The setting is really dimmed and I laughed at my friend who use her phone flashlight to read the menu. The sever is really sweet, asking if we enjoyed the food. 
We decided to do family style and here's what we ordered:
Small-
Indonesian Corn Fritters (
Highly recommend! It comes with the special sauce and it's super crunchy) 

Rolls&Dumpling-
Butternut Squash Dumplings (it's ok, nothing special, taste like curry) 

Rice&Noodles-
Indonesian Friend Rice (pretty delicious , also recommend getting this)

Drunken Noodles ( there were so little noodles ,'it's ok ) 

Meat&Seafood
Wood Roasted Char Siu Black Cod (NOT WORTH THE PRICE, although it taste good, the portion is so small...good if ur ballin$) 

Overall, Price sucks for the portion size, but it's not bad for the taste
author: Judy M.

description: Saw this restaurant advertised in our hotel room magazine and decided to check it out. Should be reviewed higher. Everything we ordered was fantastic! Don't miss the butternut squash and mushroom dumplings. The brussel sprout  side is quite tasty. I was full long before I stopped eating...
author: Kit S.

description:
Came here for happy hour - the food and drinks were great and came at a good deal!
I just stuck with a Pilsner beer and my friend tried the green tea vodka cocktail, which definitely tasted like both green tea and vodka. 
My personal favorite dish was the dumplings in red curry sauce - so, so good! I only ordered 3 because I wasn't sure how a butternut squash dumpling would taste, but next time I go back I will make sure to order 8 or so. The $1 oysters were pretty good, as were the corn fritters. Chicken satay was a little bit dry and bland, but otherwise passable. My only criticism is that the food came out at different times, so I was almost done when my friend's food came. The restaurant did not seem overly busy so I felt that it could have been timed better. Overall, the food's quality makes up for it.
author: Philippe D.

description: Excited to try something new with our friends while spending the day in the city - BIG Mistake - sub par food - way to spicy we had to keep asking them to tone it down - we brought 3 bottles of wine with us however they tried to charge us for 8 ! When we told the manager he told us this is San Francisco and they can do what they want ! Also never touch the staff you will be accused of sexual harassment- as the hostess called our name for our table our group leader told her thank you while he touch her arm - big mistake - reported to the manager!  San Francisco also charges you 15% on your bill to cover employee health insurance !  Unbelievable- we will never go back to this place
author: Kelly Z.

description: I've only been here for happy hour, but this is truly one of the best happy hours in all of SF. It's one of the rare ones where it actually feels like a DEAL, rather than the usual scheme of SF happy hours where the portions are just smaller but the price actually doesn't proportionally get decreased and you end up paying more. No, this place actually has legit $6 drinks (their maple old fashioned was excellent) and great food deals, with their corn fritters for $4 being the main attraction. The bartender was very on top of things and made excellent drinks. Definitely going to be my go-to HH destination from now on.
author: Kazu O.

description: Enjoyed the dinner here a lot. Ordered fried rice and satay platter with pickled veggies. The platter came with 8 skewers (prawns, chicken, steak, portobello mushrooms). The meat tasted very good and juicy. There is nothing worse than dry meat. These skewers were exceptionally delicious. Enjoyed the pickled veggies a lot too. The fried rice was good, had a nice kick to it but was on the saltier side. I enjoyed it regardless. The service was great. The waitress deserved her 20$ tip. Will definitely be back when in the area.
author: Lidiyanna Z.

description: Great lunch spot in Union Square off the beaten path from the hotels and such. Had the burger, it was great, will definitely be back again.
author: Allison S.

description:
E&O was a bit of a mixed bag. Some dishes were amazing while others missed the mark. Service was also spotty... started out strong but then forgot about us for long stretches of time. 

It truly is Asian fusion with dishes ranging from India to Cambodia. Successes were the tartare which is poke style, Indonesian fried rice, and the ginger cookies. I was not as impressed with the satay, steak, or corn fritters which seemed too fried. 

The place was packed so it must be popular, but for that price you might as well head to The Slanted Door!
author: Tami H.

description: What a wonderful dinner experience! We are frequent dinner out people and while on a day trip to SF today found this gem! We didn't have reservations and they didn't think they would be able to get us in until 8...then a young man (maybe a manager) asked if we would like to sit at the "chef's counter" with one other couple. We LOVED it! The food was excellent...the service wonderful...and a great location and atmosphere to top it off. Well deserving of 5 stars in our book! Thank you so much...we will be back!
author: Wendy M.

description: Great drinks and appetizers! Nice ambience as well. The service was a bit slow though we were there at an off peak hour.
author: Shabina M.

description: Great place to hang out with small group or if you just need some nice place to chill with some good drinks in downtown. They have some small plates which is affordable and delicious. Drinks are good and price is good, plus they have happy hours, a great place to meet friends or a bar-hopping type of date night place to go.
author: Mathew Z.

description: The aroma at e&o is intoxicating! I ordered their popular Indonesian corn fritters, recommended by Brian Boytano from Food Network's Best Thing I Ever Ate. But it was okay. I couldn't get the GMOs off my head . 3 star solely for the over-hyped fritters, but 5 stars for decor, cleanliness, and staff pleasantries. I'm visiting and have 2 more restaurants to hit up tonight but did not tell the waitress. She didn't even bat an eye but lite up when i ordered only one thing that cost $10. Good job, San Francisco lady, ure awesome. Keep up the good work!
author: Vivian L.

description:
Asian cuisine at it's finest in the heart of San Francisco! I had never even heard of this place before my 1st visit here. Large space with beautiful high ceilings just the way I like it. Pleasantly greeted by our host right away. I told her I was new there and I'd like to check this place out before being seated so she let me go upstairs for a peek and there were plenty of tables as well as private rooms available for guests. Good to know!

Water was offered right away because the area where we were seated felt extremely warm especially for it being such a cold night out. Our waiter helped me pick a cocktail and I stuck with it for the rest of the night because it was very refreshing and delicious. I got the "Vodka Thai Basil"... I didn't take a picture even after ordering it multiple times! Super fail.

The food was great! I went with three friends so don't think I ate all of this by myself :)

*Starters*
Short ribs -melt in your mouth, I wish I got this as my main dish
Fried Calamari - so crispy but still felt so light
Pork dumplings - wouldn't mind bathing in this dumpling juice
Tuna Tartar- very fresh fish. loved it!

*Main Course*
I got the Pad Thai and I don't remember it saying it was going to be spicy but I was pleasantly surprised that it was "make your nose run" kind of spicy.

No dessert for us and we all had plenty of leftovers to take home. Which probably happened because we over-ordered on the appetizers.
author: Margarita V.

description: I was here for dinner. The atmosphere was fun and exciting. It was a lively crowd. The decor is quite what I would expect in San Francisco. With Asian fusion food the decor matched the style. I had the jicama salad and pad Thai. The salad was fresh and light with a slight kick from fresh chilies. The pad Thai was cooked perfectly and the addition of Bok Choy gave it a great crunch. The service was impeccable.
author: Theresa S.

description: I have always been a loyal and regular guest at E&O. Since they were in Marin county. After they closed all the locations except Sutter st. I try to come every other week for happy hour, great service always, all the bartenders, food runners and some servers knows us very well. Well I came last Saturday and Boom!!! They change the menu!!! What in the world were they thinking??? They took off the butternut squash dumplings, our favorites, to replace them for a tasteless mushroom dumplings  and they took off the pulled pork sliders for a dry and sad duck buns. On top of that they took off a few drinks from the menu also. I'm not sure if they have a new chef, but, if they do, he should have made a study about the plates that are big sellers, (and these are the bomb!!) before Making a desition. I heard a few people complaining about the changes. I hope they reconsider, otherwise, they're gonna start loosing business, specially for happy hour.
author: Harold F.

description:
Really cool happy hour! My boyfriend was craving oysters for a really long time and saw this place on eater.com. It promoted $1 oysters and dumplings...so I obviously had to try this place out. Happy hour goes from 3-6 I think Monday - Saturday. 

Beer is $4, cocktails are $6, and the hh food menu ranges from $1-6. I mainly came for the oysters. They were fresh and pretty good. Downside is that they were the tiny ones, so you go through them really quickly!!! Watch out if you are on a budget! If you don't like oysters, definitely get the dumplings!!! It was so tasty  ahi tuna was alright, wouldn't pay $3 for one.  My friends got the sliders and they came with a side of taro chips, this was also good. 

The waiter was super nice and helpful. I love how happy hour was ending and he came around and told us about last round. This gave us time to really order the last minute beers and extra order of oysters. So thumbs up to the service. 

We didn't have to wait for a table and they could accommodate a large party. I definitely will come here again and want to try the dinner menu. Will update my review once I get that a try, but the hh is on point!
author: Jackie N.

description:
One of my many reviews I've yet to publish...I've been there a few times now for the trifecta:  once for lunch, once for HH, and once for dinner.  HH would probably be my favorite though, if I had to choose.  =)

Lunch:  Came here to celebrate my former boss's birthday and started with the corn fritters, per her recommendation and if I know one thing about my former boss, she does not steer anyone in the wrong direction.  It's also one of the more popular items on the menu it seems, and with good reason.  A mouthful of crispy deliciousness dipped with sweet and tangy chili soy sauce.  However, the pad thai that I ordered as my entree was a bit off the mark for my taste, bland and underwhelming.

Happy Hour:  Booked a reservation in advance for a decent sized party and when we showed up, everything was already set up for us.  Of course, from previous experience I opted for the corn fritters, though the ones from the HH menu are smaller in portion than the regular lunch/dinner menu.  The sampler included the house ribs and some sliders but the portions and price ratio left a bit to be desired.  

Dinner:  Lastly, a vendor treated me out for dinner and the first thing out of my mouth were the corn fritters lol.  Luckily, we were there at the tail end of HH and we were able to sneak in an order of oysters and drinks.  For the entree, I went with the shaking beef, cooked with red onions, tomatoes, chilies, and watercress.  Nothing from the dish really blew me away to make a lasting impression but c'est la vie.  

Overall, E&O is a solid option if you're looking for a sit down place for HH and a venue that doesn't get too noisy.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Great experience.  With group @ private party.  Delicious food served family style
  great Hor dorves.
author: Robert P.

description: Always great food and drinks here. Had the veggie dumplings, nan, chowmien and it was all great. Was super crowded with RSA still got seats
author: Amar R.

description:
It's hard to find a decent Asian food at financial district. I am very happy to find this gem! I am really enjoyed the atmosphere and services, especially they served the warm Ginger cookies at the end of my lunch. Yum! 
Here is the recommendation for the food, Corn Fritters, Tamarind & Hoisin Spare Ribs, Butternut Squad Dumplings, and green papaya salad.
author: Happy R.

description:
1:30 pm on a Monday for lunch and they were out of three items including all burgers and gingerbread cookies- both of which I was looking forward to trying. Kind of unacceptable in my opinion. They did have a decent lunch deal which included choice of an appetizer and entree for $24. Three of us split two orders:

Appetizers:
green papaya & cucumber salad- refreshingly light + sweet and sour
butternut squash dumplings- definitely a highlight of the meal, incredibly rich so you don't need more than 2 or 3 per person, would order these again in a heartbeat

Entree:
chicken satay- def needed extra peanut sauce but one we got that it was pretty flavorful
pad thai- tad bit spicy for my personal taste but still delicious

Would have loved to finish the meal with a gingerbread cookie which was highly recommended from someone who previously dined here but they ran out. Still bitter.

Also, our server was a bit inattentive & awkward, we had to flag him down multiple times anytime we needed anything. Maybe it was just a fluke considering how many great reviews this restaurant has.
author: Amanda R.

description: Underwhelming at best. After so much good food in this neighborhood -- so much cheaper, this was a huge disappointment for the last night. The flavors were just not there. We had calamari and the papaya salad. The best item we tried was the duck buns.
author: Deb K.

description:
I came here for happy hour with my friend. She loves this place with good reason. 

+ Not crowded for a Friday
+ Fast service
+ yummy oysters for $1
+ dumplings - the sauce was very flavorful
+/- pupu platter - the fritters (a bit very salted) and taro chips were yummy; all the meats (chicken, sliders, ribs) were kind of dry
author: Margaret R.

description: It used to be a good place maybe like 15 yrs ago ? It has loosen its qualify and food has seriously gone downhill.  I'm here ago after 15yrs and seriously it's overpriced and it's not a worth dining experience.  ahi tuna was total failure. Beef slider was a huge disappointment. Satay platter was good but $18 , I think it's overpriced.  The only good note was the Thai basil vodka cook tail drink I had. Other than that. Seriously. I won't be back for years for sure.
author: Candy S.

description:
We hadn't been here for several years and decided to give it a try. Hosting friends from out-of-state, we wanted a restaurant that was unique, as well as delicious. E & O fit the bill on both counts.

Although there were many interesting dishes on the dinner menu, the reviews of the Happy Hour menu were so glowing, we had to try it. (Note: be sure to mention your desire to eat from the Happy Hour menu when you make your reservation. If you are seated in the 'restaurant', you can't get it. Even though the tables in the 'bar' are just as nice, and literally right next to each other. Go figure.)

We ended up getting two pupu platters, which provided a huge variety of appetizers--enough for a meal! We ordered two of these for four of us and had plenty to eat. The platters were $24 each at Happy Hour, included everything from chicken satay to tuna sashimi, corn fritters, and lots of other goodies. Totally worth it!!

Also, during Happy Hour, wine (and Champagne!) was only $6 a glass. Many wines, beers, and cocktails to choose from.

Go at Happy Hour and enjoy!
author: Susan S.

description:
We go to downtown SF every year during Christmas time to take in all the lights, festivities, and have a nice dinner with the fam. We found the good reviews of E&O on Yelp, our kids loved the pictures of the Pupu platter, and we were all looking forward to having a great meal here after a long day of shopping and sight seeing.

We had a reservation for the via OpenTable for 5:45 pm to take advantage of the 3-6pm M-Sat Happy Hour specials. We were promptly seated when we arrived a little early at 5:35pm, and we were so looking forward to ordering the Pupu platter from the happy hour menu.

Here's where our evening fell apart. Our waitress told us Happy Hour specials could NOT be had in the dining area and we had to be seated in the Bar/Lounge area. I told her it doesn't say that on their website or Open Table but she just shrugged her shoulders and said we have 2 choices...go back to the front and wait for a table in the bar or order from the regular dinner menu (which didn't have the Pupu Platter). 

The kids were hungry so I nicely asked if she could make an exception and get us the Pupu platter (which our kids really wanted to try) from the bar as an appetizer and we will simply order from their regular menu for our main meal. 

She wouldn't do it and said it is not their policy to serve happy hour specials in their main dining room. Ok, I understand what she was trying to say but it doesn't say that anywhere on their website or OpenTable do how are customers supposed to know that? 

Furthermore, you have a customer who was ready to drop $200 dollars on a meal at your restaurant and you can't make one exception to let them order a $15 Pupu platter to as appetizer???  Makes no sense whatsoever. 

Because our kids were so disappointed we simply just got up and left. On our way out I mentioned the situation to the front desk hostess and she just shrugged her shoulders. 

Never coming back here, ever.
author: Alvin C.

description: We stumbled upon this gem of a restaurant while strolling around Union Square in San Francisco. It was past 2 pm but the place was bustling. Food is excellent, love the ambiance and chic Asian decor. We had the share a meal deal for $29...a bit on the pricey side considering the small portions but that's more like a San Francisco thing. I heard they have a good Happy Hour so definitely we will come back.
author: Ann C.

description:
I've been to this place many times, all of them being business meals. Food is delicious and more fulfilling than you think. I don't like leaving food on my plate, but I had to do it every time I ate at E&O. 

The atmosphere is better for a dinner rather than lunch. Lighting is somewhat low, and table are super close so careful what you say :)

My biggest complaint is about waiters. They come literally every 3 minutes and ask if everything's OK. First 3 times are fine. However, when you're in the middle of a conversation and someone keeps interrupting you when you haven't eaten anything since the last time they asked it starts to get annoying. Please let me eat and enjoy my night with my guests!
author: Cansu K.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE!
So we were stuck at our Hotel room on a Sunday deciding what to do with our lives little more exciting then watching TV, then of course Yelped a cool bar with a good menu........this place popped up!

We walked in pretty dead for a Sunday (which was perfect for us) we sat at the bar..........bartender so awesome and knowledgeable about his alcohol (always a plus) I love top notch bar, where they do not look at you in a weird way when you ask for  XO cognac! 
The starters on their menue were just amazing! We tried the mushroom soup and the shitaky mushroom dumplings! So good we ordered two of those!  Really cozy, trendy and friendly establishment! Will definetly be back!
author: Ray K.

description:
I don't know if I am having an identity crisis at this age or if they are. This place really is a true definition of Asian Fusion as the menu items range from naan breads to kimchi potstickers to pad thai...

Came here for the happy hour with coworkers, so I can't speak for a true dining experience. However, I do have to say I think their happy hour deals are pretty worth! We actually got everything on the happy hour menu. My memory is little blurry combined with the drinks, but I do remember we thoroughly enjoyed the dollar oysters, dumplings, corn fritters and sliders. Only thing on the menu we didn't like was the Ahi Tuna Tartare as the tuna seemed not fresh.

As for drinks, they were just okay, but can't complain about $6 cocktails in downtown/fidi.

Recommended? Definitely! Come for the HH M-F 3-6pm.
author: Solongo B.

description: New Englanders in San Fran for just three days, and we ate here twice!  We shared Pad Thai and chicken skewers the first evening (and an amazing rosemary gin drink); and then took friends back a couple nights later. We were staying close by, so it was an easy and convenient walk.
author: Amy H.

description:
