On the website, E&O professes to "match our passion for food with our commitment to excellent service." That wasn't the case for my friend and me. In other words, we did not get the service that was described. Far from it. We do not plan to return to E&O, despite the GM's promise that we would be "well taken care of" if we returned. I'm just not comfortable giving my money to a business that treated us so poorly, and acknowledged us only when they wanted to collect payment.
author: Alison R.

description:
A and I stopped here for an early dinner after going to the SFMOMA since they were open during the weird restaurant void time of 2:30pm-5:30pm and didn't have a wait for non-happy hour seating. I wish we had kept walking. This place is very clearly aimed at tourists and FiDi happy hours which is fine, but the food should also be good.

To E&O's credit, I will say that the restaurant space itself is refined and comfortable. It felt very modern and upscale so kudos to the interior designers. I also think the service was really friendly, though I do personally dislike places that only have happy hour in their bar area but whatever, that is the management's choice. 

I initially was pretty excited about this meal because I am trying to eat a low carb diet before my beach vacation and E&O had some healthy options that sounded great. I opted for the Grilled Steelhead ($26) and A (who clearly is not concerned with being in shape for this vacation) had the E&O Wood Grilled Burger ($16). If I am being entirely honest, I was definitely hangry and should have ordered an appetizer but, for $26 and from watching some of the other plates come out, I thought I would have more than enough to eat. When they brought out our entrees, I almost laughed. The piece of fish was super small and the veggies served with it were not sufficiently sized at all. The menu description says its served with "hot and sour" broth, which apparently to the chefs at E&O means just wetting the bottom of the plate. When I took a bite, my laughter turned to rage because it tasted awful. Almost like throw up and the coconut relish did not work AT ALL. I devoured it, given my hunger, but I was very very angry about it. I didn't say anything to the waiter since I ate it all and didn't want it to look like I just wanted a free meal but I was definitely not a happy camper. A seemed to like his burger well enough but, given my diet, I could not try it so I don't know how much I believe him or if he was just trying to calm me down. Needless to say, I would definitely not go back, especially given its proximity to Chinatown, North Beach and other Union Square establishments.
author: Carrie W.

description: The appetizers were better than the main courses. The corn fitters and ceviche were good. The steak and potatoes weren't really Asian, and need salt. Most of their main dishes needed salt.
author: Phuong H.

description: Checked out reviews and decided to try this restaurant. Very nice place. Cool vibe. Attentive staff. Ordered the corn fritters--amazing!  I didn't want to share. Dipping sauce very good as well.  I had the chicken satay, my date had the chow mein noodles.  Portion size was substantial. Both were excellent.
author: Ccwriter V.

description:
Really not sure about why this place got such great reviews. But I came here for lunch and first noticed that the tables in the restrooms were a little dirty. But I didn't mind to wait to try the food.

i'm not one to judge a book by its cover, however none of the food was impressive. We got the pu pu platter and the butternut squash dumplings - it was below mediocre, unfortunately :/

The only extra star I give is for great service, the waitress Liza (or Lisa, not sure) was sweet and quick to be super helpful!

My assumption is this place is more
for drinks and nighttime mingling - NOT for lunch though, folks :(
author: Liza P.

description:
We came here this evening with a group of four and we're throughly pleased with our meal! Easy to get to location and the atmosphere was Asian inspired tying back to the Asian fusion cuisine. 

Our friends were happy with their Restaurant Week options including a three course meal with sizable portions and had leftovers to take home.

We went ahead and ordered from the a la carte menu and here are our thoughts:

- Butternut squash dumplings: so so good. Served with a delicious panang curry. Must get.
- Indonesian corn fritters: if you love corn, you will love this dish. If not, might not be your thing as its literally fried corn.
- Burger with kimchi, aoili, added fried egg, bacon and white cheddar served with fries: I was really craving a burger but it didn't quite hit the spot. Not sure why; perhaps the beef was not flavorful enough.
- Drunken noodles: smaller portion compared to our other dishes but also nothing special.
- Chicken dumplings: were a OK. Nothing to write home about.
- goat cheese salad: was very fresh and the cheese was nice.

Service was really friendly, accommodating and patient. Five stars there! 

Overall enjoyed the experience but probably wouldn't come here a second time.
author: Christine L.

description: Exceptionally different type of SF dining.  Great lounge during lunch, happy hour and dinner.  Eclectic clientele....can be romantic for two AND works very well for a group.  Many different and delicious items both as appetizers and main courses.  The corn fritters are a favorite!!
author: Dave L.

description:
The hub and I went here on our anniversary without reservation, and luckily we were able to get a table.

We received excellent services, and the food tasted really good especially the tropical salad (Sorry, I forgot the actual name).

We will be back soon!
author: Holly T.

description: We went to this place in a large group of 18 people. Had made reservations in advance. The servers were friendly. We ordered a  bottle of wine and lot of cocktails, all of them were really nice. The food was really good too, although not as spicy as we expected it to be. The taste was really good. We gave them 6 credit cards for payment and they went ahead with that payment too, which was quite nice. We were celebrating 2 birthdays, so the server even got us a small piece of cake which was nice. Overall a very good experience and would recommend for large groups.
author: Roma M.

description: Absolutely fantastic. The flavors are amazing. I know have a favorite papaya salad!!!
author: Eric H.

description:
I have to agree with Kevin B. on this one - rediscovering restaurants is the best. Especially old favorites. 

There used to be an E&O in Larkspur as well as in San Jose, but the original one still remains, close to Union Square. This location has a unique feeling, like you're being transported to an exclusive nightclub/restaurant in a modern Asian city. I love Asian fusion restaurants and the dishes here don't disappoint. 

We started with the salt and pepper calamari and the sweet chili dipping sauce that it came with was the perfect combination of tangy and sweet. Next, we shared the Satay Platter (my long time favorite from the Marin location) and the Indonesian fried rice. The satay platter came with a mix of chicken, steak, prawn, and portobello mushroom skewers. My favorite two were the steak and mushroom ones, which were surprisingly similar in taste, yet obviously completely different in texture. The fried rice was also a success.

My only note for improvement would have to be about the service. The servers are friendly, but seemed a little overwhelmed with the amount of tables they had to cover.

After an afternoon of shopping, this is now one of my favorite places to end the day. Delicious food in a prime location.
author: Shira W.

description: Great trendy, upscale spot. Delicious Asian fusion menu. Chow Mein was so delicious I went back the next day to have it again! Sat at the bar both visits and received fantastic service from Chris.
author: S B.

description: Had the worst dinner experience at E&O Kitchen this week. I am not one to complain or bad mouth a restaurant typically but this one really warrants it. Made a reservation and showed up at this place at 8:45. The hostess seated us and there seemed to be a lot of tables around us. We understand that the restaurant was busy but nobody came to check in on us even after we tried to flag someone down for 25 minutes. The waitress literally walked around and did not even acknowledge us - that is definitely not how you treat a paying customer. We finally flagged down the hostess and asked us if someone can help or if we can move to the bar. She had some words with the waitress and came back herself to take down our order. Nobody ever came to apologize for the abysmal treatment we were definitely not warranted. After we quickly placed our order the bad service continued. The waitress seemed to be taking everyone else's order fine and again never even came up to us even apologize for ignoring us. The food that was brought to our table was just literally dumped on our table - no customary ' how is everything' or ' do you need anything'. The pork and kimchi potstickers were greasy and awful. The beet drink was basically beet water. So in short the service was awful and the food abominable. I have no idea how this place is so popular. I would never recommend this place
author: Smrithika A.

description: Went on double date and we all tried a few plates. Deviled eggs were exceptiOne, satay sampler was a perfect meat/protein selection along with the Indonesian fried rice. Had the sliders for appetizer and I wish we had ordered more. Only thing I didn't like was sponge cake dessert with some ice cream filling. The ambiance is great! Young, loud, fun and simultaneously intimate and romantic. The Asian fusion menu flows into the decor throughout. Overall the best dining experience we had while visiting San Francisco for a week.
author: Maytee P.

description: E&O has an amazing happy hour dollar oysters and dumplings, $6 Moscow Mules and other cocktails and $4 beers. A beautiful bar with hip music that's not too loud or too crowded but lively enough so you feel like you're in a hopping place. Slow service sometimes but always friendly.
author: David A R.

description: Very cool place for lunch. Sat at the bar and ordered a salad. The most kindest bartender is Sergio. He made me the best Margarita with that included a Serrano chile.
author: Ofd W.

description:
In response to Akop p, thank you for being in denial and assuming that I do not understand how service works at Eo kitchen.  Even briefly reading through other reviews, I can see that other diners have had the same experience of the server not being around and not doing anything. So just to clarify, when I was seated I am sure that my server was not "obviously very busy" since the restaurant was not even 1/4 filled at the time. That's when she was gone. She only had one other table of 2 diners in her section since the whole time I was there the only parties she approached were that party and my party. Yes, I kept my eyes on her the whole time because I was so surprised she still had a job and the food was unable to capture my attention.

Also, I work in the food hospitality industry so when I dine I always pay attention to service and I know what a busy server looks like. 
When she did return to her section she stood around having nothing to do for a long time before disappearing off the entire floor again.  I know the wonderful hardworking bus boy was very busy since he was clearing plates off all tables and I could see him doing his best trying to hustle. 
 
Anyway, from your response I am sure you will take absolutely nothing from my feedback. May I suggest that you find out who the busboy is and promote him? It looks really bad from the outside when a certain minority race are all employed as busboys at your establishment and working much hard than the rest of the staff who have better positions. 

To summarize everything - service is horrible unless you get your busboy to help you while he is clearing your dishes. Food and drinks not worth consuming. Plenty of better options in the area.
author: Vicious G.

description: Although the pan-asian/fusion trend has wained, the food here is flavorful and well-prepared.  Great for sharing.  Steak satay was super tender and the pad thai was nicely very light on the noodles.  Green beans were great.
author: Mike S.

description: Happy hour 3 to 5 my new go to. Tasty, quick and not expensive. Eat at the bar. The drinks are yummy.
author: Cecilia D.

description:
Started out at 5 stars but by the end I had to pull a star off.  Still, worth going.  Love the interior - deceivingly large and it was crowded by 7 PM on a Monday.  The menu is pretty awesome. I had the Chicken Satay to start and my wife had the pork and kimchi (I think) potstickers.  Both were outstanding.  I am a Satay fan, and this was both the best chicken and best peanut sauce I have ever had.

For meals, my wife had the braised lamb noodle.  She thought it was fantastic.  I had the burger on the corn fritters.  Mine was good, but I wouldn't order it again.  My wife loved the corn fritters, but I was not a fan.

What pulled this from 5 to 4 stars was how unfriendly our waitress was and how clueless she was.  Service was not up to expectations.
author: Marc F.

description: This place is outstanding!!  We had such a great experience on our last trip to San Francisco, that I'm glad we got to enhance that trip with dinner at E&O.  We had no issues at all with our dinner reservations.  The setting and ambiance of the restaurant is fantastic, perfect for an intimate couple or groups.  The menu is small,  but the food is phenomenal. They have a full liquor bar with wide selection.  The food servings are made for couples, and again I can't say enough on how great the food was.  I ordered Pad Thai with a special fried rice that was top shelf.  I would definitely go back without question, and I would recommend this place to anyone that visits the Union Square San Francisco area.
author: Edwin M.

description: Everything we tried was excellent!   The wood fired edamame was so flavorful.  The chow mein was a large portion and delicious.  The Indonesian fried rice was good and had a nice spice.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Christy H.

description: I had the pork sandwich and loved it.  My kids loved the food as well.  Friendly and attentive staff that sat us immediately, filled my soda every time it got low and made sure we had everything we needed and that our orders came out right.  Atmosphere was nice as well. Located in the union Square area.
author: Peter F.

description: We ordered the wrong things and were ready to go when Kelsey stopped by and turned our night around. She ordered some dishes for us. Ahi tuna and chicken spring rolls rocked our world. The maple bourbon cocktail and craft beers were the perfect compliment. Brittney gave us some great entertainment recommendations for the rest of our trip. Yeah Andy for great service. We will recommend to our friends.
author: Trisha L.

description: Pleasantly surprised! One of the few kitchens open after 9 on a weeknight. I was expecting maybe mediocre but honestly every dish was well seasoned, well prepared, and the service was excellent!! We had short ribs - yum!!!! Butternut Squash ravioli in a sort of coconut curry broth, beet salad and the black cod. Everything was super tasty and we would definitely scarf here again on fried chicken night!!
author: Liz T.

description: This place offers excellent food. Wonderful attention to detail. Perfect preparation of my shrimp, beef, and chicken. Nice upscale vibe! Decent service! Nice spot for Asian cuisine.
author: David S.

description: My bf built me up based of remembrance from when it was E & O Trading.  We went for happy hour, so we got lots of food  drink for the price.  The food was good, not amazing. We had the pupu platter, which was good for variety.  Lamb naan was awesome.  Bf did not like his oysters.  Dumplings, were good but too sweet for me.  Took home some ginger cookies and I ate 3 on the way back to the hotel while bar hopping.  I enjoyed the sutter punch and blushing geisha.  Service from the bartender wasn't attentive enough for my bf, but I got noticed and served in a timely manner.  Atmosphere wasn't too noisy, so you could have a conversation.  We're from out of town and won't make it a priority to return on future visits.
author: Rhonda L.

description: That meal was awesome!  Loved the mushroom dumplings and the lime in the coconut desert was amazing!  Delicious.  Staff was wonderful as well.
author: annonymous l.

description: Best restaurant in the area !! Food is delicious and we had a wonderful server Ranesha. The corn fritters and butternut squash dumplings to start and the satay for an entree. Will be back to try the rest of the menu soon.
author: Melanie H.

description: This place rocks! The happy hour (starts at 3!) is awesome. The restaurant is nice and we sat ourselves at the bar right away. We started with Moscow Mules ($6!) which were really good, I liked the ginger beer they used. From there, we got the corn fritters, ahi tuna tartare, spare rib, and two butternut squash dumplings. All the food was great, especially the spare rib! We ended with one more Moscow Mule which was disappointing :( it tasted completely different (and waaay sweeter) than the last one. Maybe he forgot the vodka! But other than that, a good experience! They messed up on our check at the end but happily changed it.
author: Julia M.

description: Busy place but really good food! Went there as part of a business meeting and was surprised by the excellent preparation, ambience, and service!
author: A M.

description: The service and ambiance were both excellent. The high point for us were the butternut squash dumplings. A delicious, fresh, and inventive fusion item. We also enjoyed the shiitake and fried  kimchi-pork dumplings; however, they both swam in an overly vinegary sauce which my companion did not mind, but which I found took away from the delicate flavours of the dumplings. The weak points of this meal were the satay platter and phat thai. The platter was overpriced for the quality of food 28$). While the ingredients were very fresh, the sauces were amateur and disappointing. The chicken and shrimp skewers were also dry. The phat thai was also vinegary with too much sauce. This could have been such a great dish, given the freshness of the ingredients used. Instead, it was one of the worst phat thais I have had anywhere. I would go back for the dumplings, however!
author: Sue G.

description: ONE STAR for this place, we came for a quick bite. Be thankful you have good bartenders who are attentive and courteous to your customer. Cause the Asian gentleman and two young ladies in your entrance desk SUCKS, they don't even greet at arrivals nor at departure. Not even a thank you, mediocres!
author: Charlie A.

description: My hubby and I had an amazing dinner last night at this Asian Fusion place. We couldn't decide what to order, and were leaning towards the black cod, but when asking our server what his favorite meal on the menu was, he immediately said, "oh, the lamb with the handcut pasta is my favorite meal" and once we read the description - done - that's what we ordered. From the handcut pasta to the braised and slow roasted lamb shanks along with the amazing sauce and veggies, I literally wanted to climb into the bowl and lick it clean. We'll be back! Beyond delicious. KUDOS to the chef who prepared this meal. SPECTACULAR! Go if you haven't tried it yet and if you're a lamb fan. We'll definitely be back!
author: Roma B.

description: What a place! Chris behind the bar was fantastic, even though he he place was packed! The New ad Thai and Shaking Beef were sons of the best Asian I've ever had, and the Moscow Mules were the perfect compliment (plenty of ginger, not too sweet). They were lovely about accommodating my gluten-free dinner companion, and serving CEO was outstanding. I will certainly be back!
author: Colleen F.

description:
$18-Pad Thai was yummy
$12-Spring rolls, it literally looked like 1 roll split into 3 pieces :-( 
$16- Ahi Tartare- alright
.10- bag charge the norm I think
SF employee mandates $1.38 not sure, tip?

Total cost: $51.63
author: Cella S.

description:
Just left happy hour here (3-6) we got a bunch of different things but I would highly recommend the $1 oysters, $1 dumplings, the naan, and the spare ribs. We also got a few different drinks, my favorites were the vodka ginger (basically a mule), the prickly tequila and the rum vanilla (all $6 cocktails). 
Our server seemed to be very busy from the moment we walked in, we waited approximately 13 min to order (where we ordered drinks and all of our food at once) and waited a total of 25 min from the time we sat down to the time we got our drinks. 
The restaurant manager did her best to "take care of us" and comped one of our items ($3.50) on an over $50 tab for happy hour apps.
We were very understanding that he was busy but I felt like if they had just communicated that we could have figured something else out; i.e. Sat at the bar, in another section or went somewhere else. 
That being said the food was awesome and the drinks were really good for $6 cocktails.
author: Lindsay M.

description: Yum. Came for SF restaurant week. One of the best freshest tasting pad thai dishes I've ever had. Ahi tuna tarter was good, not great: Fish quality was good but not a dish to write home about as as tuna tartare goes. Amazing cauliflower side tho
author: Tanya S.

description: Amazing happy hour in SF! With so much to choose from, I'm so glad we came here. The corn fritters are so good, it will make you want to slap your mama. My boyfriend couldn't get enough of the short ribs and the $6 tequila prickly pear drink is amazing.
author: Michelle M.

description:
Can't beat $1 oysters. They were so fresh and so delicious. 
The dumplings were mediocre (however, the sauce was yummy). The short rib slider was really tasty. 
Excellent Moscow miles too!
Nice ambiance & great service.
author: Tina H.

description: Corn fritter burger is a must do!!!  The butternut squash dumplings you can do without.  Seriously never tried anything like the corn fritter burger in my life. So many different flavors. The menu is a bit all over the place, but great food!
author: Nichole B.

description: Delicious food, perfect happy hour, reasonable prices which is hard to find in the bay and the staff is very welcoming! I will be back!
author: Jean G.

description:
Oh Jesus oh god oh my damn oh balls this was good. Thanks to the happy hour menu we ate and drank an otherwise very expensive meal for only about $100. To include: Oysters with a kimchi horseradish cocktail sauce; the most tender amazing spare ribs; dumplings - they looked to have been boiled like raviolis and served in a green chili oil and cream sauce - we thought at first they wouldn't be very good but they were amazing; pulled pork sliders - my wife had to pick off the generous serving of cilantro but they were otherwise one of her favorites; yakitori, a table favorite , beautiful and smoky; Tuna tartare, my favorite. I think I'm leaving off a few things. It was mind blowing.

To illustrate how every item was perfectly sourced and prepared - Even the taro straws were perfect; crispy and perfectly salted.

And I can write several more paragraphs about the craft cocktails.

The waiter was maybe just a bit inattentive. The bartender was Johnny on the doggone spot though. First rate experience!
author: David G.

description: Great happy hour, fine drinks, and a great lunch meeting spot. Excellent ambiance, good service, and delicious fried rice.
author: Bethany H.

description: Great restaurant with a decent service (depends on when you go there, lunches are very busy- slow service). Some of my favorite dishes - mushroom dumpling, corn fretters (their speciality!), Puppaya salad, Pad Thai and off course the ginger cookies (super yum!). They have a very interesting cocktails menu as well. I also love their house ginger ale.
author: Anisha Y.

description: Fabulous!  Friend & I ordered the most desorption that wasn't on the menu ... huge bowl,of piping hot ginger with gobs of shiitake mushrooms, all for $8!  Then we shared really tasty pad Thai.  With tip we each paid $22, an incredible bargain.  Clean, friendly, bustling, just perfect on a rainy night.  Arrived at 5:30 but I think it was all filled by 6.
author: NANCY K.

description:
This is a true gem near the Dragon Gate. It's best to eat family or tapas style, and is very affordable with great quality food. We loved everything, especially the tuna tar tare and the Indonesian fried rice. Food varies in spiciness, and you can crank up the spicy or mild it out. 

Wait staff was well informed, attentive, and not over bearing. It took about 15 minutes for them to put a table together for 6 people. But they had a seated waiting area, which was perfect after walking around all day. 

They even provided entertainment for the 1 year old kiddo in our group. They gave us a package of wax sticks that kept her entertained (and quiet) for over an hour. So much more creative than crayons.
author: Kate V.

description:
This place is awesome! My partner and I decided to treat ourselves during their happy hour and I could not get over how delicious everything tasted! The oysters, the cocktails, the pu pu platter...it was all great! It's easy to get drunk there with the discounted cocktails :P

The waiter who served us was also very very friendly and super awesome! I accidentally ordered a chicken satay in addition to our pu pu platter and he waived the charge. This is the epitome of great food and great service!!
author: Nicole G.

description: The food was ok. The sauce was a little to heavy . In my opinion , the food is over price for the amount of portion we received . We had the squash and mushroom dumplings . The phat Thai didn't have enough noodles, very saucy . The service was poor. Our water glasses were not refilled until we received the bill. Probably will not come back next time we visit the area!
author: Ferdinand T.

description: I ordered the flatiron steak but its on the very salty side due to the kim che sauce. I did have a bite of the shaky beef and that was very tinder and juicy, i would recommend that if you wanted to order steak. Its  a very trendy atmosphere to lounge and chat. I gave it a 3 star due to the flatiron steak i Ordered. Its not worth the price in my opinion.
author: Bernardo S.

description: I really wanted to give this place 3.5 stars. The food is ok but in San Francisco that doesn't cut it.  Staff was nice I just wouldn't visit again not the top of my list
author: Jessica S.

description: E&O is us a great happy hour spot to meet up with your girls for tasty craft cocktails and oysters .  This place does get crowded but that's because everyone loves socializing here and the atmosphere is great.
author: Crystal B.

description:
Before even sitting down my experience here was ruined by the hostess. 

She was working around 4pm on Friday the 27th.

Not polite. Not friendly. 

Rude and even ruder facial expressions.

Consider replacing her
author: Nick W.

description: Love this place!! Me and my best friend have been coming here since they were previously called the trading company! Huge place with a nice ambiance. My favorite is there happy hour! Good deals on the drinks and food is good to! My favorite is the sliders and the $1 oysters
author: Leah P.

description:
A hop, skip and a jump away from our Grand Hyatt hotel and what a find.  Wife and I went there for dinner on a Friday night and with reservations got seated right away.  Our table was upstairs which was significantly quieter and more cozy than downstairs.

We ordered the Satay Sampler, butternut squash dumplings, corn fritters and Long Life House Noodles.  Everything was great esp. the dumplings and fritters. 

Service was ok...waiter seemed pre-occupied but still got our order right and drinks were flowing.  Seemed like he was engaged until we ordered just one entree to share and then we "lost" him...just my gut feeling.

All in all a nice restaurant with an interesting menu.  Will definitely return and recommend this place.  From all the other Yelp reviews it seems Happy Hour is a good time to be here.
author: Kahai D.

description: Came here with my husband and brother who took the Bart over from Berkeley. We wanted a nice place that wouldn't break the bank completely, and we found it. Very nice ambiance and amazing food. We order a bottle of the Malbec (only one on the menu)... Great taste and very reasonably priced. For food we had the shrimp satay, chicken curry, shaking beef, and pad Thai. All were amazing! I loved the pickled veggies that came with the satay. Our server, tommy, was really a gem. He is the epitome of what it means to provide service. He knew what we wanted before we wanted it and he took really good care of us. Any time I'm in SF I'll be going to E & O and asking for him!
author: Neda S.

description: Their happy hour is AMAZING! Pad Thai to die for! Their Sliders are just as fantastic! Great ambiance! Definitely recommend to someone looking for a good dinner and drinks.
author: Mariana N.

description: This has been our go to spot for years when visiting "THE CITY"...........unfortunately, we cannot continue this tradition for only a 4 star experience......that would be ridiculous if your go to spot was not a 5 star in your book.  The last few times the exceptional service has been reduced to good and the food and spirits reduced from excellent to standard.  Although we have these feelings, the establishment still deserves a shot to impress you.  A bit sad for us, in a way.
author: Pete M.

description:
Great drinks and solid food. The restaurant is located on bustling Sutter Street, right next to the conveniently located Stockton/Sutter garage. I had a memorable dinner with a couple friends at E&O recently and just can't stop talking about the tea deviled eggs! 

Their popular Indonesian Corn Fritters made a tasty (and very crunchy) appetizer. They have actual chunks of whole corn kernels and the majority of the fritter is composed of the kernels versus flour. Deep fried and delicious. I really liked the Roasted Beet Salad too. It's a refreshing dish - slightly sweet and super simple. My Black Cod main dish was AMAZING. I vaguely recall doing a little dance in my chair. 

Plates cleared. Dessert menu came. I tried to push it away but a few moments later i was sharing a Bananamisu. I love bananas and i love coffee. What is not to love!! Espresso soaked ladyfingers and a banana mascarpone mousse is a heavenly combo.

I'd come in much more often if i didn't live across the city. It's an awesome space for happy hour post work with coworkers.. definitely suitable for an evening out with friends... but just as fitting for an intimate dinner date.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Dinner in Union Square the other weekend was simply awesome. I'd go for a 4.5 star experience. 

Lucky for us too, not a lot of diners. More attention, better service, faster food turn-around. Have wanted to try for a while. Took advantage of DAT"s last evening for a spin in the City.

Bursting with flavor. Everything that came out was nearly perfect. We fawned and swooned over the papaya salad. Duck imperial rolls were generous and well fried. Presentations were great. Cocktails strong and yum as well.

When the steelhead came out (both wanting the same), amazing flavor!!!! Perfectly cooked trout, and roasted roots....Portions were generous, and we even went for those corn fritters. Sadly, though, I thought the sauce was equally as impressive as the corn. Not crunchy enough, and needed an element or two, in my opinion.

Desserts here were such a treat. Totally delicious mango panna cotta and banamisu. We just could not finish them.. shame too.

Great first time dining here....they apparently have a nice HH and even late bites menu as well.
author: Jana C.

description:
Long standing Asian fusion restaurant with a nice modern bar, ample space to host groups and room for happy hour. Came by for happy hour 3-6pm on a Friday. Wasn't too busy, managed to find a bar table after a few minutes.

Cocktails are $6 for happy hour instead of $11, the four offerings are on the sweeter side, served in a low ball glass when they should probably be served in a high ball glass. While delicious, I thought the drinks were on the weaker side especially for the Sutter Punch and Blushing Geisha. Also had a E&O Mojito that was okay. Beer is $4, selection of four includes either Anchor Steam beers, one pilsner and then Sapporo. Wine was $6, choice between sparkling, white, or red.

Bar Bites:
$1 oysters available!
Wood Oven Naan ($4) - tasted not very fresh or fluffy, like it came out of a microwave, skip!
Tamarind & hoisin pork spare rib ($2.5/rib) - bit too sweet, felt like it was made for American tastebuds.
Beef short rib slider ($4) - tender, almost fall off the bone, but still a bit too sweet.
Chicken Satay ($2/stick) - juicy, came with a peanut sauce that was good & pickled veggies.
Steak Satay ($3/stick) - one piece, medium rare steak on a stick.

Thought the bar bites were okay overall, it's pretty much Asian fusion for American taste preferences. Maybe their full entrees are way better but I'm a bit wary.

Decent happy hour overall but not one of my top spots around Union Square.
author: Steven C.

description: Stopped in to E&O for a small snack at their Happy Hour.  They had a great selection of food and drinks from 3 PM until 6 PM.  I had .5 dozen of the raw oysters and four butternut squash dumplings in a red curry sauce.  Both were magnificent and had a tall 21st amendment sully beer to wash it down.  The place was packed and would definitely go back to try something else.
author: Bradley B.

description:
I haven't been here since it was E&O Trading Company. But a friend and I decided to get together for happy hour and she picked E&O. Got there a little after 5:30pm. Seats were easy to find which is always a plus! I don't really remember what E&O used to look like, but it seems like the bar area is a little bigger and the design of the place a little more modern?

Happy hour cocktails and wine are $6 while beer is $4. Oysters and dumplings $1 each plus a variety of bar bites starting at $2. I'm not a huge mixed drink fan, but decided to try the Moscow mule. Surprisingly I liked it! The mint and ginger beer made it super refreshing and it wasn't too sweet! We decided to get the pupu platter since I love variety and appetizer samplers are always a fav of mine. I really liked the pickled veggies that came with the chicken skewers. They had a nice spicy kick to them and anyone that knows me knows I love spice! A low point however were the ribs. They were super tough and stringy. Almost like eating jerky. No falling off the bone here! All in all I had a good time. Happy hour prices are reasonable and I would like to come back to try the $1 oysters and dumplings.
author: Elena N.

description: The food was alright for the price, but the service was terrible. It took about 40 minutes for the food to arrive at the table, and we had forgotten to mention that one of the guests has a peanut allergy and the server scolded us for not reminding them earlier. I asked for water, and I had been waiting for about 15 minutes for a server to look over at our table or stop by-however, no one came. So I asked the hostess for some water and she was incredibly rude and said, "I'm not a server here, but here's your water." Our server rarely paid attention to our table and all in all it wasn't a great experience at this restaurant. Definitely overrated.
author: Alexa T.

description:
Even better than we anticipated! Every dish captured unique flavors and perfect balance of texture, spice, and freshness.

Gorgeous, calming environment.
Terrific wine list (Thank you! finally in an Asian restaurant!)
Salt & Pepper Calamari has a delicious sweetness in the spice mix that forced us to eat every last leg!
Every veggie dish and those Drunken Noodles tasted better than any Chinatown options we've had, beyond a doubt.
Their Corn Fritters are FAMOUS for good reason- 2 HUGE pieces, these are not typical dumplings... the fresh corn keeps them crunchy and amazing!

Our lovely server Sasha couldn't have been more delightful, permanent smile, great recommendations, and charming personality.
GM Akop steers a very smooth ship - he's as nice as can be! Surely his direction and guidance help maintain the warm, Zen atmosphere that makes E & O so COOL.
Thanks to all for such a perfect dining experience!!! We'll send our friends!
author: Elaine A.

description:
First, let me start by saying props to E&O for taking reservations for a party of 8 on a Saturday. I don't know how many places my friend had to call in order to get reservations for her birthday but this place definitely pulled through. The ambience is perfect for a celebration or a date. It has a good balance of sophistication but modern. The funky thing is that the bathroom is at the front of the restaurant and down a flight of stairs lol. 

But most importantly the food and drinks here are amazing!!! My friend and I shared the satay platter which has a variety of 4 different satay sticks and we ordered a side of rice. The birthday girl ordered the shaking beef. All the meats were cooked to perfection and the portions are decent. Someone in our party also ordered the butternut squash dumplings and though they were tasty, the portion was very small. Also, I highly recommend the Tequila Strawberry drink.
author: Casey B.

description: Popped in for the first time the other day at the suggestion of a friend.  I like the place, the drinks, the food, and the service.  The entire experience was 5 star and would definitely recommend eating/drinking here.  Our server was Sasha and she was super sweet and nice.  She answered all of our questions and brought out our food and drinks at a good pace.  We first tried the Pu Pu Platter which features fritter bites, 2 sliders, 2 ribs, 2 chicken satay, 2 ahi tartare, and taro chips & pickled veggies. The fritters were cute, but the chicken satay skewers were the best.  I'm not a fan of peanut sauce, but their sauce was pretty good - not so peanuty.  hehe  Then I ordered the Fritter Burger for my entree.  For this one, I'd say AVOID!  It's not bad, it's just the fritters used as buns absolutely do not work as buns and the whole thing collapses and becomes really messy.  For drinks, I had the Vodka Ginger (it was ok) and the Vodka Thai Basil - which was really good!  The texture was so smooth.  I'll definitely order this one again.
author: Shaun W.

description:
We are staying, in SF financial district. We wanted a late lunch recommendation, not far from the hotel, when we arrived. A hotel employee recommended this place, if we didn't want to go into Chinatown. 
Happy Hour had started and they were still serving lunch. 
We ordered happy hour drinks and appetizers and a couple of lunch meals. 
The service seemed like it was going to be really good, when we first got there, then it slowed down. Items seemed like they had been forgotten. Water glasses were never refilled. 
It wasn't worth the amount we paid, even with some happy hour prices. 
The atmosphere is nice. The decor has a nice vibe. The tables are well spaced and of various types; booths, high tops...
The fried rice would have been perfect, with just vegetables. The pork was pretty tough. 
The chicken satay was good, as were the dumplings. Our friends had the raw oysters. They were tiny, for $1 an oyster. 
It was a Thursday.
author: Michele W.

description:
I came here with a group and to their credit, we were seated immediately in a private room. I guess that was the only space available but whatever, we didn't care. What happened next was unacceptable.
We sat down
We waited
We were asked for drink orders and when I asked if I could order food, the waiter said no, I'm just taking drinks right now. He wrote down orders on a post-it with a florescent green pen. Needless to say, most drinks never came and some were plain wrong. They were delivered by all different servers none of whom knew where to bring them or what the beverages were.
After asking THREE TIMES for the ONE iced tea we ordered, suddenly 4 of them arrived.
Once we ordered food (again taken on a post it with same green pen) the waiter came back to ask me what I had ordered. Then food came randomly--some got all of theirs and others got a few things and still others got none until we asked. Again. Order was forgotten.
The order the waiter came back to ask me about after somehow not getting it after he wrote it down. 
The service was horrendous, we weren't sure we ever got everything we ordered. Big mess. Never coming back. This place clearly cannot handle large groups. I wish they would have said, "sorry, we're really busy tonight, we cannot accommodate your group" We would have understood. We had not made a reservation, just walked in. There were plenty of other options for us. Don't promise what you can't deliver.
author: Amy V.

description:
The happy hour here is awesome and they have happy hour on Saturdays!! During happy hour we ordered the ahi tuna, corn fritters, and dumplings. The dumplings were by far the best we've had... a must try! Also, cocktails are $6 at happy hour. The Moscow Mule and Maple Old Fashioned were great. Overall happy hour gets 5 stars!!

We also ate dinner here which is was very underwhelming, hence the 3 star review. Pad Thai had a weird flavor and too many peppers that were not cooked. The Moroccan Curry Chicken was okay, not horrible but not amazing.

I would definitely go back for happy hour, but skip the dinner and try somewhere else.
author: Melissa B.

description: Yelp reviews reminded me how much I like this place. First, I love Parking next door at the Sutter Stockton Garage. Second - great place for small bites, and big drinks. Some of us use E&O as The First Date Place. Perfect set up - you can sit in cozy nooks or high tables. Love the ambiance...and Corn Fritters sound way to South-y however, they are Dreamy.
author: Kae D.

description:
We made the trek to SF on Black Friday for the International Car show and some shopping. Starving for a good meal afterwards, Yelp led us here for dinner.

I usually refer to other yelper's pics to help me make my menu selections but sadly there were few pics here, and most were of the Corn Fritters.

Ambiance 5/5: I loved the dim lighting and candles at every table. 

My GF and I made a reservation for 7pm, arrived 15 minutes early but we were seated almost immediately. I did notice there were 2 other tables of 4 open next to us , but we were placed at a smaller table for 2. Within the next 10 minutes, those 2 tables were filled by couples, also parties of 2. I am not sure if this was intentional, if the larger tables were saved for couples, or they try to fill the smaller tables first.

We ordered :

Lap Souchong Tea Deviled Eggs $2.25/ea  5/5: These are truly a beautiful, delicious masterpiece of asian fusion. All other "fusion" restaurants need to take a note of this! Deviled egg meets tea egg , seasoned perfectly, garnished with chinese bacon. I savored every bite of this egg. My mouth is watering just thinking about it.

Indonesian Corn Fritters $13 4/5 : The portion was actually quite generous for this dish. Crispy corn fritters with a unique sweet and tangy soy chilli sauce. The sauce really made this dish for me. Of course I added extra sirracha for a heat kick.

Pork Tenderloin $21 3/5: The pork was tender, nicely plated on top of black bean sauce. The grilled bok choy tasted or smelled of wax, I did not enjoy them. I am not sure if at this point our tiny table was so full of food that I was smelling the candle or if the veggies were just burned. The dish was overall tasty, but I don't see how it was a fusion dish.

Beef Short Rib Sliders $16 1/5: This dish was the only disappointment of the night. The bread was soggy, and the taro chips had no seasoning. The meat had little flavor and tasted like a wet Banh Mi (Vietnamese Sandwich). We did get this removed from our tab, so the review here is not affected by the dish. The manager also came to our table to apologize and explain this is one of the best sellers here. Unfortunately we could not agree with our experience.

Service: Our server only came to check on us once, our water carafe got switched out once as well. It was very hard to make any eye contact with any of the waitstaff, as they hustled and bustled back and forth and never looked our way. This is why I had to deduct one star. The attentiveness from wait staff was not up to par, but once we finally did flag someone down, The provided good service. 

Note: We were pretty cramped with our 4 dishes, water carafe and stinky candle. We should have asked for a larger table.

Portions: We wanted to order an additional dish, but our server said that was a good amount of food. We ordered 4 dishes and finished every last bite.

Tip for people with kiddies: They do offer wax molding hand outs for the kids. I was lucky enough to be seated at a table who had a child in their party. We we also provided some wax moldings upon request.
author: Sharon N.

description: We were looking for a good restaurant near the ACT Geary Theatre near Union Square and found this intriguing and wonderful restaurant!  We came early at 5 PM when it opened on a Sunday, and it filled up rather quickly.  This is a rather large restaurant with a long bar, and they know how to make an East Coast style martini!  The chardonnay that wife had was excellent. The menu is a curious fusion of many Asian flavors, including Japanese, Korean, Chinese, Thai/Indochina, Indonesia, Indian, and French. We ordered oysters on half shell with Kimchi sauce (very fresh, wonderful sauces), Ahi tuna tartare (truly wonderful, fresh and delicious sesame oil hinted sauce), green papaya and cucumber salad (very fresh and tasty), salt and pepper calamari (crisp and tasty).  For the main course, wife ordered the wood roasted char siu black cod, which was cooked just right with a delicate and tasty sauce, and I ordered their "famous" fritter burger, which uses corn fritters for the bun, and has many other fusion ingredients- this was huge and very tasty if a bit messy.  The service was quite friendly and professional.  This restaurant seems to be open 11 AM-11 PM except on Sundays when it opens at 5 PM.  This Sunday evening, the noise level was reasonably quiet but one can imagine that it could be very lively on other nights, especially during the happy hour, which seems quite popular according to reviews.  Our experience overall was quite positive- outstandingly delicious fusion food, excellent drinks, excellent service - we will definitely come back!
author: Hoyle L.

description: I love the food here for the happy hour but didn't care for the happy hour red wine. Should look into other choices for happy hour wine. I had a variety of appetizers from the happy hour and they were all pretty tasty except the chicken skewer (forgot the name) that was a little blend but the rest was good including the chocolate cake. Love the tuna tartare. The corn fritters were a little weird to me but the girls loved them. I also like the naan bread and the steak skewers oh and don't forget the sliders so yummy
author: Esperanza C.

description:
I LOVE E&O!
its a bit on the pricey side but you get what you pay for. the servers are vey polite and knowledgeable of the menu. parking is not bad but its in a garage and when walking to the restaurant you pass some weirdoes but its not that bad. I love their drink menu, I always get some cucumber drink. the fritters are the best and the butternut squash ravioli thingy is super yummy. don't get me started on the dessert, its all good!
definitely a great date night or special dinner/lunch place.
author: PlainJane F.

description: This was probably my worst dining experience in San Francisco to date. The food was bland and the pad Thai was dry. The breaded whatever meat that was trying to be was terrible. Soggy breaking and just terrible quality. The shrimps were very small and could imitate those terrible bagged shrimp you find in a cheap shrimp Louie. The service matched the food. No water refill by the server and no check on quality of food. I purposefully moved the bad breaded pieces to the side of the dish. Still no quality check by the server. The food runner refilled our waters but again no quality check. No quality check on check drop just basically pay and get out. With the abundance of quality Asian food i will never come back to this place. I am requesting the manager to contact me via yelp message. Pathetic....
author: Scott F.

description: Icky, icky, yuck, yuck. Came here after following the Instagram account for months. Decided that the day required cocktails and dumplings... had to wait to be seated and we were told we had to leave our table after an hour and ten minutes. We agreed despite the fact the fact the restaurant was mostly empty. When the check was presented, the waitress returned within two minutes to retrieve it despite the fact we were still eating and drinking. Maybe whatever crowd they were expecting wised up and went elsewhere. Not really the vibe I'd expect for an upscale establishment.
author: Angela P.

description:
4.5 stars

I took advantage of a Gilt City deal and I am so glad I did.  The deal was for 1 small plate, 1 order of dumplings, 1 rice or noodle dish, 1 meat or seafood dish and 2 specialty cocktails.

-Indonesian Corn Fritters: I've seen these featured on the Food Network and Cooking Channel.  These shows were right about this dish.  Great flavor.  Great crunchy texture.
-Salt & Pepper Calamari:  Since my husband & I had our daughter with us, we ordered calamari because it's one of her favorite dishes.  E&O's calamari is like potato chips - can't stop at one.
-Oxtail Dumplings: This was the only disappointing dish.
-Indonesian Fried Rice:  Decent.  Not as memorable as the other dishes but better than the Oxtail Dumplings.
-Beef Short Rib Sliders:  So juicy with just a little kick.
-Steak Satay:  Absolutely delicious.
-Devil's Food Cake:  Moist.  Not too sweet.
-Bananamisu:  Yummy but the plantain chip didn't add to much to it.

It was my first visit to E&O so I don't know what it looked like before the remodel but they did a great job.

Would I eat here again?  Most definitely...
author: Rose A.

description:
Great food, fun atmosphere, amazing drinks and friendly staff.
We stumbled across this place, but now would highly recommend it. Also, the gluten free options are amazing!
author: Nat W.

description: My mom and I went here for Happy Hour Friday night. We sat at the bar where we enjoyed the cheap appetizers and drinks. Our bartender was attentive and friendly. The music was not too loud so we could easily hear each other talk. They have a gluten free menu which was a definite bonus. My mom got the Indonesian Corn Fritters (not gluten free, fyi) and she loved them! I had edamame and a vodka with ginger beer - both were great. Next time we're in the area we'll stop by again!
author: Rosa E.

description: Chickpea fries and butternut squash ravioli- YUM! So good I wanted to go back the next day and order the same thing! The flavors were bold and blended well. The food also came out quickly. The staff was friendly- I was a visitor in San Fran, and the bartender gave me a lot of great places to check out.
author: Mary N.

description:
I was heartbroken when the sister restaurant at Larkspur Landing in Marin closed.  I had to try this location when  we happened to walk by it while shopping in Union Square. I am not sure about the owner but the name has changed.   Nice interior including a beautiful bar and atmosphere.  We had excellent service.  Some of the best salt and pepper calamari ever, Gruner Veltliner by the glass. Heaven!

Only negative was that the chicken wings came out burnt.  The kitchen replaced them and my dining companion said they were good. You may wish to try something else.

I will return and highly recommend.
author: Celeste B.

description:
More like a 3.5...

Nice decor, good atmosphere for dinner with friends
Get the corn fritters. I was imagining something really deep fried, but these were excellent! Corn pieces, lightly fried with just enough amount of crispiness and so yummy! The rib sliders were decent, but I really loved the taro chips that came with it. My mushroom dumplings were alright. I would not order the tuna tartare again, that was a bit boring. 

Over all I had a good time trying out this place, but probably won't return.
author: Vivian D.

description: This place has a great happy hour! The drinks were super reasonably priced at $5-$6 each with similarly priced and the ambiance was awesome. I would definitely come here for HH again soon!
author: Stephanie D.

description: I thought this place for was completely overrated for what it was. The decor and ambiance is very nice of course. It's got a modern asian fusion vibe to it, and it is about a block or so from union square so probably gets a lot of foot traffic and tourists. The food however I thought was pretty subpar considering the price. The part that stood out was how our waitress was raving about the "Indonesian Corn Fritters" that had "put them on the map". So of course we order it and when it came both me and my girlfriend thought "you got to be kidding". It tasted like dry rice crackers! And the sauce sure didn't make it that much better. We also ordered a few other items, nothing really wowed us.
author: Dale C.

description:
I've come here for Happy hour (3-6pm everyday) several times and lunch once. I totally recommend the platter at Happy Hour if you have 2 or more people with you. A perfect selection of all their Asian inspired tapas, all of which are delicious. Happy hour drinks are $6 with 4-5 cocktails on the list. 
I love the setting with high ceilings and a mixture of bar seating, lounge setting or tables.

For lunch, I had the Nasi goreng and also the mojitos :-)
author: Van-Anh N.

description: Chill relaxing atmosphere. Great place for a drink and sharing small plates with coworkers and friends. We loved the dumplings, especially the squash one (slightly spicy but good). Awesome find!!
author: Jen A.

description: Been there a few times and always amazing!!! so tasty and always something new to try! I had the Chinese New Year Dinner special with duck buns, long life noodles, and crispy fish. ALL WERE DELICIOUS!!! the long life noodles were my favorite. Made with foie gras... it was so rich and creamy!!! HIGHLY RECOMMEND!!
author: Nicole J.

description:
I have yet to find an Asian Fusion restaurant that I love.  Sadly, E&O was another Asian fusion restaurant that was subpar.  Came with my best friend and her family and they agreed too.  

The presentation was beautiful and the atmosphere is great for having business parties or having a classy asian influenced meal with people who may not be familiar with Asian cuisine. Many of the dishes came in fancy plates and were arranged very nicely.  Unfortunately, the size portions are very very very small for the price and the dishes lacked in flavor.
author: Kristin C.

description:
E&O will always be a favorite of mine, for many reasons.  When downtown, this is my 'more often than not' destination of choice, with its tremendously convenient parking location directly built into the block where the massive Sutter/Stockton parking garage is housed. 

E&O has undergone a name change and a complete make-over/remodel in the last year, and their menu has been tampered with but not dramatically.  Once upon a time, E&O did a great job hosting my wedding rehearsal dinner, accommodating a very large group (60+) of my family and friends, and pulling the event off in a wonderful fashion.

But here I am, back in after a random downtown appointment, and their lunch-time menu still satisfies me time and time again.  No matter what I order, the items are always full of flavor and a mix of various Asian culinary disciplines- Thai, Indian, Japanese, Chinese, and so on. On my most recent visit, I tried their 'pork buns', which were more like a lotus-bun style taco- stuffed with shredded pork, peppers, and tons of flavor.  Delicious!

Additionally, I think it should be mandatory that anyone entering the restaurant gives the fried corn fritters a try.  Essentially these are large, fried discs of corn kernels stuck together, with a tangy dipping sauce. EXCELLENT!  I could make a meal of these alone!

Worth a try for the weary Union Square shopper, and equally worth a drive across town when you are seeking something different, I will be back again and again to E&O.
author: Andy S.

description: Tried this place for the first time tonight and was blown away. The happy hour menu has a lot of variety and the happy hour drinks are fantastic. We had the ahi (stellar), corn fritters (so delicious; don't skip the sauce), butternut squash dumplings (the curry sauce really made them stand out), and the mushroom dumplings (which weren't on the happy hour menu, but worth every penny). Our server, Shawn, was incredible. Very knowledgeable about the menu and his recommendations were spot-on. We really appreciated it. All in all, a wonderful restaurant, and highly recommended.
author: Mara E.

description:
My sister and I decided to try this place after a day of shopping.

The service was very attentive, however they wouldn't let us sit at a bigger table, even though they were pretty much empty the whole time. They also brought out everything that we ordered pretty much at the same time (nothing for a long time and then everything all at once), so there was barely any space to put all the dishes on the table :(

The dishes are small, so you get to try a lot, which is great, except for the fact that... well they don't fit on your table!

We tried the papaya salad, the corn fritters (I think I liked the papaya salad better), the portobello mushrooms (definitely try that, absolutely amazing), butternut squash dumplings (another must try), and grilled steelhead (also good).
They were able to accommodate my garlic allergy :)
author: Anna P.

description: This was the very first restaurant I ate at 17 years ago when I moved to San Francisco and had not been back until last night. We sat at the bar and the service was spectacular. I ordered a Shirley Temple with vodka because it was National Vodka Day! Normally I would have a dirty martini, but I was feeling sassy. They do Bourbon drinks and Scotch drinks pretty well here. The beet cocktail was creative and powerful. We ordered Lamb Noodles which were very well prepared. The lamb was cooked well and the greens with the noodles were flavored well and provided great sustenance. We also ordered he Papaya Salad which was the best one I've had in the City. Perfect. The Shaking Beef was yummy as well, perfect pieces of tender beef with tomato and onion. For dessert we shared the Banana tiramisu. It was awesome!!! We will be back.
author: Sherie R.

description: We came here for happy hour (3-6pm). The prices of drinks and bites were really good. Oysters are very cheap but also small. I personally liked the twist on the dumplings a lot, and my friends really liked the mushroom satays. The service was also great. Would come back here again!
author: Sabrina W.

description: "Asian fusion hot spot in San Francisco". This is just one of those spots that brings me back to my days of living in Hawaii. This was one one of our most favorite restaurants, when it existed in Honolulu, HI, which was then called "E&O Trading". Though they re-branded in the recent years, I still found the same infusion of flavors I did many years ago at the Hawaii restaurant. The restaurant and bar was beautiful on the inside, ample seating for groups, huge bar and views of the kitchen. Servers there were attentive and not overbearing. The meal was perfect - a very unique corn fritter burger (corn fritter patties served as the buns with a juicy meat patty in between) and some Indonesian Fried. Everything about this meal was flavorful and was a perfect meal for 2 people - split the burger and the fried rice dish. The whole evening felt like I was sitting in Hawaii again and E&O Trading restaurant.
author: Rebecca W.

description: From out of the country and LOVED THE FOOD. They serve it quickly and I got it all packed. It was still an amazing meal. The only slight let down was slight fishy smell from the shrimp fried rice. I LOVED IT!
author: Dhanush S.

description:
OH MY GAWD!! OMG omg. Did I say OMG?

Wow! Came in alone for a quick dinner very excited to try it. I'm visiting for the night and my gf is not a foodie and was tired and stayed in. (Wtf??? In SF?) I started w Short Rib Sliders w siracha and pickled veges on a little steamed bum. Ooh! The vinegar from the veges mixed w the meat-fantastic. Then Butternut Squash Dumplings w Coconut Basil Sauce-simply divine. Sauce was rich and creamy and delicious when I drug the Lamb Naan through it.  Back in a few days. Might have to come back. Victor was my excellent server who guided me along the way. All the way to Bananmisu.  Rich and smooth dark chocolate and banana wo the rum which was nice.
author: Veda Loca K.

description: This place has the best happy hour menu! I tried the corn fritters, ahi tuna, chicken skewers - each item was around $2-$3. Dumplings were amazing and only $1.00. I sat at the bar and the bartenders were friendly and attentive. I will be back for sure!
author: Elaine Tiffany P.

description: We came here with friends for a lovely dinner out. The food was excellent. The calamari was perfect, the corn fritters are totally unique and delicious. We also had oysters, spring rolls and the butternut squash dumplings. Pad thai noodles and prawn salad for shared entrees. All superbly prepared and presented. The server was knowledgable about the menu and made excellent suggestions. The decor is very modern and subdued. Nice atmosphere. Overall, we had a great time enjoying some very tasty food. Nice selection of cocktails and draft beers too. Highly recommend.
author: Jerry M.

description:
E&O is a great spot in Union Square for a catch up dinner and/or drinks with friends. The downstairs space is very open with roomy tables and seats. There are a few different kinds of tables so depending on your group, you can be flexible in how you're seated. We were seated by the wall with the booths, which was great because there was so much space for all our stuff (sigh winter). I also like the woven straw (looking?) chairs in the middle of the room. There are also tall tables with tall chairs by the bar that look fun for drinks. The upstairs looks like like a more cosy eating space.

We got a variety of dishes to share.

Deviled eggs: they were okay, nothing too spectacular, good to start with.

Mushroom dumplings: I didn't have these, but they looked great. The rest of the table said they were really good.

Beet salad: I thought the portion size of this dish was on the small side. But the beets were flavorful and the creamy cheese was a great accompaniment.

Shaking beef: This was very well liked by my friends. Personally I thought the flavoring was very similar to roasted eggplant, and was slightly on the sweet side. The portion size was good though.

Roasted eggplant: I like that it came with onions, peppers and tofu. Again, the flavor was very similar to the shaking beef, and was on the sweet side. Eggplant doesn't need such strong seasoning and can taste great with less.

Black cod: I especially liked the bean sprouts at the bed of the fish. The fish itself was okay. Nothing spectacular.

Mango panna cotta: My favorite of the night. There's a creamy cheese-like garnish above the panna cotta and that just made everything taste great.

All in all E&O Asian Kitchen is a pretty decent place for dinner. They have interesting cocktails and a variety of menu items to satisfy all diets and preferences.
author: Sherry L.

description: Celebrating a birthday with friends and the food and wine were great.  Recommend the corn fritters, tuna tartare, and mussels with chorizo.  Made reservations on a Monday and good thing because they were packed.  Wine was line 39 Pinot which was a great summer pick.
author: Michele R.

description: Average food. Outrageous prices. How you going to charge $16.00 for three sticks of grilled chicken or $7.00 for 500 mL of Sparkling water. Soggy calamari. Nah. Just fancy deep fried stuff with Siracha and soy sauce is their definition of Asian fusion.
author: Annie W.

description:
6/27/14  Dinner

Met friends visiting from Australia for a quick dinner. Chose E&O because of its cozy decor and convenient location in Union Square next to the Sutter Garage. Service is professional from the moment we walked inside. Promptly seated for 7pm reservation. 

Cosmopolitan ($10) is surprisingly good deal. Pink, lime pulps, and tasty. Singapore Sling ($12) is a prefect re-rendition of the the drink served on Singapore Airlines first class lounge. Well done! The French red blend Equis ($11) was undrinkable. My friend set it aside far enough for the waiter to notice. He took it away and gave him a cosmo instead. The wine had a weird sweet taste reminiscent of a cold medicine.

Food was decent. It's Asian fusion with a lot of Asian ingredients but easy on the "ethnicity factor" to cater to American palate. 

*Green Papaya & Cucumber Salad ($12) is a huge platter of shredded Asian affairs. Owing to the fact that green papaya is usually not great in this country, E&O makes do with pickled apple to give that fresh tart flavor. I would appreciate more chili and peanuts on this plate.

*Duck Imperial Rolls ($12) are two rolls cut into four pieces served on banana leaf. Roll wrapper is not too think and crispy on every bite. Duck is minced and marinated. Served with the tasty lime ginger dip. It's pretty good, a welcoming twist from the usual shrimp rolls.

*Butternut Squash Dumplings ($13) is a miss. It's too much like squash rivioli. Mushy and uninspiring. The Thai curry dip is tasty though.

*Malaysian Dry Braised Chicken ($20) is well done. Chicken is not dry but juicy inside. It's slow-cooked and tender. Coconut cinnamon braise a good complement to the taste of the chicken.

E&O Asian is one of its kind in the area. Asian fusion in a very comfortable setting. The decor is colonial, with mezzanine seating open up like a verandah. The have happy hour and specific city dining menu. Manila was the feature of the night we ate. Overall service is good and friendly. But the food is not ethnic enough for my Asian palate.
author: Matt Y.

description:
I've been here a couple of times before years ago, but I'm giving it five stars because of my most recent experience. 

You see, I was with a group of friends celebrating a birthday. We were out boating around the bay, drinking wine and eating cheese and, when it was time for dinner, one friend suggested "let's all go out for dinner!" and everybody was like, "sure, that's a great idea!" and the birthday girl was like "omg, yes, I want dinner" and then we all realized that it was Saturday, it was 6pm, and we were a group of 10 people. No one would be able to sit us at the last minute. 

Then, I was like, "wait, I know of a place that has good food, good drinks, and is huuuuge" so I called and asked if the could sit us, and the hostess was like "sure, come on over" and we went there, we ate, we drank, and we loved it. 

at the end we all were like, "omg, yaaaaaas"

The end.
author: Ezekiel G.

description:
I was there for the second time with out of town relative and friend.  The first time was about two years ago around Christmas.
What impressed me was their sliders.  This time we ordered other things such as:
Devil's eggs - REALLY good.
Calamari - I had better.
Pork buns - Pretty good.
Lettuce wraps - Tasty, but alittle too salty.
Sea bass - Not bad, but too sweet for me.
Japanese bimbop (can't remember the exact name) - pretty.  Lighter in taste.
Ginger cookies - a lot of folks like them, but I thought it was ok.
Chocolate cake - pretty good.
author: Wendy W.

description:
This is a convenient happy hour spot near Downtown/FiDi area of San Francisco. Hello $1 OYSTERS and $6 glasses of PROSECCO! I enjoyed the different spicy sauces that came with the oysters, although I wish the oysters were bigger. The BEEF SHORT RIB SLIDER was tasty I liked the crispy taro chips on the side, but it was a bit pricey for its small size. I would definitely pass on the ahi tuna tartare...way too tiny and the fish was just so-so. 

The atmosphere is classy and chic so I will definitely come back for another happy hour soon. I would skip out on the food (except for oysters!) but take advantage of the $6 wine and cocktails and $4 beers.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Stumbled across this place while in the city and stopped in for happy hour. The $1 oysters definitely sold us on coming in!

My boyfriend tried 2 drinks on the happy hour menu, the blushing geisha and the maple old fashion. Both were great and strong! 

The food was decent, some items better than others. We had the oysters and dumplings which didn't disappoint!
We also tried the sliders which were "ehh" nothing special

But over all a good place to stop at if you're around during happy hour
author: Megan O.

description:
I HAD to come for their Happy Hour because of their incredibly enticing menu. $1 Oysters? How can you resist!?

Actually, everything on that HH menu was delicious and "cheap"! The dumplings were yummy, the corn fritters are a definite must and I the naan was pretty good too. But of course, it's only cheap because it's super small. I mean, the tuna tartare was literally one chip and a spoonful of fish. Fancy~ 

The drinks were just okay. I only had the Blushing Geisha because it was so weak, I figured all the rest were just the same. Or maybe I'm an alcoholic. Whatever, did nothing for me. 

The ambiance was very relaxed and ...dark. I loved the clean and modern decor. I most especially loved the fact it's RIGHT NEXT to a really cheap parking garage. At the peak of Happy Hour, it does get really crowded but I was lucky to walk into an empty space around 4pm. Service was not as prompt as I'd have liked it to have been, but we were served by the same man who greeted us and he was really nice. Maybe he had too much on his plate, but we were also charged more than twice our receipt. If we hadn't checked our bank statement, it would have probably slipped by. Tsk tsk! 

Overall, the food was superb. Very delicious! But I don't think I'd be coming back again after trying it once.
author: Krissy L.

description: E&O Kitchen and Bar is a staple restaurant of Union Square. Great fusion with excellent small & large plates. Don't miss the happy hour Mon-Sat 3-6pm. The bartender Sergio, remembers everyone and it always feels line the TV show "Cheers".
author: Teresa L.

description:
Lunch and happy hour rare bets times for this trendy delicious place.
Loved the butternut squash dumplings with Thai red curry and lemongrass sauce.
Ahi take mushroom dumplings are explosive with a rich soy pan sauce that just makes the dish over the top.
If you don't mind a heck of a lot of calories go for the fritter burger.  Their famous corn fritters are the bun for a thick burger topped with cheddar cheese,bacon sriracha aioli, kimchi, toga rash fries and pickled vegetables. Explodes but have a big appetite.

Nice deal for sharing is the lunch break menu for 21.95.  3 courses but too good to share....
author: Judi G.

description:
Recently, I was invited to try the gluten-free menu options at E&O Asian Kitchen in San Francisco, California. I tend to not think of Asian food when it comes to gluten-free dining so I was glad to be introduced to this restaurant. Right away I was very impressed even just upon entering. The interior design is amazing cloaked in warm inviting earth tones.

My daughter, Ashlee, home from college, joined me for lunch. Presented with our gluten-free menus (I love it when a restaurant has a specific gluten-free menu), it was hard to choose there are so many GF options. We opted to begin with the shrimp satay served with basil mango dipping sauce. It was lovely. I am so used to simple eating that it was a delight savoring all the unique flavors I do not get to experience at home. I enjoyed the lightly pickled veggies as well as the perfectly prepared shrimp. The dish was very creative.

I just had to try the E&O wood grilled hamburger with brown rice flour sesame bun with sriracha aioli, green papaya salad, white cheddar and fried egg. I asked them to hold the cheese and egg since I can't do cow's milk or egg. As it turns out, the gluten-free bun is Canyon Bakehouse which just happens to be my favorite hamburger bun. Oh, joy! It was delicious and a treat to enjoy a hamburger with a bun out on the town.

I could see right away the awesome quality of the burger. It is so hard to find a good burger these days. My meal was delightful.

My daughter opted for the Indonesian fried rice with gulf white prawns, char siu pork, vegetables, egg and chilies. She was very impressed. This this was way out of the box for her so the fact that she liked it is a solid testimony.

For dessert, our only option was the sorbet but, wow, what a sorbet selection. There were three options: coconut pandan (Asian grass with a vanilla flavor), grapefruit and mango/passion-fruit. The flavors were very exotic. I was very impressed and pleased.

When asked about cross contamination procedures, the chef, Sharon Nahm, came to our table and assured as that precautions are taken to avoid gluten contamination including proper equipment procedures and hand washing. Of course one never has a guarantee but I felt confident (and safe) after talking to her.

We had a lovely experience at E&O Asian Kitchen and would love to go back. I give this a thumbs up and a "Coach Kim's Pick" for Asian cuisine in San Francisco.

Check out my blog post with photos at www.thrivinggf.com
author: Kim R.

description: The service was terrible... A 40-50 years old waiter kept us waiting for 25 mins and didnot come to order... I guess he does not serve Asian ppl. It's shame.
author: Maggie Z.

description:
We went here for dinner on a busy Friday night. We were seated immediately near the kitchen. 

We decided to do a "tapas" style dinner ordering some of the small plates/apps from the quite varied menu. 

Corn Fritter - 2 served, along with a dipping sauce. I highly recommend this dish. Some folks think it's too large, but as long as you don't try to eat it with your hands, I found it fine. Delicious, undoubtedly.

Portobello Mushroom Satay - Probably wouldn't get this again. By no means was it a bad dish, but I found the mushroom a little bit too spongy for my taste. 

Fries - HUGE serving, easily enough for 3 people, and amazing. The fry on them was awesome. Crispy on the outside and nice and soft on the inside. Just how you want them. Served with ketchup, but I asked for an aioli of some kind and was given a really scrumptious garlic aioli. A must try. 

Panir naan - My only issue here is that the filling to bread ratio is a little askew. I would've liked slightly thicker bread. But, totally minor, and I'm nitpicking. A must try as well.

Butternut squash dumplings- so amazing. Also a must try. The dumpling is not chewy, the filling makes my mouth water as I write this review! 

You'll not be disappointed. Solid service too. A finished plate never stayed on the table long and the waiter was on his toes ensuring that even our water was topped up as we drank it.
author: Anthony H.

description:
Was here for lunch with a colleague and had a decent overall experience. 

What I liked...
Was greeted by the manager with a big smile
Nice trendy decor
Appetizers were very good, butternut squash dumplings and duck imperial rolls? 
 
What I did not like...
The pad thai was really disappointing. Lacked flavor and was meh.

All in all netted out to a 3 rating/
author: Sunil R.

description:
Excellent service and nice ambience.
Overall their food was good.
To me the Indonesian corn fritters (said to be their number 1 dish) is over rated. The side sauce is what makes that dish acceptable. Without the sauce I found it to be bland and although I will be back won't order the corn fritters again.
Their ginger ale was very good.
author: Vic M.

description: We went here for dinner since our hotel was a few blocks away. I remember coming here for happy hour when I worked in the City with my then co-workers. This recent visit, we ordered the calamari, the corn fritters, the beef sliders and the sticky ribs. We also tried their chili tamarind margaritas. If you're into Asian Fusion, this is a good place to start. Service was good.
author: Mika D.

description:
Came here during happy hour and ordered drinks. Geisha drink was sooo good $6. 
Didnt eat anything but wouldnt mind returning for food next time.
One star off because bartenders werent very friendly.. Our bartender was a tall caucasion looking guy who spoke spanish.. He seemed soo miserable being at work... Didnt smile. Kept speaking spanish to fellow bartender. Pretty inattentive.
He only used his left hand and seemed bored. I thought maybe he had a stroke on the right side as he literally kept his right hand limp as if he had no zeal or
Passion in bartending. Rest assured, i noticed his right hand was just fine as when we started talking to his bartender colleague, he moved it around naturally... Advice? Yeahhhh, pay attention and be attentive to your patrons.DUHHHH
author: Lilly S.

description:
We stumbled upon this restaurant by accident.  

We ordered appetizers as we had a big lunch.  Everything was excellent, edamame, short ribs, and butter nut squash dumplings.  Excellent.  

Highly recommend it and the atmosphere was great!
author: Bonnie U.

description:
Came here for late dinner with family because it is just down the street from our hotel. Wasn't impressed.
We ordered:
Corn fritters: not bad. Came in big pieces. Really shouldn't have listened to the waitress and gotten an extra piece for the three of us. 

Chickpea fries: pretty good. I liked the curry sauce that came with it. 

Chicken satay: tender pieces of chicken. Probably the best thing of the whole meal. Then again, it is just chicken.

Drunken noodle: I had way better for less than half the price. It is way over salted. Tastes like someone tipped over the fish sauce bottle. This dish had a lot of end pieces of Chinese broccoli with tough outer skin. Quite often it's as if we were eating wood shavings. Dish also had a lot of cilantro in it (which is not listed on the menu) and almost no basil (which is listed on the menu). We would've asked to skipped the cilantro because my husband doesn't care for the taste. But there's no way for us to find out. 

Water spinach side: Thank god this is kinda bland, so I can mix it with the overly salty drunken noodle and get something a little better. 

Our waitress did seem very knowledgeable with the menu. When we tried to figure out what water spinach is, she couldn't offer anything other than "it's like spinach with smaller leaves."
