Corn fritters still on the menu, and still yummy.  Also got the minced chicken with lettuce cups.  Also a winner.  Two items were enough for lunch due to portion size.

Tab for lunch for two inc tax&tip $40.
author: Shirley N.

description: My closest 8 friends joined me for a spectacular Asian fusion meal and we were not disappointed. I recommend the allustrious furikake covered edamame which was very yummy and I also enjoyed the fritter burger. Don't be fool, eat here.
author: Gary G.

description:
The space is nicer (marginally so), but was the renovation worth all the money....no! It was quiet on the busiest weekend in San Francisco history. I think that's perhaps an omen of doom.

The food is solid, but not outrageous. Like it would be good for Asian Fusion by Milwaukee standards.

Best part was my awesomely cool and nice waiter. Just a good natured, relatable, genuine bloke. 5 stars for service.
author: Andrew K.

description:
We were in the city for a show and came here very late afterwards.  We called about 1015pm just to see if they would be open, they did answer the phone (it can be hard to get ahold of a restaurant many times) and let us know to try to get there by 1045 when the kitchen would close.  It took us about all of the time to get there and I dropped off my wife to get the table and put in orders while I parked.  She was seated quickly and put in the beginning of our order while I searched for a space (didn't want to miss that deadline. 

I came in about 10 minutes later and found her.  I sat down and we were discussing for a few minutes.  The waiter very nicely came by, and said he hated to interrupt but he knew we were hungry and didn't want the kitchen to close before we got our order in.  It was very polite and not pushy at all, I think he handled it very well.  We placed our food order first and I then went about trying to find a drink...

We had calamari, it was crispy, not greasy and had great seasoning with a sweet chili style sauce.  I had shaker beef and my wife had an indonesean fried rice.  Both were great.  The beef was good just right, the sauce was with just a hint of spice but also somewhat sweet, veggies complimented it well.  My wife's rice was good, fresh shrimp and great seasoning.  I had a Malbec to go with it and it was fantastic, kudos to their selection in wines.  My wife had a gazebo and she is still raving about it to this day.

For a last minute choice, close to closing time, we got great service and had great food.  I was very happy with this meal and would gladly go again.
author: Scott P.

description:
The ambiance is generally good.  Good for date nights.  There is an area you want to avoid which is the back near the open kitchen.  It's loud with dishes crashing, pots banging, etc.  otherwise the rest of the restaurant is nicely decorated and classy.

Service was ok.  Hostess was cheerful.  As you walk in though the other servers and busboys don't smile or greet you. So not the service you would expect from the looks of this classy place.  Server was ok.  Very quiet not talkative. If you want someone to just bring you food and stay out of your way, then the servers here will fit the job description. Busboys are great with keeping dirty dishes off your table, making sure your water is filled.

The food was average.  
That's the whole reason I came for and it was a little disappointing.  The flank steak I ordered was supposed to be med rare but it turned out bloody rare entirely.  Only the crust was cooked leaving the entire inside all rare. They must have thought I was a vampire cause my plate was filled with blood.  
The pad Thai was average tasting.  An authentic Thai restaurant will do better.  The coconut ceviche was the highlight of the night for me.  It was delicious. Chunks of white fish inside a fresh coconut with taro chips.  

Overall, I probably won't be returning as I didn't leave with a good impression.
author: Adam L.

description: I had an amazing dinner this evening.  We ordered salt and pepper calamari along with the prawn salad.  The salad was such a great blend of flavors - mint, basil, chilies, fruits and cashews.  I will definitely be ordering this dish again.  E&O is worth a visit!
author: Jason K.

description: The food taste is not so authentic... Although the environment is good for a a single person , a date or a group of friends
author: Yumi K.

description:
After the renovation, this place sure gets a lot of mixed reviews. I do agree it is a little pricey but I do love the new decor and service. Before getting seated I went to the bar and the bartender was very attentive. I point this out b/c I am sick of the frou-frou places in SOMA where the bartenders are bitchy and completely ignore you (yeah, I am talking to YOU - AQ & Bar Agricole).

Corn Fritters are much bigger than before, butternut squash 'dumplings' were great as were the chicken lettuce cups (I can't believe I admit that).
author: Karen S.

description:
Came here for a new year's lunch with my boss and coworkers and was pleasantly surprised by the serving size of the appetizers and main dishes. We started out with deviled tea eggs, papaya salad and fried calamari. E&O is a combination of Asian foods around the world with a leaning toward Southeast Asian cuisine. Though the papaya salad wasn't the best, both the deviled tea eggs and the fried calamari was incredibly flavored. Our Pad Thai also turned out to be somewhat of a disappointment, because they mixed in a disproportionately large amount of filler items--tofu, pickles, shrimp, etc. to noodles, and because it tasted heavily doused in soy sauce. Our side dishes of brussel sprouts and eggplant saved the main meal. When dessert rolled around, we were all craving something sweet because of the saltiness of the Pad Thai.
I finished my meal with the coconut pandan ice cream which they topped with a large very gingery ginger cookie. Overall, the ambience of the restaurant is calming. We felt taken care of but not bothered. I would come again to try another main entree and enjoy the superbly done sides.
author: Margaret H.

description: The cocktails and drinks were very good!  The waitress that we had did a fantastic job recommending dishes to us.  We got the corn fitters for an app and they were fantastic!  Then we got the kabobs for dinner and our waitress was about to substitute the mushrooms out for us which was very nice!!   Atmosphere was very good as well!  Great place to go even though I was a little skeptical going into it!
author: James R.

description: The happy hour prices were great and our waiter was awesome. He handled our rowdy group of 8+ with grace and humor. We loved all the cocktails and favorite apps were the short ribs, corn fritters and dumplings. Get the pupu platter for sharing.
author: Wendy D.

description: Food was great, we ordered the tuna tartare, shaking beef, fried rice and Brussels sprouts. I was not very pleased with my pisco elderflower, could've been better.
author: Monique H.

description:
Thanks for hosting Yelp's Holiday kickoff Red Tie Gala!

This place is pretty awesome -- Here's the breakdown:

Atmosphere: Loved it! Very trendy and intimate. Seems like a great date place.

Food: For this event they served their chicken satay, beef sliders, spicy fries, and corn fritters. The chicken satay and spicy fries were just okay. Their corn fritters were pretty good. However, I was a big fan of their beef sliders. YUM!

Staff: The staff was great! Very friendly and courteous! They made sure your tummy's were full as they walked by with the appetizers, asking if you would like a bite of whatever they had to offer. They asked what was yours and what wasn't when cleaning up the tables and counters (hey, it matters more than you think!)

Drinks: They had about 5 different yelp-themed libations you could take part in -- most of which were quite tasty. They had them pre-mixed and then poured them into wine bottles to keep it classy.

Would I come again? I am curious what this place is like as a restaurant, so I might check it out another time. It's also a nice bonus that it's 15 minutes (walking) from my place!
author: Leana L.

description:
Eastern and Oriental!

Came here for dinner.  Best parking garage is on Sutter and Stockton, less than 500 feet from the restaurant, $1/hour.

I wouldn't' say the place has an asian feeling to it but definitely liking the vibe.  They have a booth more "exclusive" table for two and I thought that'd be more romantic if you're ever here on a date.

We ordered the calamari, beef ribs slider, buttenut squash dumpling and pad thai.  Their servings are not overly huge and can easily be shared by two people.  We had plenty on our table and this girl can eat...will eat!

My most memorable dish was the slider.  One bite of the dish and all the juices came running down my fingers and the table.  So tasty and very moist.  Don't mind my messy table manners.  It came with taro chips, and that was good too. 

Girly drink of the Singapore sling.  Finished off the meal with the mango panna cotta - happy!

Nice server.  Bill was $100 minus tip - that wasn't that bad at all.
author: Pam S.

description: Great food and you can pinpoint each of the flavors of the dish without one overpowering the other. The chutney with the pork-loin was awesome!!
author: JaimeChristie G.

description: Eh. The edamame was good, the best part of our meal probably. My husband got the Japanese "bop" and really enjoyed it, and I got the pad Thai and it was soooooop friggin' spicy I couldn't even finish it...and I love spice. The menu, nor the waiter, mentioned the spice level. I was disappointed. Oh well, good to try a new place, probably wouldn't go back.
author: Cmf F.

description:
We always get the $1 oysters and for happy hour they have $6 glasses of champagne.  I wish the oysters were a little bigger but what to do. 

The staff is attentive, and the decor is California chic.  Plus it's literally a block away from my office so super convenient. 

All in all, it's a good place to have on your list.  The rest of the food is kind of pricey, but I only go for the oysters and champagne anyway :p.
author: Michelle L.

description:
The sizes of the plates are very small and not setisfait .
The food is not more then nice and they charge me $4 for peanuts. Unbelievable!!
author: Andrew B.

description: Fabulous food, amazing service and fun ambiance.  The coconut ceviche was unbelievably good.  The butternut squash dumplings were also phenomenal.  Wish it was not so far from Seattle!
author: Linsey B.

description:
We went there with the group of four people. The bill was $200, for nothing! We got the pork tenderloin, which was very dry, and the flatiron steak, that came with lots of greens, which were super-super bitter! It's like an animal food. Ugh, will never forget that taste. And when we actually told the waiter about it, he said that lots of people hate this grass. Then why you never told us that before? I ordered medium well steak, my boyfriend - medium. I got it well done, and my b - medium well. I thought that at this level of restaurant cooks should know the difference. 
So we will definitely never come back. I expected much more for that price. Awful.
author: Krystyna T.

description:
Coworker birthday lunch, during the middle of the week. The place was pretty busy so I was glad we had a reservation.

Prices are a bit on the steep side, but the food actually measures up to expectations. Everything I tried was delicious, intense, and amazing. There's some good vegetarian options and they made concessions with some dishes that should have come with meat in them for the two of us who wanted to try.

Service is right on the ball, food came out fast despite it being really busy, and I'd happily come back again. My partner and I have plans for drinks/appetizers on a weekend, as it seems a good option for it.

Fair warning: everything was definitely on the more spicy side. Not totally blow your head off, but that slowly-builds-up-and-then-you-realize-your-mouth-is-on-fire hot.
author: Cassandra J.

description: Great place to stop by whenever I am in town.  The drinks are really good and so is the food.  The corn fritters are a must if you have not had them before.  They also have a great mix of cocktails to try.
author: Mike B.

description:
This is my go-to happy hour spot. Seriously it's the best happy hour downtown with great drink and food specials.

The service here is absolutely top notch. On more than one occasion when it's been too crowded, the amazing guys behind the bar have helped to shuffle people around and make room for us. They really make this a special place. I would frequent any bar that they tended.

The Moscow mule and old fashioned (now called the maple bourbon) are great cocktails. The pupu platter (for two) has all the highlights of the bar menu (sans the squash dumplings). Once when I came in a group of three, they easily added another portion onto the platter. My favorite bar bites are the short rib sliders, the ahi tuna tar tar, and the chicken satay. The $1 oysters and $1 dumplings are also winners. You really can't go wrong on the happy hour menu.
author: Kelly A.

description: Delicious food and a beautiful ambiance. The staff is incredibly friendly and attentive at just the right moments. The food is more Asian-fusion, so if you're expecting authentic Thai food, go to a different spot. With that said, their take on Pad Thai and Satay was exceptional! And if you love seafood, this spot has incredibly fresh seafood.
author: Anna E.

description:
I would have to say that I enjoyed this place a decent amount.  The reservation and seating portion of the evening was excellent and the recommendation to eat family style as a party of 6 was also spot on.

We got the mushroom dumplings, the asian ribs, the drunken noodles, tofu, butternut squash dumplings, shaking beef, garlic chicken, and some other stuff.

Out of all the mentioned above, the mushroom dumplings and ribs win for best selection.  My friend, Joe, even mentioned that "Those were the best Asian Ribs I have ever had in my life"  He usually just says "today" instead of "in my life"

The only "sizzling beef" I have was getting talked out of the Strawberry Soda for the Cucumber Chill out "Spirit Free" drink.  I would definitely come back and recommend this place to friends.
author: Patrick K.

description: I am writing this review based on the service. I don't know what it is about San Francisco but people aren't that nice. Show up, asked if we had reservations followed by it's a 30 minute wait I can wait in the lounge area and have some drinks. 2 other parties there were eating and drinking. Finally 35 minutes later a server approached us if we wanted a drink which at this point our table should be ready soon so we declined. I notice the hosts approach the party who arrived 25 minutes after us with also no reservations telling them they're table will almost be ready. So of course that's when I ask about our table and we are finally seated with a few empty tables in the back. So why did I wait 45 minutes? To cut to the chase our actual server didn't make it better. Ran out of water during dinner, never got a refill till I asked for one once we were done eating along with the check. To me good service is better then good food so for that reason I will not be returning or recommending this place.
author: Michelle P.

description: My friend made a reservation here when I was coming into town and I was with someone else who requested Asian food. The decor of this place is very swanky. As is the cocktail menu. The food is meant for sharing. I would say that the menu has some high aspirations but I have had some more creative and flavorful dishes elsewhere. They really do try and the service is excellent. The open kitchen is cool to sit by and watch the chefs do their magic. Overall it was a pleasant night. I would probably go again but might be more interested in trying something new. There are so many places to try in San Francisco! This one did not blow me away. Please take that with a grain of salt however. I travel a lot and eat out often. This place deserves a visit.
author: Jen V.

description: We had dinner here tonight at the suggestion of our hotel Concierge.  We came in around 7pm and a shorter guy at the front desk showed us to our table in the back.  We waited about 15 minutes before our waiter came over to the table.  He was an older white guy with glasses.  He didn't really say hello and asked what we wanted to drink.  We figured the service was not going to be quick or good, so we ordered our appetizer and meals at the same time.  About 10 minutes later, our waiter brought us our beers, but gave the wrong one to each of us.  He walked away.  About 10 minutes later, another guy brought us our appetizer (Chicken Satay).  It was good but not worth the price.  We then waited, waited and waited some more.  About 20 minutes later, our server came by and asked if we had received our main dishes (2 Pad Thais) in which we told him we hadn't.  He checked the kitchen then said they were being made but never apologized for the long wait.  After another 10 minutes, another guy brought the dishes.  The Pad Thai was pretty good.  Our waiter never came and checked on us.  We had to ask another guy for boxes.  Our waiter came back and put dessert cards on the table to which we told him we didn't want any and wanted the bill.  He brought the bill and never said thank you or anything.  This was our second to last night in San Francisco for our honeymoon and it was the only experience that we want to forget.  We told our Concierge about our awful experience and he said he was very sorry that he suggested this place to us for dinner and will not be recommending it to future guests.  Such a shame the service was awful, this could be a nice place.
author: Nicholas S.

description:
We normally wouldn't stop in randomly at a restaurant in Union Square, but we realized last second that Hops n Hominy was closed. It was cold, and this was the closest restaurant with good reviews.

First off, the place is beautiful. It might be a good place for people to visit who are from out of town. But for people who are spoiled with the  stellar restaurants within a short walk, this is a resounding PASS. 5 seconds into our meal, we realized we could have just taken the extra time to walk to Katana Ya (Also half the price).

We ordered the Squash dumplings, which were very bland and forgetful. The Beef Toppoki seemed like the chef couldn't wrap his head around what type of fusion he was going for. It was like a mish-mash of different ingredients in one, that didn't work well together. An interesting take on gnocchi, but executed poorly. And the meat was chewy. Odd to have chewy meat that is cooked medium-rare.

The servers were nice, but there was confusion with the food runners. Other people's dishes were put in front of us. Not a big deal, but should at least be noted.
author: Jon C.

description:
Visited for the first time and came in with a friend from out of town.

It was a good experience and service was good. Thank you Tim!

Was pretty late on a Friday, but tried to take in as much as I could without going overboard on carbs.

Entrees:

Pad Thai - thin noodles, not greasy and flavorful
Short Ribs Sliders - as close to high protein low carb that I could order at the time of dining.

Dessert:

Devils food cake - heavenly
Bananimisu - First time and loved it!

Drinks:

Vodka Martini

Spent about $73 with tax.
author: Marc M.

description: Had the Chicken Curry and was really disappointed with the quality considering the price. The curry didn't have the best flavor, but the fried rice made up for it. Overall, decent place but not worth the price.
author: Claudia E.

description:
It's conveniently located between the financial district and union square. Or, perhaps just in union square? I can't remember where we were since we did quite a bit of walking before we landed here. 

We ran a few errands after work, and lost track of time. It was getting a little late and we wanted dinner .. immediately.  So we checked out E&O Asian Kitchen.  We've seen ads about the restaurant on SF Weekly, and apparently they had a great happy hour menu. The food wasn't bad. The selections are similar to any other Asian Fusion restaurant in town.  Our waitress was extremely nice and patient, but I wouldn't come back for a second experience.
author: Patricia T.

description:
Awful food. Really. I should know better than to eat at asian fusion restaurants. I came here for a business lunch and everyone pretty much left still hungry. 

Whatever you do, do not order any salads. It's a crime to charge $15 dollars for the tiniest of tiny salads. Definitely order something that's actually cooked, not just assembled. We ordered some dumplings for the table that were okay. But overall, I would not recommend this restaurant. It is beautifully decorated, so leave it for business meals if you need a place to go in the neighborhood.
author: Patricia Q.

description:
I wanted to try this place because it was featured on a food show and the I wanted to try the corn fritter. For me this place was okay, its wasn't the best. 

The restaurant is a pretty pricey place with a nice sized portion. My friend and I decided to share the special of having a 3 course meal for $36.50. I was like damn this better be good. So we ordered the fried calamari, corn fritter (which is an additional $5), pad thai, and the mango panna cotta. We also order a side order of the kendenish fries. I wasn't really impressed with the food though it  wasn't bad either. Maybe I was expecting too much because you would think that since its sooo expensive it's going to be amazing and it just wasn't. The calamari was pretty good, the fries were nice a crunchy and spicy, the pad thai I definitely had better, and the panna cotta was really good though it was a small portion.

The wait staff is good and very attentive, which is always a plus in anybody's book.

It's a nice looking venue, but I didn't like how we were seated right next to another party. I mean if it was crowded yes, but not when there's is practically nobody there.
author: Denice D.

description: Loved it.  Went for Happy Hour.  Had the poo poo platter and it was delicious.  Had to order more of our favorites.  Corn Fritters and Nann.  Drinks and service were on point.
author: Brian N.

description: Great waiters and bartenders. Wonderful place for appetizers and drinks.  Check it out n
author: Mary Ann L.

description: We stopped in for dinner after sight seeing the city! Our experience was awesome! We ordered the Fritter Burger and the Satay platter and split both entrees! It was fantastic we will definitely be back. Highly recommend.
author: A G.

description: Great food, loved my wood fire burger! The siracha aioli was delicious!! This restaurant was at the suggestion of the hotel I am staying at. Very good choice!
author: Benny P.

description:
This review is based from my last experience here which was a few months back. My boyfriend and I decided to come here for the second time because of the amazing experience we had previous to this one. 

As soon as we arrived it was as we expected, busy and had a wait, the hostess we encountered was such a sweetheart and accommodated us as best as she could.  She offered us to have a seat at the bar until they had an available table. She even came back to check up on us and said we would be seated shortly. We were planning to just have dinner at the bar, which we wouldn't have mind, but as soon as we tried to order our drinks the bartender that was working that night had a bit of an attitude he came up to us and asked if we were ready to order. And I haven't decided yet. I ignored the hint of rudeness in his voice and thought okay he is just busy. But then I saw him roll his eyes and walked away. The second time he approached me he said very firmly "Are you ready to order now?!" And placed my order. 

Good thing as soon as we got our drinks we were seated at our table. Our waiter was so nice and made up for the rude experience we had at the bar, we ordered our food and few more drinks afterwards. Food was good, and was presented beautifully. 

BUT, as soon as we got our bill our fairly good experience went down hill, we paid in cash, we waited for about 15- 20 mins to get our change. It was towards the end of the night and they were closing very soon so we just patiently waited. Then when we finally received our change it was SHORT! And I'm not talking about a few dollars short but $30 short! 

I'm glad we have the habit in counting our change! And to top it off they left us no receipt in the holder along with our change! So we tried to get the attention of our waiter but we felt we were purposely ignored because he even walked by us and acted as if he didn't hear us.. Finally when he came and asked us what was wrong we told him that he gave us the wrong change and that it was short $30, he apologized and pulled out a stack of cash from his apron and handed us our exact change. 

I understand we had a few drinks but we weren't oblivious to what was going on. At first we gave him the benefit of the doubt thinking it was late and he probably had a long day and it could have been an honest mistake, but as we were walking out we realized he didn't even go to the register to try to fix our transaction and just handed us cash from his pocket of his apron.. 

Hmm.. A little suspicious if you ask me! Hopefully, it was an honest mistake and we weren't being taken advantage of since our age group was a lot younger than the rest of the crowd the was there that night. 

But thank you to the very kind hostess that evening! Other than that we will not be back to the location.
author: Bernadine T.

description: A huge fan of their happy hour.  Love that there are drink items AND food items.
author: Tiffany C.

description: The food was good but we came at a crowded time and it was so noisy it was impossible to carry on a normal conversation. Install some sound absorbing panels, please.
author: Dan M.

description: Been here twice and it's really more of a hip place.  Not really very romantic. Great for after work and lunch.
author: Kevin F.

description:
This place is remarkable -- in the literal sense. That is, it is so good, I wish to remark upon it--two months later.

At E&O dishes don't make the menu because they're easy, or popular. Each entree and appetizer is exceptional. E&O gets all the little details right. Presentation. Flavour. Selection. Everything I tried wasn't just good, but great.

Edamame? Cooked perfectly. And then not just sea salt, but furikake, a new-to-me Japanese seasoning.

The kimchi It wasn't just good kimchi. It was good kimchi and pickled mango -- you can pickle mango? mind blown -- and pickled japanese plum.

Drinks -- alcoholic and non -- were winners. The homemade ginger beer (homemade ginger beer!?) was mulled with amazing spices. The dark and stormy? Tasty.
author: Paul S.

description: Super friendly staff. Chill music. The short rib app is amazing as well as the pork steamed buns.
author: Jonathan R.

description: Had a great time here m sitting at the bar with drinks and small plates. We had corn fritters, deep fried crunchy corn goodness, pork and Kimchee potstickers, tasty but somewhat missed the kimchee, and super yummy short rib sliders. Great taste on the sliders and nice toppings. Drinks were good, service was nice even with every seat filled. Really enjoyed it!
author: Zillah T.

description:
I came here with some friends and had the Chinese chicken salad bowl (I may have the name wrong) - it is a ground chicken bowl wherein you create your own chicken cups with lettuce. 
It would have been better had there been more vegetables provided - I received lettuce (not enough) and a few mint leafs. The food itself wasn't too bad. I am leaving a two star review because my friend and I both got food poisoning (massive diarrhea) for about five hours after eating here, while our third party did not. Our guess is that it was either the food handling or the peanut sauce, because that was the only thing our third party did not consume! The prices are in the mid-range, so expect to spend about $25 a person.
author: Josh S.

description:
I love this place.  I always try to stop by when I'm in SF.  Started off with their Wild Orchid drink; gin, lime, St. Germaine and house-made oregat syrup.  Wish I could get this at home.  

The corn fritters were amazing as usual. The portions have been downsized which is great because 3 were just too many for an appetizer. They're pretty good sized. 

This time I also tried the deviled eggs. Absolutely wonderful. They are hard boiled in dark tea which gives them a unique smoky flavor; topped with a sprinkle of spicy paprika, and a tiny piece of sweet bacon. I ordered two halves, but ended up ordering two more because I was craving the amazing flavor.  

Great experience. I'm a happy girl.
author: Lisa H.

description: The decoration is really good. Food is tasty. If you only consider the taste, then this place is too pricey. However, after the ambience and the nice service are taken into account, the price is reasonable.
author: Sydney C.

description: Admittedly we should probably have made reservations but  who does that for happy hour. I and 19 of my friends stopped by after work for drinks and appetizers on Friday but I am guessing that just because I am the one who got there first and am the African-American looking one of my group the hostess made some racist assumptions and said they couldn't accommodate us.  I went in anyway and they did at least serve our diverse group of professionals when they saw that's what we are.  I expected better in SF 2016.
author: Ina S.

description: This is a lovely spot, high on ambience and obviously a popular gathering place.  Staff were very attentive and service was quick enough, although the multiple dishes we ordered came out one at a time, and the last one arrived well after we had finished eating everything else.  That might have been co-ordinated better.  The menu was diverse, with a great selection of Asian- and Indian-inspired favourites.  But I'm sorry to say that all five dishes we ordered were rather bland.  In this type of fare, we expect the zing of garlic and ginger and chilis and the sauces, but there was none of that.  And we think they may have forgotten something as simple as the salt!  The corn fritters were crispy, but whole cumin seeds would have added flavour.  The ahi tuna seemed to be nothing but cubes of tuna with some pea shoots mixed in.  No distinct flavour.  The steak satay was too thick to be cooked properly, and the peanut sauce was flavourless.  The green beans side dish with chilis and garlic should have been the most intensely flavoured, but again, we think they forgot the salt or used a too-light soy sauce.  By the time the pad thai arrived, we weren't expecting much so we weren't surprised that it, too, was bland.  Maybe it's because we cook these dishes ourselves and/or we order them from a lot of different places in our travels, but we'd have to say that we wouldn't go back here again for the food.
author: Carly D.

description:
This gem of a restaurant is insanely delicious ! 
Every time in the past when I would visit SF, I would have to come here. It's been over ten years since my last visit and the food is just as flavorful and tasty as I remember. Miguel was our server and he did a phenomenal job!
author: Lucy T.

description: They make a mean cocktail at this Union Square restaurant and bar. Try the Thai Basil vodka cocktail. Excellent. It also has nice modern interior. However with all of the excellent restaurants in this city, this one was just ok. I wouldn't recommend it for the food. I found it average.
author: Tina N.

description: Wanted to try something off the Food network again. Heard the corn fritters were a big hit... Um, definitely not on my list of best thing I ever ate. Not even close. Everything was a little too peppery. Service was slow. Glad I tried it but probably won't be back when there are so many great places to go.
author: Mel L.

description:
Food Quality - Excellent
Food Taste - Excellent
Food Originality - Excellent
Price - Good
Customer Service - Excellent
Ambiance - Good

Went as a big group. We had reservations and they immediately seated us. Took good care of the big group. Good was good too. So was the service. But i think slightly expensive for what they offer.
author: Vibhor C.

description:
I was very excited to try E&O for the first time last night. The decor is very chic, clean and modern. The service was superb! From the host to the waiter to the bus boys, it was a wonderful experience.

The food was very very very good! Usually Asian Fusion restaurants are not my favorite, as most restaurants do not do the "fusion" part justice. But E&O definitely hit the nail on the hammer.

The Tea Smoked Deviled Eggs were my favorite. @ $2.95 a piece, a bit pricey but worth trying as it was very different and good. My next favorite dish was the Prawn Satay with Thai Basil Mango sauce. Oh man, I could drink that sauce every day. (I'm a huge mango fan) and of course, if you love corn, get the Corn Fritters!

Everything we had on the menu was very good and satisfying. The least favorite I would say was the Butternut Squash Dumplings. Just because it was not as "wow" as compared to the other dishes. 

Last but not least, you MUST get the Mango Pannacotta with Ginger Compote. Again, I am a sucker for anything mangoes...

I will most definitely come back!
author: Teresa W.

description: We ate here on New Year's eve night.  The restaurant has a very cool atmosphere.  We sat at the low top table in these cool cabana style chairs.  The hostess was very nice and accommodating even on such a busy night.  The dumplings we ordered were pretty good.  We ordered the mushroom dumpling and the carb dumplings both of which we enjoyed.  The crab dumplings are a little on the spicy side which I liked.  We also ordered the pad thai which was ok.  The service was very good and so were the dumpling so I would recommend this restaurant.
author: Abbas B.

description: My dinner here was simply amazing! Where to start? The very diverse cocktails are a real winner. I had something called a Moscow mule, which came in a copper cup. It was very good, and the small details of the use of copper cup was awesome. This restaurant has small plates as well as full size meals. We ordered the Indonesian corn fritters, which I wish I could make at home. We also got the roasted eggplant, which could have been mistaken for tender meat it was so good. Others at the table had chicken satay as well as the sliders. Both were very good I was told. The place wasn't too loud, our waitress was just great (pleasant, polite, helpful) and the bussers were very attentive. I wish there were more restaurants like E&O.
author: Ashley T.

description:
During my most recent visit back to SF I found myself wandering downtown looking for a place for lunch and a place that wasn't going rush me or make me feel rushed. I've been to E&O in the past for dinner but now they've remodeled and look more chic so I hoped the food would be better.
I sat at the bar and the bartender was on it, he was friendly and professional, unfortunately I was not getting cocktails with lunch, the list looked interesting.
I have to recommend E&O Asian kitchen and that surprises me. I had a green papaya salad which was tasty though I prefer it to be hotter in my mouf. The Spicy pork sandwich was also real enjoyable. There was a crunch and sweet and a spice and bread and that's the way I like it.
If it matters the crowd was quite attractive for lunch.
author: Alexander R.

description: Came here on a Friday night for happy hour with friends. It was super easy to find seating without any reservations which is super surprising for any place in financial district. The place was definitely lively but I liked that it never got overcrowded. E & O has a wide selection of drinks and appetizers to choose from and we ordered their Moscow mules (which came in the obligatory brass cups), butternut squash dumplings, corn fritters and a dozen oysters. Everything came out delicious, and the service was on point. Will definitely be coming again for their happy hour!
author: Jia-Yuan W.

description:
The food and drinks were really good! You have to get the Tamarind & Hoisin Spare Ribs!!! They were falling off the bone! 

The other items we ordered were: Edamame, Black pepper shaking beef, Wood roasted char siu black cod, Indonesian fried rice, Butternut squash dumplings 

They have some pretty good gluten free options as well!
author: Karen B.

description:
I first had their corn fritters back in 2005, one of the highlights of my SF trip. Tried making it at home, but those suckers are difficult. The various online recipes are garbage. Walked by and noticed the new name change. Stepped in for happy hour and ordered the corn fritters. It was still really good, but just a tad tougher, chewier than before. Maybe just an off batch today. Still, those suckers are not easy to make.

Now, I have a ton of friends who love oysters. Me, I've had my share at various places but could never really drool over them like everyone else. Just not an oyster guy. Then I had them here for happy hour. Wow. Bar raised. A smidge better than Hog Island? Possibly. At an Asian fusion restaurant? I'm confused as well. $1 per. 

The spare rib had a delicious flavor but was TOO salty. 

The butternut squash dumpling was surprising. Bite into it, it's all mash. However, the flavor wasn't overbearing. I grew to appreciate that aspect of it. Typically I only go for pork and chive dumplings over in the Sunset, but there was an enjoyable soft, sweet texture to these butternut squash dumplings. And that's just about as far as I can describe a squash flavor.

Slider was just amazing too. What's going on???? I'm not even drunk yet!

To top it all off, they make a perfect Old Fashioned. 

So yeah, some pretty amazing things have happened since the renovation. Bravo!
author: Ethan L.

description: Stopped in here thinking about using the venue for a private event. Joya, Chris, and Miguel were very friendly and accommodating. We tried various items including the corn fritters, butternut squash dumplings, ahi tuna tartare, chicken satay, and oysters. Everything was very tasty with the fritters and satay as our specific favorites. Happy hour pricing was very good too. We look forward to celebrating our wedding dinner here next month. Joya is very easy to deal with in setting up a private event. Would recommend.
author: neal s.

description: Awesome Asian fusion food with layers of flavor and depth. Couple this with an amazing staff to back it up. Very enjoyable dinner and environment, not precocious but very trendy. We will be back...
author: Tad J.

description: Yum! Not much more is needed. Get a Moscow mule or a blushing geisha and enjoy an awesome atmosphere.
author: Samantha K.

description: After being delayed in San Diego for 2hrs+, our arrival in SF was marked with frustration and hunger pains. E&O fixed all that instantly. The food was on point and the staff was great. The corn fritters are salty savory sweet goodness and perfect with cocktails. The manager was so sweet to send them to us complimentary. Plus our bartender gave us so many great local tips. Thanks E&O for turning things around for us and setting the tone for the rest of our trip.
author: Renee G.

description: It has been years since I've been here and they did a nice job with the remodel.  I had some clients in town that we staying near Union Square so this was a perfect location.  The staff was super friendly and didn't rush us at all.  Their recommendations were spot on and we enjoyed everything we had which was quite a lot.  I really liked the pork buns but the pepper was almost too hot in there although I did love it.
author: Blake B.

description: I love the atmosphere and great service. Food was pretty good. I had the pad Thai and it was mostly great but thought the bell peppers were kind of weird in it. Mostly everything was awesome.
author: Kristin S.

description: Ate here last night and was so pleasantly surprised! It's been in the city for almost 20 years and it was DELICIOUS! So nice to have restaurants that aren't the latest and trendiest and still hold up the bar of excellence. Nice wait staff too, and yummy desert!
author: claudia s.

description:
the menu here has so many new and exciting twists on asian classics.  it's not easy to narrow down the choices.  

everything we had was good, especially the corn fritters and oysters (Ok, I admit the oysters were just oysters but they were good and had proper presentation)
author: Paul S.

description:
Its been ages since I've been back to E&O. Throwback Thursday!

It feels the same, the food seems the same. 

Love their Asian fusion and their overall meals are good. I'm sure there are plenty of better restaurants in SF if you really want to do some serious comparison. 

Went back to a somewhat late dinner and the place was decently packed. Parking is easy with the public parking structure next door. Their menu seems to have the same stuff with some variations here and there. The food taste is overall good. 

Enjoyed some drinks and my brother and his friends all showed up for drinks as well. Good chill place to grab some food and drink.
author: Kevin Y.

description:
I was skeptical when my friend told me we were going to an Asian fusion restaurant for her graduation dinner. And E&O is kind of ambiguously Asian. Is it Korean or Chinese? I don't know and I'm not trying to worry about it because each dish I had was nicely flavored, cooked, and portioned. Our waiter Victor was attentive, well spoken, and able to explain the extensive menu in what seemed like a single breath. It's served family style so you can have a little nibble of everything on the menu.

We had:
chicken lettuce cups
corn fritters (apparently featured on the Food Channel, crispy crunchy yummers)
asparagus salad
satay platter with chicken, steak, shrimp, portobello mushroom (the shroom is a hearty, juicy one!)
oxtail dumplings
flatiron steak

Special shout out to the bathrooms which smell of lovely fresh gardenias because of the vases of flowers all along the sinks. This won me over because I am a girl and I like these things. Honestly though, I would never go back because it's too pricy for my budget but hey when someone else is the footing the bill by all means!
author: Alice L.

description: Ambiance was awesome, pupu platter was great, service was good, but drinks were okay.  Had the Moscow Mule and thought it was okay.  Had the Maple Old Fashion and thought it was meh.  Overall, pretty good experience and would return and recommend to friends.
author: Karl H.

description: Had my birthday reception at E&O last nite.  Party of 11 for siblings, spouses and moms (my mom and my mom-in-law).  We had a fantastic time!  I reserved a beautifully decorated room that afforded us lots of privacy, yet on the main floor for excellent service.  Our server, James, was way cool!  Friendly, professional, fun, attentive, and provided us with a memorable time.  I  pre-ordered the menu, so everything was stress free.  Only thing we really had to decide was which bottles of wine to have and how many.  My wife continue to enjoy this place, and will be coming back soon for happy hour.  THANKS EVERYONE!  Mahalo and Aloha....
author: Joel M.

description:
The food, the service, and the atmosphere were all top notch. We enjoyed the service at the bar and both bartenders were friendly, attentive, and made a lot of great suggestions. They were very busy when we first sat down, but were quickly greeted and attended to. The cocktails were great - both the gazebo and the Moscow mule.
 
The food...."aghh!" There are so few meals where we can look back and say "everything we ate, every component on every dish...was exceptional." All ingredients were fresh, cooked perfectly, and seasoned. The smokey taste in the dipping sauce that accompanied the shrimp sate elevated the dish and showed the attention to detail in the kitchen. The Indonesian pickled vegetables that accompanied the sate were to die for! We loved the butternut squash dumplings and after eating...we thought to ourselves...."this is my new happy place!" For us, good food (on any level) can take us back to our roots, remind us of how great life is, and how lucky we truly are. My fiancé is from Cape Verde and grew up in Angola and Portugal. His family uses curry in many unique ways (they made me appreciate and enjoy curry, after believing I hated it) and he loved the kale salad's flavor profile. He kept wondering, "how did they pull this off?" Yet another item we loved! We finished with the shaking beef and green beans ---and the last dish was just as delicious as the first. Kodus to E & O for pulling off such an amazing meal and operation.
author: Amanda M.

description: I am in love with the Chickpea fries. Amazing. Crispy, packed with flavor and a delicious dipping sauce. I just ate here today and I want to go back and order more. The mushroom dumpling was delicious, the corn fritters are different, filling and tasty. Their own ginger ale drink is so good. It has a real snap with the ginger and lovely tang. We ordered a bunch of appetizers to start out with and those were my favorites, but everything we got here was high quality and very tasty. I got full before the entree. Next time I will just order the Chickpea fries and mushroom dumplings as my meal. I felt the portions were generous. This was the first time our group has been here, and we meet every few months for a business meeting nearby. We will be back. Service was attentive and good. It is a cute restaurant with a nice vibe. There were 9 of us and we sat at a table by the front window. We could all hear each other and it was a nice spot. Highly recommend.
author: linda c.

description: The food wasn't as good as the last time I was here.  Too bad.  I liked this place enough to come back after the last visit but probably not again after this one.
author: Jennifer J.

description:
Came here for dinner with a friend. Restaurant was easy to get reservations at on Open Table and even allowed us to change it last minute. 

The restaurant decor was spacious and modern and seemed to be pretty busy. We were seated right away and got our drinks pretty quickly. 

The food we got (Dan Dan Noodles, Scallion bread, Lettuce Wraps, Crab Eggrolls) -were just OKAY. I mean, I think the best thing was the Lettuce Wraps. The worst thing by far was the Dan Dan Noodles. Bland and tasted like Spaghetti with Meat Sauce. So gross. 

Would go back if someone else insisted but to be honest, I think Asian Fusion is a dime a dozen in SF.
author: Carmen K.

description:
I came here for two work-related lunches while attending the JP Morgan Healthcare Conference.  What's great about it, at least during lunch, is that it is not loud, which makes it great for business lunches.  The staff and service were superb.  The food on the other hand, was okay.  We had the fried corn (forget what they call it).  I was surprised that that dish gets so much hype on Yelp.  We also had a few other appetizers.   I ordered the sea bass one of the lunches - it tasted okay, but lacked the rich flavor I'm accustomed to when eating sea bass.

Anyhow, I think this is a good place for lunch, but remember the food here is not something to go home to cry about.
author: Gaurav M.

description:
Have wanted to go here for a long time, and since I got a gift certificate, I took my wife and adult son there for lunch today. Wow! Service at the front desk as well as the wait staff was beyond what I expected; but food was way better than I thought it would be.
 
We shared Butternut Squash dumplings (yum) and Indonesian Corn Fritters (SUPER yummy). We coincidentally all ordered the Black Cod entree. This was absolutely delicious, generous in size, and cooked to perfection. Tender and topped with a soy glaze. Wait staff were knowledgable and were more than willing to make substitutions and suggestions.

Yes it is pricey, but in proportion to other fine restaurants in the area, it is actually reasonably priced. Black Cod entree with greens and rice was $24. 

Glad we went so we can now tell our friends. Looking forward to returning here to try other items on their menu.
author: Howard S.

description: Went to E&O for dinner.  We where staying at a Union Square hotel and wanted something close.  A short walk from our hotel.  The atmosphere was good kind of had a 70's country club vibe, maybe just me.  Had a great craft beer and my wife had a great craft cocktail to start.  The polite waiter suggested when asked that we order a few things off the small plate menu and share.  That was a great suggestion we did and got to sample some very unique flavors and styles.  had the drunken noodles pretty spicy but spot on and very good.  Also had the Naan Lamb?? very good and different.  Banana masu was good but didn't have that unique flair as the rest of the meal had.  I would definitely recommend and will go back on our next SF visit.
author: Don C.

description: Asian Fusion hits a high note one street up from Union Square. Try the butternut squash dumpling with curry sauce. It sounds odd, but it works. The tuna tartare is similar too Hawaiian poke. A yummy popper. Their happy hour is the best.
author: Kirsten S.

description:
Some colleagues and I were in town for a convention and went here based on a recommendation from a lovely older couple we met in our hotel lobby. We had a great time.

The three of us sat at the bar. Our bartender was friendly, attentive, and made delicious cocktails. His drink recommendations paired beautifully with our food. We tried a variety...the spring rolls, duck rolls, butternut squash dumplings, chicken satay, dry fried green beans, and corn fritters. Oh. My. God. Everything came with its own delicious sauce. The fritters weren't what any of us expected, but we all loved them. Lots of complex, layered flavors at work here. I especially enjoyed the duck rolls and the corn fritters. 

I thought presentation was good and prices were fair. I would definitely return.
author: Jenn W.

description: The corn cakes are a must!  There were 6 in our group and ordered a bit if everything to share. All of the food was great and service was spectacular.  We'll make this a regular stop when in town.
author: Greg M.

description: Great service, drinks were well made, food was fantastic. Calamari was off the hook! Chickpea fries were different but had great flavor. Watch out for the peppers in the green beans!
author: James J.

description:
Here's a quick review of one of my favorite places to eat...

Pros:
Tapas style asian food, order several small plates and sample a lot of great food
Beautiful ambiance, furnishings and decor
Service is above and beyond par, such friendly and courteous servers
Don't have to wait long for food either

Cons:
It's very easy to get carried away and lose track of how much you're spending. So don't go here if you're feeling frugal. Even though they're small plates, they definitely adds up quickly
Wished they had more vegetarian/vegan selections

Cheers to a SF favorite!
author: Lea F.

description: Great dishes that tasty and well balanced. I try to come here every time I'm in town.
author: Rich F.

description: Very easy to get a table here with the open table app. Thursday evening saw a mix of out of town and locals, people conducting business and casual friends. Ended up hanging out in the lounge area instead of taking a table. Happy hour from 3p-6p ordered 2 sets of the pupu platter, oysters and dumplings. The dumplings came in a bowl covered in a thick mild yellow curry sauce. That dish felt very sloppy. I can't think of any drink that goes well with a thick yellow curry covered soggy dumpling. Just pan fry them please. A warm soft centered with a pan fried crisp bottom dumpling would have been perfect with any drink. The oysters were good. Maybe kumamamotos. Small and sweet. The platters were a tastefully sample including Thai Japanese Korean and Chinese tastes. Service was above average. Got busy after 5. Love the union sqr location.
author: Satoshi K.

description: Came here for a dinner date night and was very satisfied. The food all had great flavor and their signature cocktails were delicious!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Enjoyed a nice lunch here. Shared the Butternut Squash Dumplings, which were great. The shrimp salad was delicious. Decided to share a piece of the Devil's Food Cake for dessert and, oh boy, was that a good choice. Dense, deep chocolate flavor with a hint of Five Spice powder giving it a little kick. Ummmmm. 

Nice atmosphere. Good service. I noticed they had a nice private room, too, for a group of 10 or so.
author: Joanna S.

description: An absolutely amazing dinner!  Beyond my expectations.  The fish just melted in my mouth.  The pad Thai was amazing.  A must do for anyone that loves Thai influence to their food.  Half a block walk from taj Compton.
author: Becky N.

description:
Good beer selection at a reasonable price.
Had the: 
-ribs
-shiitake mushroom dumplings
(oh so good, not your typical dimsum)
-fried rice
Great food for a late night.
author: Mike N.

description: Very good asian fusion food, served family style, reasonably quick service and decent cocktails. The price tags are okay for the level of service and quality but don't expect "cheap".
author: Stefano Z.

description:
Good Asian fusion, the dishes draw on influences from all over Asia. In the same meal, I had duck spring rolls with a zesty dip (they were really hot temperature-wise), Indonesian-inspired fried rice, deviled eggs ala the Chinese, and pad thai. 

Everything was delicious but the fried rice was a little too salty for me (and I eat salty!). Service was great. Our waitress probably came over and refilled my water glass at least 5 times.
author: Nan L.

description:
I have to admit utter disappointment at E&O. Having seen Yelpers go nuts for this place and the fact that it was near my hotel, it was the perfect option for me to head to. Plus, they were also recommended as doing lots of GF options. Sounded like a winner, but hey, turns out you can't win them all.

Service was quick and efficient - maybe like other reviews have pointed out, a tad too quick but I wasn't planning on lingering all night. I only wanted one course and I wanted something light, having ate a larger meal earlier in the day. I opted for the Tuna Ahi Poke. 

Yep, it was on the GF menu and it was tender and fresh but when it is served with lettuce and the overwhelming flavour of the dish is lettuce, then that is not so good. No ginger, no tuna and no seaweed flavours coming through. Just lettuce :-(
No rice crackers either and no explanation of why they were missing.

As for the GF menu - its limited. Advertise as GF and say it is totally GF - not with exclusions such as cooked in contaminated oil because coeliacs (celiacs) need to have stuff genuinely GF and if you are selling yourself as a higher end place then do it right and adapt the menu properly.

So, I was disappointed. So many great meals (and safe for GF) meals in San Francisco, but this was really just meh, hence the 2 stars...
author: Claire L.

description: Disappointed for the price vs. the service and the food. Service felt as if you were troubling them to be there. The food tasted fabricated to the point of liquid smoke being used for an effect on a satay.. I do not recommend nor will return.
author: Kristin N.

description: A perfect place to meet for a business lunch or dinner as well planning a extravagant dinner with out-of-town guests.  The Sutter Stockton garage parking is ideal.  Just drive in and jump out..the restaurant is right off the elevator practically.  There are few restaurants on Union Square that I, as a local, would frequent - his is definitely one of my favorites.  Delicious food, relaxed atmosphere and gracious service add up to a simply delightful experience.  Highly recommend!
author: Paula M.

description:
I have been to E&O only twice...both on New Year's Eve, 2011 vs. 2012.  While the restaurant decor has been the same, the experience was significantly different.  Last year, my husband and I had a marvelous dinner.  The food actually wowed us, as did the decor and the service.  

Sadly, this year, the food was extremely disappointing.  We were actually embarrassed  since we brought friends along.  

-- Shitake Dumplings -- last year, we were wonderfully surprised at how "mushroomy creamy" it tasted.  This year, while the food was still beautifully presented with small dried shitakes beside the dumplings, it only tasted of vinegar and something herby, similar to cilantro.  You couldn't even taste the shitakes in it.  Even the sauce was different -- more of the vinegar and probably a thickener like corn starch, and less of the mushroom taste.  

-- Corn Fritters -- Underwhelming.  It certainly looked good; had the delicate taste of corn, but nothing else.  It was actually the sauce that's carrying it, and even then, it falls flat.

-- Dungeness Crab Rolls -- definitely not!  Didn't care for the rolls, and certainly didn't care for the dipping sauce.   

-- Beef Rendang -- I think this was confused with some other types of Thai curry -- this was weak on the Rendang spices (cloves, anise, cardamom), but atypically strong on the kaffir lime.   This could also have been offered as a vegetarian dish as it is very light on the beef, only 20% of the dish is beef, the rest is made up by the potatoes and taro.  It also was very soupy, which is not what you would expect of a Beef Rendang.

--  Crispy Cod Fillet -- this takes the cake.  It was bland!!! The fish was not seasoned and was not crispy.  The sauce was supposed to be muchi curry tartar, but all I can taste of the miniscule amount of sauce underneath, was pure tartar sauce.  Yes it was yellow suggesting turmeric and other spices, but I couldn't taste them!

-- Drinks -- we had the Tombstone, the Sake "something", and the Pineapple, Basil, LIme Agua Fresca.  All of them very disappointing!  the alcoholic cocktails were so imbalanced in favor of the booze, mezcal and sake.  while the bartender likely forgot to put in pineapple juice in the agua fresca since all I could taste was lime.  

All in all, it was a very disappointing, embarrassing, but OVERPRICED experience.  I will never go back, and I will never recommend this place again.
author: Arlene M.

description:
The transition from E&O "Trading" to E&O "Kitchen," as told by our waitress during our New Years Eve dinner, resulted in a 40% re-engineering of the menu.  But what we were not told was that 100% of the food quality, especially taste, diminished along with it.  Despite decent presentation of the entrees, flavor was disappointingly deficient.  Now I have to pass a kidney stone after putting too much salt on everything... 

I'm sorry, but this place fell off BIG TIME!
author: John E.

description:
I'll rate E&O using the compliment sandwich technique.

The space is really cool - airy, nice design, cool mix of communal tables, high tops, and tables that adds a sort of market feel to it, with dramatic lighting and a really polished and pleasant decor. 

But it's loud. Like Vegas loud (see last reviews from Vegas). Add in a way too loud Austrian family next to you and it's like some sort of CIA torture. The satay was really nicely cooked but salt lick salty. The duck rolls were mostly tasty but super greasy.  And our waitress was uppity... borderline rude - seemed like she felt she was doing us a favor by serving us. 

The coconut ceviche on the other had (with halibut that night) was divine. To die for. Perfect. If I go back I'd be tempted to just order 3 of these for a heavenly meal. Particularly if I could pair it with that nights special drink which was sort of sweet martini with basil and cumin and lemon infused vodka and absolutely magnificent. 

All in all a decent place that I'd expect to get 4 or 5 stars in a second tier food city but  not in the food mecca of SF.
author: Howard F.

description: The food highlights were the dumplings, and drinks are really good.
author: Graciela C.

description:
This review is for happy hour.

My sister and I needed a snack before our fancy Italian dinner and after an adequate walk around China Town, yelped and used EaterSF to find E&O. We walked in just after 5 on a Saturday and they sat us right away at a table by the bar.

The Sutter Punch is delish and packs QUITE the punch. 

I really enjoyed the pork spare rib. The sauce was spicy and sticky an the bone had a fair amount of meat on it.

The oysters were fresh and I liked the sauce it came with however they did have some shell inside.

Our waiter was great and very attentive.

A nice choice for a more upscale happy hour in the area with reasonable prices.
author: Danielle K.

description: I'm a fan of happy hour here. Cocktail and wine specials - can't beat that. The $1 oysters aren't bad. Spareribs and naan bread are good. Dumplings and corn fritters aren't bad.
author: Melinda C.

description: Was invited for a corporate event.  Very similar to PF Chang quality of Asian food.  If you don't eat again food often, you might like it.  I found the food lacking in depth of flavor and quite bland. On a Saturday night the restaurant was not full which is indicative of it's lack of appeal.
author: Kendric W.

description:
Still a Great Place!!!

I've been here twice before but not for a couple years.  Took a large party here for lunch and it was absolutely spot-on.  The ambiance, food and service were all outstanding.  Clearly an establishment firing on all cylinders!  The Indonesian Corn Fritters are simply a delight--a must have!  Many other outstanding dishes as well.  In particular our favorites were the Beef Toppoki, Japanese BOP and the Indonesian Fried Rice.  All were well-executed, exceptionally flavorful and artfully presented. Service was completely attentive yet unobtrusive--very difficult to balance, especially with a large group.

Well done E&O!
author: Mike B.

description:
I've wondered what the E&O stood for...based on my experience it would be expectations & outcome.

I expected a typical sf brunch experience (they don't serve brunch, so shows you how much research I did!) with a twist of Asian fusion (whatever that means.).

The actual outcome was a pleasant surprise. Deviled eggs were good. Japanese bop wasn't what I thought it would be, but was still tasty. The black cod was cooked well and was very satisfying. The only thing that I walked away just ok with was the banana tiramisu dessert, which wasn't bad, but didn't stand out.

Overall, a very good outcome and did a good job providing a very good unexpected lunch surprise. I would come back to try the dumplings, as they looked delicious. The decor is also gorgeous.
author: Chris J.

description: Last dinner of the San Fran trip and I cannot complain! We sat at the bar and were immediately greeted by the bartender, Archul. Archul was a multitask-er and helped the bar and the whole restaurant with their drink orders. As busy as he was he still managed to make food and drink recommendations and introduce us to new liquors. The food was incredible I ordered the Shaking Beef and my boyfriend got the cod which melted in you mouth. Food was great and drinks were unique and delicious. Great experience!
author: Christina M.

description: Attended a birthday dinner there. Mushroom and tofu dumplings were to die for, flat iron Kim chi steak was scrumptious! Awesome service. James was the best!
author: Johann M.

description: great vegetarian options and really fast service. if you are planning on getting the dumplings be sure to order another thing, it is not enough for a meal. the pad Thai was phenomenal, and I had a bite of the corn fritter burger which was different but also really good
author: Kate K.

description: I'm 9 years old and writing my first Yelp review. I love the food and all our waiters and waitresses were fantastic, especially Mercedes : -)
author: Naomi K.

description: Great asian fusion food,  good beer selection.  Really enjoyed the indonesian fried rice.   Also the bartenders friendly, creative and helpful, and happy hour menu is a good value
author: Erich T.

description:
First off, this review is purely for the dessert titled Bananamisu. This is a dessert that I daydream about...multiple times a day. It is simply a tiramisu constructed with banana flavors extracted into the cream. I have never tasted anything like it. The natural banana flavor and the traditional tiramisu aspects blend together in such perfect harmony, never with one overpowering the other. 

We ordered the butternut squash ravioli-type appetizer and pad thai. Honestly, the food was mediocre. The unique taste of Asian spices are being overwhelmed by many other unnecessary ingredients. 

I will return for the bananamisu and most likely nothing else.
author: Priscilla V.

description: Amazing sliders!!!!
author: Jess C.

description:
Went here for a birthday dinner and shared a ton of dishes! Great place.

Black cod- delicious. I would come back just to eat this again.

Sweet potato ravioli- also delicious. Mmmmm that sauce.

Tuna tartar on strange yummy wafer things- good and light. Not that unique.

Corn fritters- they're supposedly famous for these but I think they're kinda overrated. I'm less keen on fried stuff though.

Calamari- standard fare, mostly tentacles and extra breading. Not many rings.

Chocolate cake dessert- I'm not a dessert person and I'm definitely not a cake person, but I really liked this a lot. Great texture, and they put a candle in it for us to sing to (and embarrass!) the birthday boy :)
author: L B.

description:
This place rocks!

I used to come here a lot back when it was call E&O Trading Co and now apparently it has been redecorated. Frankly, I like how it used to be and now it's even better. The food here is so good and always on point. It is a little expensive though and the place does get really crowded at times so make sure you make a reservation if it's a Friday or Saturday. I suggest you try the corn fritters since it's their signature and their meat platter is awesome too. 

Happy hour at E&O is great. They have good beers on tap that are reasonably priced. The ladies seem to really like the cucumber martini. The crowd here varies from the older work crowd to tourist to regulars who live around the area. This is definitely not a dancing type happy hour but more of a classy and chic spot to let time pass and forget about your work week. The location is great and staff is always friendly. 

All in all I suggest coming here for some food or a beer, you can't go wrong.
author: Javier G.

description:
Food: Ordered the Eggplant and the Shrimp Skewers. Both were outstanding. The Shrimp Skewers' Mango and Thai Basil sauce was really the star of both dishes. 

Service: Awesome! Had dinner at the bar and chit-chatted with the bartender about a wide variety of things. Very friendly. 

Notes: Very sensitive to allergies, but the food was a liiiiitle bit bland as a result.
author: Michael G.

description: Fantastic, our new go to place in SFO . The menus is awesome. And Chris the floor mgr rocks.
author: Vicki N.

description:
Horrible.   Deviled eggs, some sort of crummy corn fritter thing ... Really, really bad ...

The only reason it gets one star is that the wine list was reasonably priced.
author: N M.

description:
We went for lunch at 2:30 on a Thursday.
It's beautifully designed with an open kitchen. 
Beat and radish salad was amazing as well as the chicken lettuce cups & satay.
I'd come again next time I'm in San Fran!
author: Tony D.

description: We were for lunch. The ambient is interesting and welcoming. The food quality is good but not excellent. The dumplings were great, but the Indonesian rice was so so. The service was good too but not 5-star.
author: Me M.

description: My wife and i were sat right next to the kitchen.  Food  was ok.  The waitress seemed nice the times she came to our table. Not a great overall experience.
author: Erick O.

description:
Giving 3.5 stars.  Upside- great food!  We shared a bunch of appetizers.  Fun and unique dishes and all excellent in terms of flavor, temperature, spice, and presentation.  Service and ambiance was pleasant.

Downside- the chairs when we were escorted to our table had left over food bits from last people.  Lighting also a bit harsh over table.
author: S A.

description: We had a bad customer service experience from the start. Not very accommodating.The food was good but not great. They tried too hard to impress and overwhelmed the taste buds. We sat at the bar to eat and that was a mistake the bartender seemed very angry by this. We didn't receive items we ordered so we just paid the bill and went to eat somewhere else. The interior design was the best experience we had at this place.
author: Jacques D.

description: This is my go to spot whenever I'm downtown. I've actually been here a bunch but am finally writing this review. The restaurant space is vast space and the bar is long. I love their happy hour which serves up hand picked food and drink items. If you come with a pal share the "puppy platter" it comes with all the essential items. Cheers to the great bar staff who is always pleasant and knowledgeable. See you soon E and O.
author: Raquel F.

description: I've been going to this place for over 6 years and last night was definitely the best. They have new menu items like Halibut Ceviche in a coconut/magic broth, their Lapschong deviled eggs were amazing, and the drinks never disappoint. That paired with perfect service and a great atmosphere gets me coming back year after year.
author: matt j.

description: It's great food. The service was good but it wasn't amazing. The deserts were very interesting and it was a fun experience.
author: Nate G.

description:
I am in love with the new space, the new menu and the new cocktail menu. 

Colorful and tasty food that leaves you feeling refreshed, satisified and happy!
author: Shawnana S.

description:
I really like the decor and the ambiance of this place! The staff was really nice and the service was quick.   
The food was not bad, just ok:
-BUTTERNUT SQUASH DUMPLINGS (thai red curry lemongrass sauce, basil oil) Very light and delightful dish. 
-KODA FARMS HEIRLOOM RICE STIR-FRY (gluten free heirloom rice blend, gulf white prawns, char siu pork, vegetables, chilies, tangy soy sauce)  Not a bad dish for someone on a diet.  It's a gluten free fried rice. Very yummy.
-JAPANESE "BOP" (crispy dashi kokuho rose rice, sunny side farm egg, spinach, 
pickles, red chili furikake, bonito flakes, umeboshi plum)  Not bad.  Very slight and smaller portions.  Interesting display of a BOP.

Overall, it was an ok experience.  I probably would like to come here for drinks cause its a nice ambiance.  Parking is a bit tricky.  It's easier to park at the stockton lot around the corner.
author: Ying F.

description: Kinda pricey... food portion isn't that much... good service though.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Excellent food - just a tad bit overpriced. All their seafood entrees are delicious. Asian fusion done right.

service is very crisp and wait time was reasonable each time.
author: Umair K.

description: Went for after dinner drinks.  Nice ambiance, big bar and a good overall space.  Mixed drinks were $10-12, wines $10-16.  Selection was ok.  Had a pretty good old fashioned.  Would go back again.
author: Hui C.

description: Service was awesome but the food was too salty. Plus for ambiance and the unique Asian fusion, but definitely doesn't satisfy my taste buds.
author: Albert C.

description: We celebrated our wedding rehearsal dinner in the Pearl Room of E&O for 13 people.  Joya coordinated our dinner, provided us with a quick checklist for our dinner including menu options, and made sure everything went smoothly.  The Pearl Room was beautiful and fit our group perfectly.   The food was delivered family style and was wonderful.  The standouts were the tots and the portabello kebabs.  The wine selection was great and the service was efficient --- almost too efficient: the starters all came out very quickly in succession.  The dessert option was delicious and they even made a special dessert plating for the couple to celebrate our wedding the next day, which was very thoughtful.  Everyone very much enjoyed the venue, the food, and the service, and we highly recommend E&O and Joya for a future small, private dinner.
author: Beverly W.

description:
Meh....

Came back here for the first time in several years for lunch - it's just been remodeled.

Lunch Beef dish was just over-cooked and just not particularly tasty. Calamari starter was good, but not great.

Service was good, but food has gone down hill.
author: Sheridan H.

description:
I would give E&O three or four stars for the food, but the prices are criminal. I paid $25 for a decent pan of nan and six decent potstickers.

There's an Indian place a few blocks away that does the same naan for half the price, and plenty of places in the nearby Chinatown who do far better potstickers for half the price.

E&O tries and fails to make something unique in its fusion of multiple Asian and Western cuisines. None of the dishes were all that different from their traditional versions, and they were all disappointingly okay. E&O is an overpriced, okay restaurant in a part of town known for amazing food and great value in all price ranges.

I feel like the French after the Louisiana Purchase.
author: Andrew G.

description:
I came to E&O with my friend yesterday for dinner and had no problem making a reservation the night before on Opentable. We were seated promptly and the staff was attentive and friendly. 
I loved the atmosphere and decor here- I felt like I was in a completely different setting and taken away from the outside noise and downtown traffic. Also liked the selection on the menu, there were small plates and entrees but everything sounded tasty. I ordered the Dan Dan noodles and requested for a mild version. The plate was delicious!! The noodles were cooked perfectly and the ground pork with scallions and cucumbers and sauce went together well. The dish was also not spicy but not bland either- the chef did a good job on getting the flavor per my request. Also tried the duck imperial rolls as an appetizer which was also good. 
Overall, very satisfied with the food and dining experience here. Adding to my list of restaurants to eat at downtown for Asian Fusion! I also felt the prices were not over the top- considering the location.
Looking forward to returning soon to try more menu items.
author: Miss H K.

description: Had a delicious dinner here - amazing ambiance (makes for a great date night spot) and the food/cocktails were delicious. We tried ahi tuna tartare (great!), butternut squash dumplings (to die for!), pad Thai (least favorite), and black pepper steak (delic!). Would def recommend this spot
author: Anya R.

description:
Kudos for the effort of making Asian fusion dining but no kudos for failing...they try to bring a bit of twist to all the typical asian dishes, but the results aren't always good.

The great:
- ambiance and service - the night was really enjoyable with the soft lighting and great service and beautiful decor
- the grilled pork tenderloin ($21): the fermented blackbean sauce gave the pork a taste of vinaigrette with an aroma that's not often found in asian dishes and went perfectly well with the pink tenderloin. We got a second order oft his because it was so good.

The good:
- dry fried green beans ($8): the portion was a bit small, but all the right flavours where there and there were some crunchy turnip bits that made the dish fantastically flavourful. 
- matcha green tea affagato ($9): it was creme fraiche ice cream soaked in green tea and a dark chocolate kit kat on the side. Generally creme fraiche is like yogurt, so a bit tangy and sour. Overall it was interesting pairing, though not something I would have regularly.

The meh:
- chicken satay ($12): basically four bucks for each skewer. The chicken was a bit dry and not very flavourful. The satay sauce had a slightly strange taste to it, likely the miso and i didn't think it went very well together.
- indonesian corn fritters ($13): the server recommended this dish saying it's been around for 13 years at the restaurant but it was bland and required the sweet chili sauce to provide it with flavour. The sweet chili sauce was pretty typical in flavour that you can get at any supermarket so the dish was a waste of money.
- salt and pepper calamari ($15): way too much batter. the flavour was passable but it felt like i was eating hard batter a lot of times.
- duch imperial roll ($11): not very memorable. it was like a large spring roll with duck fillings and some herbs. I don't remember it tasting particularly good or bad. Not expensive compared to the rest i guess. 

The big disappointment:
- black pepper shaking beef ( $26): okay the flavour was not that bad, the beef was a little chewy. But at twenty six dollars, this dish is not worth it. It's barely good. it feels like someone cut some beef and added some grocery store canned sauce to it. highly disappointing for the most expensive dish on the menu.

The ouch:
- price here is a bit ridiculous.  if you stick with the smaller dishes and appetizers, it might be just on the expensive side. but if you go with their meat dishes, expect your wallet to be broken.

Overall, the prices are too high for the quality of food. I'd come here for a drink and snack but probably not for a nice meal out.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Just had a wonderful experience here for lunch with a customer. I made reservations 30 min prior on Open Table, and they were ready for my when I got there. We were seated at a nice four person table, even through it was just the two of us, which was great because it allowed for us to do business. The flow of the service was great. 

He had the cod dish, which looked perfectly done -- he finished every last bite. I had the rice gnocchi, which I wouldn't recommend. The sound of it was nice, and it was nice in appearance, but the actual pieces of gnocchi were tough and too chewy.

We had the kimchee as a starter, which I would recommend. It was different than any kimchee I've had before.
author: Laura L.

description:
My (now ex) husband and I came here on our honeymoon back in 2008, so the review is a bit dated, but I'm transferring my UrbanSpoon reviews over to Yelp, so bear with me :)  

The ambiance in this place was great! Everything I ate was delicious, especially the corn fritters. We had ordered one thing that we didn't like at all (an appetizer of ribs with some sort of mustard sauce - I'm not seeing it on the menu now though) & the waitress insisted that she take it off of our bill. The presentation of everything was modern and aesthetically pleasing. Overall, I don't think E&O is anything to make a huge fuss over, but I'd definitely go back. Especially now that my tastes have expanded - I'd be willing to try a lot more from that menu that was once intimidating to me.
author: Kim D.
